number of helpful: 361 of 421 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 26, 2013
												RAGE seems like a strange lovechild if Fallout made love to Quake in the backseat of a racing car. It is a furiously fast-paced FPS with visceral and brutal combat, while at the same time mixing things up with off-road racing, RPG elements, mini-games and crafting.Sounds an awful lot like Fallout, doesn't it? Well, it's not. Despite many striking similarities, RAGE is entirely its own game. It does all the things Fallout does, but in its own way. If you leave your expectations and comparisons at the door and just play the game for what it is, you will find a competent and diverse FPS that may keep you entertained for a good 10-12 hours.RAGE is a linar post-apocalyptic action game with a twist. It has towns with NPCs, quests, exploration, hidden loot and collectibles, mini-games and even racing tracks.But most of all it is a hectic First Person Shooter, and this is where the game shines. The shooter element is the bread-and-butter of RAGE. It's fast, powerful, intense and it feels good! There are a wide range of weapons to use, each of which has numerous different ammunition types to spice things up even more. Take for example the crossbow; it fires regular steel bolts as one would expect - but swap them out with Dynamite sticks and watch your enemies panic as they realize they have only 3 seconds left to live. Swap in the Mindcontrol bolts and the crossbow turns your enemies into deadly walking bombs under your control!The variety of weapons and ammo has you swapping back and forth between them with glee as you leave wasteland mutants in exploded gibs, charred corpses and decapitated slumps. What is even more striking is how the enemies move. They will pounce at you, climb railings to reach you and leap off of walls. They deftly dodge and weave in zig-zag patterns to make your life as miserable as possible. Their movement is fast, sporadic and unpredictable - and it just looks awesome.When you're not dropping mutants by the dozen, the town offers a nice breather away from the gunfights and gives you the opportunity to pick up side-quests for extra challenges. Race for glory at the local racing track or shop and listening to NPC banter. The mini-games range from strumming banjos, throwing dice or even pitting your deck of special playing cards against NPCs. You can also craft your own specialized ammo, grenades and other useful gadgets with ingredients scavenged on missions or bought from merchants.RAGE also has a few downsides, the most glaring perhaps being the poor and sudden ending. The plot is likewise lack-luster, uninteresting and just overall trivial. More often than not I found myself skipping story conversation because it was so bland I just wanted to go back to shooting stuff.The graphics are a mixed blessing. Generally the sky and landscapes are mindlbowingly beautiful, but many of the up-close scenery looks washed out and blurry, sometimes to the point where you can't even make out what you are even looking at.The sound effects and music is very good. The guns sound punchy and futuristic, and the voice acting is excellent from start to finish. The vehicle sounds are, however, quite bland.Overall I feel that RAGE is a worthwhile game that offers a very solid shooter experience and a fairly mediocre "everything else." Definitely worthwhile if you enjoy FPS games and/or wasteland style games.+ Excellent FPS-style gameplay, shooting mutants is a treat+ Great wasteland atmosphere and setting+ Tons of fun guns and ammo to play around with+ Lots of variation; racing, minigames, crafting, collectibles, exploring+ Gorgeous graphics in the landscape/environment/character department+ Excellent voice acting and music, overall good sound design- Muddy and blurry graphics in many interior areas and on up-close objects- The story is uninteresting and lacks engagement- Horrible ending- The game is too easy even on the hardest difficulty- Poor mouse controls when navigating menus and inventory- Engine sounds while driving is pretty weak

content:
er 28, 2013
												People can compare Rage to many other games, however it reminds me most of Borderlands with a touch of Fallout and a pinch of Mad Max. However Rage has something new to offer. Yes, it is similar to other games, however what game is not? Rage has a style all its own and really pulls off what they were going for. This is a very grungy game, yet it has times of bright sunny skies and colorful scenes.The story is not heavily detailed but that's alright for the type of game Rage is. It's a FPS that gets to the point and you never feel bored while playing. I thought the story was enough for me to have an idea of what's going on and get me into the action very smoothly. The first few missions give you a better idea of what's going on and flow of the story feels balanced.The gameplay mechanics are very easy to use and to adapt to. Driving is fluid as is walking. The pace of walking is a bit quick, but I like it that way. Be that as it may, I often slowed down my pace to really take note to the detailed environments of the caves, tunnels and dilapidated buildings I scrounged through. The enemies are a joy to fight and have a mind of their own. From scaling the walls to jumping at the last second to dodge your attack, it quickly reminded me of the splicers who walked the ceilings of rapture in Bioshock. This makes it all the more challenging and enjoyable. Lastly, RAGE incorporates some RPG elements to help sooth that part of my gaming palate in the forms of customization, upgrades and side missions. All of that and a vehicle only multi-player tacked on? I believe that's a pretty good package.All in all, I am happy with this purchase and would recommend this to anyone who enjoys shooters with creative atmospheres. I have read mixed reviews about it's length not being what people had hoped (about 10-12 hours) but then again, many of the shooters I have completed were only about 8 hours. With the existence of towns throughout, this will allow me to pace my gameplay and savor the experience without blowing through it a la any other mindless shooter.

content:
5, 2015
												A real gem in the rough, While this game has a lot of rough edges and if you do buy it you might want to look up some config or visual modification tools in order to make it work for you the game is well done for the most part. While it may not be as open as some other FPS/RPG games out there it does bring a few good things to the table that others do not have. The enemy models, animations and reaction are very well done, fluid and depending on which faction you're fighting against it might play out differently. NPC interactions are good, and facial animations are very well done making them feel organic at times. The story is a bit rough in places and if you've read anything about this game you will already know that the ending is well not great to say the least. While I do wish there was more to the game then what is offered it was mostly fun while it lasted. The tech in the game world is very nice and refreshing; the in game crafting is rather well done and very quick allowing you to use different items against different enemy types. the "big picture" of each scene is mind-blowingly beautiful. This game's canyon vistas are the most intensely gorgeous I've ever seen, and I include Skyrim in that list. Even the interior scenes, with their gross 1990s textures are are composed and lit with an obvious hand-crafted touch. Graphically, it's a "don't miss the forest for the trees" kind of situation. Make no mistake though, the art direction and craftsmanship in-game is absolutely phenomenal and despite the blurry textures,If you can buy/find it on sale like I did when I got it, it’s well worth the money, especially once you tinker with the game engine to make it look/run a little better. It’s far better then anything Gearbox has done to date I can honestly say that, it’s not a boring motionless world with singular friendly/peaceful NPCs, however it is no Fallout 3.

content:
r 4, 2014
												Rage, a post apocalyptic game developed by Id software (the makers of the Doom series) and running on there tech 5 game engine.I played this game for both Xbox 360 and PC on Steam. I pre-ordered this game when it was available on Steam so I paid $59.99 for it, its now (as of this re-review) $19.99 and the one DLC is $4.99.The game is your traditional FPS shooter game. Its heavily action packed and has lots some cool weapons. I personally found that the shotgun was the best one to use and favored that over all other weapons. There is crafting in the game as well but I find it very simplistic and only of use when you need to make items to break open locked doors, med packs or throwing blades.I did play both the solo campaign the coop and the multiplayer side of the game. I am amazed at how well this game looks and plays and the voice actors used for voicing the game characters. The graphics are also superb and very detailed and amazing to look at both scenery and attacking enemies.The game includes an addon that wasn't originally available unless it was pre-ordered and that's the sewers to explore. When it was released the game wasn't what gamers were hoping it would be, an open world post apocalyptic game as the media coverage lead you to believe. Once you started playing you quickly found it to be a closed world and once you go through a mission area you can't go back and do it over to get any secrets you left behind or want to find. I didn't find this game to offer any replay value in the solo campaign at all. Don't get me wrong the first play through it increasingly good and very enjoyable.The multiplayer side of the game is just a dune buggy race doing lap after lap and shooting at one another with mini guns and rockets. Its like deathmatch but with cars. Nothing new provided here by Id Software in this regard.The says there is Coop play however this can be misleading because you would expect that you can play the campaign with a friend but this isn't the kind of Coop play that Rage offers. Its basically playing objective based missions with a friend.Rage play's very good with the Xbox 360 controller and that is what I use for all my game play and its what I prefer over the traditional keyboard and mouse.Overall the game is totally amazing for my first impression and first play through but severely lacks for replay value. However the multiplayer and Coop play looks as if it was an after thought.In my opinion Id Software dropped the ball on this game or turned a tech demo into a game. Not sure which. This game made Id Software look dated and relying on its old game play style hopping for success. Had the game been an open world type game with the ability to play it cooperatively then it would have been ground breaking.Pro'sAmazing GraphicsVoiced CharactersBladed throwing weaponCon'sClosed worldNo replay valueCoop play is not campaign basedMultiplay is just deathmatch playCVGAnton's Ratingːfirst_starːːfirst_starːːfirst_starː

r 24, 2014
												I love RAGE up until the point where it suddenly railroads you into a final mission and then ends abruptly. The first half is great - made even better by the Scorchers DLC. The shooting and AI are first class, the environments and character models look incredible even in 2014 and until you get near the end of it you'll be wondering why everyone gets so down on it. But up until then, RAGE ♥♥♥♥in' rules. Also the racing and co-op are surprisingly well made and fun. Find someone to play them with. Also, wingsticks.

content:
20, 2016
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below) Game Name: RAGE Original Release: 2011 Genre Tags: FPS; Action; RPG; Post-Apocalyptic My Overall Grade: A Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 20-45 hours Multiplayer Aspect: Auxiliary Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Aesthetes; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs REVIEWRAGE is an extremely underrated game, and is definitely worth your consideration. It's another game where you find yourself exploring a post-apocalyptic wasteland performing missions for money and trying to survive— then wind up saving the world. In that sense, it feels a bit like a Borderlands game, but with a serious undertone and with realistic-style graphics. When you start to play it, though, you will find it definitely has the FPS experience of an ID game.It isn't an open-world game really in the true sense of the meaning. But it isn't exactly forcing you from one level to the next, either. I personally found the world immersive and the story engaging. The narrative is well written, even if it relies heavily on established clichés. And I thought the graphics were quite nice; very, very nice actually— there was several times I found myself taking a moment to look around at the scenery and grab screenshots. The gorgeous visuals and interesting narrative establish an undeniably captivating presentation.As far as gameplay is concerned: the mechanics and controls were solid, and the combat is exciting.  There is a decent amount of gun and enemy variety, but there definitely could be more. It’s enough to keep you interested, but it is certainly somewhat limited. The desire to explore more beautiful landscapes and to finish the interesting story will keep you intrigued, though, if you find yourself growing bored with the combat in the later stages of the campaign. It is certainly a decently sized game. And there are sidequests and minigames that are pretty fun if you are into achievements and extras.Besides the campaign, there is a coop multiplayer mode where you can clear dungeons with a friend. There are a good number of missions to beat and they tie into the main campaign as little background stories of NPCs and locations. It is quite fun, actually, and adds a very welcome bonus layer of content.Also, there is a racing multiplayer mode (for which I had trouble finding games, to be honest). I was able to find a few games with a low amount of people— but it wasn't living up to its full potential. It matters little in the long run, as the rest of the game is well worth it.And so: if you are looking for a story-driven, atmospheric, and action-packed FPS game with a high standard of quality, you would be wise to give RAGE some consideration.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

content:
15, 2015
												I've read so many things about RAGE, how it was a huge disappointment, what kind of a lacklustre game it was. I needed to give it a try and all I can say is that while the game is a lot better than its counterparts in many areas, it lacks some vital things to make the world more vivid.Pros:- Enemy AI is great, they are responding to how you play. If you're going head on with a shotgun in your hands, they try to stay far and shoot you down with AR's or surround you with their greater numbers. If you're playing one shot one kill, they act swiftly and try to mow you down with their athletic skills.- Enemy variety is good. You never find yourself killing the same type of enemy all the time. Even in missions and bandit clans, variety is good.- Town designs are good and based on real world architecture. For example Subway Town is based on Chinese style, Jackal Territory resembles Brazilian Favelas, Dead City is the classic metropolis.- Different accent and characteristics for every bandit clan feels great, a lot better than any other generic bandits in games.- If you play stealthy, there are a lot of times where you can see how bandit clans work, how they are small military dictatorships, ruled by benevolent and paternal figures. Great insight.- Missions are great, especially Dead City is one of the most memorable FPS missions for me.- Caricature NPCs, like J.K Stiles and Dietrich are great. - References in the story, things that are hidden shows that this game was made with passion and the goal was to lead the player to experience the game fully.- Boss fights.- Ammo and weapon variety can make any FPS player wet, but an oldschool LMG could add a lot to the gameplay.Cons:- Sİlent protagonist is a huge no for this kind of game. I've been asleep for years, I should speak, eat, drink, love, hate etc. I need to do things that makes me feel what it's like to be a human again. For example, one of the first missions could be getting in shape something like (Run 20 miles, do some push ups (like in GTA:SA)). The protagonist feels like a mindless robot.- Alienation of the protagonist continues with no personal story. Finding devices that contained data about him should have told who he was, all you get for motivation to play is "this is this, that is that, now go kill them."- Secondary missions could use some variety. Assassinate this guy, destroy that thing, drive for this person, try to convince someone, organize resistance, build up defences etc. would be great and very fitting for the personality as he was one of the "chosen ones" before the apocalypse. - NPC dialogues are weird. One step and he starts talking, one step to back, he ends talking abruptly.- Towns and settlements should have been more lively, developed according to your actions. For example you do one work for future expansions when you go back you should see that the town has expanded.- More enterable buildings could be better.- Subtitles inside the towns are ♥♥♥♥ed, your dialogues are interrupted with megaphone announcements.- Needed more quests.- Economy is ♥♥♥♥. You do some quest, you earn money and you give it all back to get some ammo and upgrades for the next mission.- Eastern Wasteland is the definition of dull. All gray with nothing interesting to see around.- Last mission, ending of the story was terrible, no decent closure to the story and there was no boss fight. In general it was easier than most of the other missions.- If more sandbox elements were added it could enhance the game incredibly (actually I suspect that they were going for this at one point, but when they were acquired by Bethesda, the plans went to ♥♥♥♥).Seems like RAGE has great potential to build upon and all of the Pros I listed are examples of great mechanics and level design. Only thing that they needed to improve upon is story and open world elements. I, personally, would be more excited about a RAGE 2 than the new DOOM.P.S: People said that they got lots of texture pop-ins that are of course pretty annoying. But for me, with my ♥♥♥♥♥♥ laptop with Intel HD 3000 and 4 GB RAM, it ran like a charm. Even explosions did not cause FPS drops.

content:
12, 2015
												RAGE is a great game at first. Everything feels unique . The graphics are incredible and the atmosphere stunning. The weapons feel satisfying and the enemy AI responsive. The enemies are not too tough , but not too easy either. The story seems interesting in the beginning too. The driving can be fun and there are options to modify your weapons and vehicles. The world seems big enough for you to explore , which is also pretty nice. The crafting system is simple and useful. Additionally , the mechanics in total feel useful .There are also plenty of mini-games you can play in order to earn some extra cash which are pretty fun. The combat system is similar to most of the shooters today, nothing special , but was made better and more engaging by specific mechanics , like the wingsticks . Overall, the first few hours spent in the game were enjoyable and the game just felt great. After the first few hours of gameplay,however,  the game starts going downhill. The weapons  stop feeling that great and the game starts to repeat itself just to make you feel that it's longer. The missions feel incredibly repetitive and I just felt that the only thing I was doing was to drive from point A to point B and then kill endless waves of enemies.  I also started getting really mad about my character , since I never got to even hear his voice. Even the driving started becoming extremely boring and the challenge had all been lost , since I was never pressed for ammo. There were infinite supplies of everything : grenades , bandages , ammo. The enemies stopped being interesting and handling them was just too easy. I didn't even get to finish the game , since the atmosphere and gameplay became so repetitive that drove me mad! It felt like an endless motive.. Last but not least ,the lack of cutscenes took away the immersion for me as well. It felt like the game lacked something basic , apart from the other. As a conclusion , every aspect of the game was simply ruined by the unneccesary extreme length of the storyline , which caused repetitiveness.To sum up , RAGE is a fun shooter at first , but as you get used to the mechanics and the gameplay  , as well as the story and the mission patterns , it stops being  immersive and throws away the potential.Thanks for reading and I hope that this review has been helpful!

content:
1, 2014
												I kept going hot & cold with Rage to start with, but my perserverence was rewarded when the story line kicked up a gear & suddenly, hours flew by. The whole linear story line holds no issues with me, there's nothing wrong with a single thread-story if it's an immerseive experience.On the one hand, it has the same issue Farcry 2 has; it's side jobs that extend the game time are little repetative at times, popping you out of the experience & it has a typical id trait that means the character feels slightly ponderous in his movement. Not a major thing, but something I need a little game time to adapt to.However, that said, the combat is excellent, the AI engages in tactics that vary from one group or tribe to the next; some use melee weapons, others keep their distance, the Authority uses armour & sheilds. They use grenades, they retreat when you over power a squad, they use cover... It really holds onto you as a player. The mutants, meanwhile, are aggressive, really fast moving & resistant to injury, so you have to be accurate & prepared to retreat yourself. They crawl on any surface so appear out of no where, giving some genuine tension when an NPC tells you to go into mutant-infested locations.Secondly, the little mini-games; trump cards, gambling machines, holographic games to bet on, racing... all make it feel like there are actual communities looking for entertainment & diversions. You're not forced to engage with these, but they do add detail to the 'world'.While the car segments aren't the worst in an FPS, OK at best, it's the FPS part that makes the game. All the weapons have different flaws & strengths, all have various ammo types to play with that give advantages but also have drawbacks. This means you have to use your loadout rather than just use one gun as everything is useful & necessary. Remote control cars with bombs, sentry bots/turrets. emp grenades... all of these can be built using parts found laying around, plus to get a dead characters ammo, you have to 'use' them, all making the player get involved in the game, rather than just shooting anything that moves. As different groups & tribes favour different weapons, you're forced to consider what guns to use depending on who you're fighting.The problem for Rage is that Doom 3 & id's reputation hangs around it's neck a bit, colouring what is a good story driven FPS. Give it a fair chance, put enough time in for the plot to shift up a gear, 5 hours plus at least, & it will reward you. For me, a fully filled-out world is more than just being a sandbox shooter & Rage is an example of that. It's not a top game, but it's pretty good & certainly worth spending time with.

												This is a hell of a game. I remember it getting heavily critizied when it first came out for technical issues, but these have been fixed now, you will need a decent rig to be able to play RAGE on full graphics, understandably though, since it looks absolutely stunning. The game play reminded me very much like Borderlands, lots of different types of weapons, and your vehicle that you can upgrade with different weapons and armour. The there so much content here, just the right amount of side missions to go along with the main story, that makes the flow of the game feel good. There is a few dull moment where you find yourself running from point to point in the cities, but they come part in parcle with this sort of game. Another interesting feature would be the racing, this is done very well, the controls are perfectly carried out, not difficult at all, and it is actually a really nice addition to the game, it gives a nice break between running and gunning. I would really recommend RAGE, there is about thirty hours of content here and you can always get this really cheaply now days.

												It was definitely fun. But there are a few things that really took away from it.Positive:- The graphics and environments are still amazing, even today.- The AI is incredible. Enemies are dificult enough to keep you awake. Their death animations are realistic, and make you feel like you actually just killed a real human being... yay.- The combat is fun and engaging, though you'll never be pressed for ammo. - The racing is pretty good, even if it's almost impossible to lose.Negative:- Your character is boring. He's silent, and has basically no personality beyond people telling him that he's awesome.- The main antagonists aren't even seen until the second half of the game.- The main antagonists are basically just future Nazis.- The textures take a while to pop in.- The final mission is really really short, and there's no huge boss battle. Just a bunch of easy-♥♥♥ enemies that I breezed through with a shotgun.- The ending isn't really explained, and makes no sense at all.I give it a 7/10. Worth at least one playthrough.

content:
ber 14, 2014
												First off, I think this game is awesome, which is made even better by the fact that I got it for free with my graphics card back when it came out.  However, its a VERY mixed bag in terms of quality in various categories.TEXTURES:  Terrible pretty much across the board.  The game engine also mishandles the loading of the textures so that they "pop in" if you rotate your view at even a modest speed.  The pop in problem can be minimized via config tweaks, but there isn't much that can be done for the low quality assets themselves.LIGHTING:  Disappointing to say the least.  The vast majority of shadows are baked in and ugly, and the few objects with dynamically-rendered shadows (enemies, cars, etc.) only cast a single shadow from the strongest light source, leading to shadows suddenly shifting when the strongest light source changes.  The particle and distortion effects created by things like torches look great, however.  The only other lighting effects to speak of are some weak HDR and specular maps.GAMEPLAY:  Once you fix the narrow default FOV (+cvaradd g_fov 15 in the launch options), the game is great.  The weapons feel epic and you can carry ludicrous amounts of ammo for them in up to three different flavors (e.g. buckshot, pulse shot, and exploding shells for the shotgun).  The racing side of the game isn't quite as good as the shooting, mostly due to a uniform lack of variety making it something of a chore later on, but everything handles well.  In addition, this game has some of the best animation I have ever seen, particularly the enemy behavior.  They jump off of walls and combat roll in an effort to avoid your fire, and their death animations are wonderfully unique, combining scripted sequence and ragdoll physics seamlessly.  Also, quicksaves!  Every time a PC game omits a manual saving feature, a puppy dies.  Fact.RANDOM STUFF:  The mouse feels janky in the menus, but feels fine in game.  The cursor becomes almost unusable at lower sensitivities.  Also, some areas of the game get blocked off as you progress through the main story, so you'll want to complete any and all side quests you see first thing upon entering a new location.  In addition, the game could do with being a bit more difficult.  The amount of extra money and upgrades that can be found through exploration is either good or awful, depending on how OCD you are.  Lastly, this game has little in the way of replay value or endgame content, as all you can do is run the Mutant Bash arena figher thing or any of the races over and over again.  Each co-op mission is standalone and the multiplayer is racing only.I'd give this game an 8/10 overall, the absolutely incredible old-school inspired gunplay quickly makes you forget that the game looks older than Half-Life 2.  Oh, and don't even bother buying this game without the Scorcher's DLC.  The extra weapons are a riot (nailgun and railgun, the quake classics), it allows you to keep playing after you complete the final mission, so you can backtrack and do any side quests you may have missed, and it grants you access to the Ultra Nightmare difficulty, which is as close to challenging as this game gets.  Thanks for reading!

number of helpful: 73 of 89 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
er 14, 2013
												First and foremost: RAGE is a strikingly beautiful game. Coming from iD, I would expect no less. Since the dawn of the shooter they've been at the forefront of cutting edge technology with a minimum of requirements. With new engine iD Tech 5, they've done it again - this is one of the most beautiful game worlds ever realised. It's staggering the amount of detail that can be seen in this title, from the cliffs and canyons to the exquisite characters. But for all it’s beauty, RAGE is a shooter very much stuck in the past, and while story and character have been beefed up a great deal from past iD products, they just can’t compare with shooters of today. RAGE is wonderful to play, but caring about the game world or having an emotional attachment to any character is a darn sight harder.You awaken in the beginning from a cryo-chamber after many hundreds of years of slumber. The world has mostly been destroyed by an asteroid, and various mutants, bandits and factions now control various parts of this ‘wasteland’. Upon exiting the safe confines of this vault, noting that the other inhabitants have long since deceased, you’re attacked by a mutant and saved by a local. In short time you’re given a gun and you’re told to start shooting. As is the pedigree of this developer, RAGE is a shooter first and foremost.It’s a very traditional shooter as well, corridors and small warehouses rule the day, and enemies jump out from the shadows and behind inaccessible doors. While the game world is at times large, this is more of a playground for vehicular destruction and transportation, getting from one location to another, and can be considered filler. While it has its moments it certainly feels like a part of the world to give it a greater ‘Mad Max’ vibe – there for the sake of being there, and it begins to lose its sheen the longer you play. However, it plays second fiddle to the shooting, and while no one could accuse RAGE of being revolutionary, it’s not held back by its lack of ambition.In fact, because of this, RAGE’s old-school gameplay feels a little fresh, even if it’s playing to its out-dated strengths. The guns, for instance, genuinely feel powerful, and the ragdoll physics really show their strength. Shoot a guy with an arrow, and he’ll stick to a wall. Blast out their legs and they’ll flip over as they’re in full pelt. Shields crack and splatter from impacts, skulls crack open, and generally, the various guns, each with multiple ammo types, feel creative and meaty.In addition, there are many single use items that can be crafted, found or purchased throughout the game world, such as bladed boomerang ‘wingsticks’, gun turrets, spider droids and RC bomb cars, to name a few. Occasionally you may need to be creative, with the enemy A.I being considerably good. They tend to work together, hide behind shield carrying allies, flush you out with bombs, call orders to each other, flank and generally do their best to kill you. Even suicidal mutants will jump back and forth, hop around corridor walls and ceilings, only to backstab you. The various enemies each have their own powers and weapons they favour as well, zig-zagging while they throw screen-darkening clutter at you, ducking and dodging as you’re blasting away. Thankfully, the pacing is spot on, you never feel over-whelmed, and there is always enough challenge.Apart from the shooting, there are odd jobs around towns, such as blowing up bandits cars in certain areas, various race types, delivering timed mail, and even a circus like murder simulation television show where you are literally put into arenas of death. None of it is as compelling as the main quest, but it does help break up the monotony, and helps create the illusion of a living, breathing world. The detail to RAGE is exhaustive, in only the best and most obsessive point possible.This obsession has been carried to some of the most detailed and amazing character models yet seen in any game. Sadly, they’re not all too interesting. Especially when the game attempts to shift gears and provide a sense of tension – I just wasn’t feeling it. The good guy archetype character is boring as hell, the corrupt characters as cliché’d and obvious from the start. Everyone plays their character, but there is no real personality, and there never feels like a compelling villain or even a compelling reason to your character. The world feels like it’s had far too much lavished upon it’s visuals that it’s characters have become secondary.The faceless bandits and “Authority” you fight throughout the game might as well be very detailed stick figures with some great artificial intelligence. Fun to shoot at but why should I care? For all the amazing detail, and terrific character animations, especially by the town folk, they might as well all be playing parts in a stage play. Yet even as I played away, hoping to find a payoff, I was quite disappointed. There is no real satisfying conclusion or encounter, and it felt like I was really only fighting for my own personal entertainment rather than any emotional connection.As of this writing, RAGE has been available for just over two years and it’s more interesting modes have been all but abandoned by gamers. The online multiplayer, once iD’s main claim to fame, is not supported, and the co-op mode, while fun, with a friend I was able to rope in, never felt like a compelling addition, just a very good one. And that really sums up how I feel about RAGE. It’s a game that feels rooted in the developer’s past while having the vision, the visuals, and the environment, to look towards the future. RAGE proves that iD knows how to craft a fun shooter, yet struggles to create compelling characters or even a memorable narrative. Why should I care about the town of Wellspring when I only just entered it? Despite the context, RAGE is still a blast to play. It may not be revolutionary, but its still a finely crafted shooter that is a whole heaping of fun and comes recommended as something a little old-school.8.0/10.

0, 2015
												I wish Steam had a "Meh" rating, because that's how I felt about Rage.  Not a solid "No" but definitely not a "Yes."  RAGE is, let's be clear, an old-school shooter.  In spite of slightly open visuals, most of your FPS action occurs in the same general tunnels and limited pathways that Id Software has been doing since Wolfenstein 3D.  Oh, and there's a driving/racing component which is decidedly "meh."  The IdTech 5 engine is visually reasonably pretty, but the game is, I gather, pretty poorly optimized to take full advantage of the highest resolution textures.  But to be honest, I don't find the graphics all that amazing, and graphics alone don't sway me without otherwise solid gameplay.The story itself is pretty humdrum stuff, and ends rather abruptly.  I gather we won't be seeing a sequel, at least not any time soon, since Id is busy with Doom 4.  Honestly, it's nothing special.  Post-apocalyptic wasteland controlled by authoritarian regime (very cleverly known as "The Authority."  Yeah.).  Plucky rebel faction fights against them and sees you as their possible savior because...aw hell, I forget why.  But whatever.  You're the chosen one.You fight alone through Id corridors using mostly typical weapons (pistol, shotgun, assault rifle, sniper rifle, etc.).  There's some variation there, but it's all the usual suspects.  The gunplay itself is kind of meh, really.  I found the sound design for the weapons to generally be kind of underwhelming.  They seem to "clatter" rather than "boom," if that makes sense.  The wingstick is kinda neat, but limited in ammo.The minigames are generally pretty forgettable.  Gambling stuff, racing, and rhythm games, really.  Nothing special.Honestly, the game plays like an "also ran" to Borderlands, but it takes itself much more seriously and lacks any co-op component.  I'd say it's worth not more than $5.  At that rate, it's decently fun to run around and shoot stuff.  But it's a fairly disposable game and even at a $5 price tag, you won't be missing much if you skip it.

content:
er 25, 2013
												For all the artistic and technical talent that Id has at its disposal, you'd think that after all these years they'd pick up someone who could write an interesting story. But Rage, like every property Id had created, has a shallow and generic setting, a mere framework for the gameplay it supports. And sadly, the gameplay equally lacks in innovation.That's not to say I didn't have fun; for an action-shooter FPS, the combat could be remarkably tense, thanks to some good AI and an impressive moveset for all the enemies. The NPCs advance, take cover, throw grenades, retreat, and even try to drag their wounded carcasses out of the firefight. The fights were probably the best part of the game, which is all the more odd since the weapons you fight with are so dismayingly underpowered (in fact, the bulk of my kills were with the pistol with which you start the game). I have equally little to say in favor of the mission-based gameplay and even less about the abysmal driving segments, both of which seemed tacked on to show off the open world technology rather than for interesting gameplay.And what about that technology? The graphics engine -IdTech5 - excels in creating large detailed levels with sharp textures; there's no low-res skybox in this game! But it rarely takes advantage of this technology; the outdoor levels are broken apart by narrow canyons so you rarely get a feel for the expansiveness of the world. Worse, this impressive long-range detail comes at a cost to the short; close up, the models are distinctly low-polygon in comparison to those used in other modern games. In many areas, Rage looks decidedly second-class.Throw in a variety of other gaffes - serious technical issues (albeit none that effected me), uninteresting "mini-games", unskippable cinematics and a noticeable lack of content - and its not hard to understand why some are calling Rage just another Id tech-demo. It has its moments, but as a complete product it is significantly lacking.

content:
er 28, 2014
												+ Beautifully realised game world. When the textures are at their peak they're gorgeous, and this game is a prime example of Post-Processing done right. There is an unbelievable amount of visual fidelity & attention to detail in the game that makes the environments feel seamless, believable and immersive.+ Fantastic animations and voice acting make for lively, genuine characters.+ Great enemy AI - though their banter gets repetitive, they'll duck & weave and take cover to make combat more difficult for you.+ Satisfying gunplay, with weapons that feel like they have some kick on account of good audio mixed with realistic enemy reactions.+ Linear, but with PLENTY of exploration. Don't go in expecting Fallout's expanse or Call of Duty's hand-holding; RAGE sits fairly solidly as a mid-ground between these two ends of the spectrum.+ The driving is actually FUN. Vehicles handle nicely, and I found myself playing all the races out of enjoyment rather than necessity.- Horrible texture pop-in, which detracts greatly from the experience in some areas where flat, mushy Play-Doh surfaces are rampant. No, your eyes aren't blurry... that's just the game's major gaping technical flaw.- Easier difficulty than you'd expect from some of the godfathers of First Person Shooters. I'm usually a normal difficulty kinda guy, but if you have ANY experience with FPS games then "Normal" is a vacation and "Easy" is just insulting. "Hard" feels like the definitive experience, where it's difficult enough that you'll want to experiment with everything in your arsenal, but not SO difficult that you can't rely on the basic pistol to carry you through most situations. Seasoned shooter fans will want to skip right to "Nightmare" or "Ultra-Nightmare", but even then the veterans and masochists will probably leave unsatisfied.- Boring soundtrack that really doesn't live up to the standard of the sound effects & ambience. It's uninspired, and frankly too loud - I turned it down, but you wouldn't be missing out on much to just turn it off altogether.- Pre-order DLC shenanigans. Generally this isn't an issue because the content isn't worthwhile or players can buy it afterwards, but the Anarchy Edition content is valuable and can only be obtained by hunting down a DLC code for sale or cheating. Throw Pop Rocket ammo in the Double Barrel Shotgun and you have a dual grenade launcher that makes quick work of difficult bosses, and the Fists of Rage & Rat Rod buggy are straight-up statistical improvements over the vanilla versions. The armor essentially combines the game's 3 "classes" into one, making your life in the game much easier.On top of my playtime here, I also played on PS3 at release and achieved 100% - I bought it again to experience PC graphics and play The Scorchers.

ber 23, 2015
"Immersive FPS & Road Rampage from ID"Rage was the long anticipated project of ID Software. Some mixture of a decent FPS and a wasteland stockcar racing like in Borderlands. Ofc the racing controls are not the most amazing but it makes quite fun to do some boost jumps and armed car fights. There's also a MP. But it's just concentrated on MonsterBashTV and some car arenas. Unfortunately it's quite laggy.However the end product has breathtaking good graphics, especially the 64bit version if you buy the DLC. Rumors tell the DLC "The Scorcherer's Job Path" was once included in the main game and just bought separately to make more money. Bad tongues consider the games as one unique 40GB texture because no stone seems like the other. The skybox looks just amazing. All human characters including the enemies feel pretty vivent and natural in their animations. Otherwise some plants are rendered as awful 2D sprites into the 3D world.  The enemy AI is also brilliant. They act smart and take cover, flee on losses or try to jump on you. The campaign is pretty linear. You will meet several families and communities that you can join after you finished some missions for them. Some new interesting features are a quick weapon menu for 4 weapons, different bullet types, several craftable items like spider turrets and lock grinder, melee weapon wingsticks, defib unit for after death revive (max 3 times). Rage is just an impressive graphics adventure.

content:
0, 2015
												A semi-open world semi-linear FPS game. You are a survivor of a post-apocalyptic world, battling bandits and mutants at first until you are dragged into a resistance in war with a corrupted army of battle armor soldiers.This game have one linear main quest, and a number of side quests per main event. Each main quest involve you traversing an area like a city, a dungeon, or a tunnel to find something or kill everyone. Backtracking/sidetracking options are very limited, so there is no feeling of repetition at all.Weapon options are padded very nicely. The variety are there and not too overwhelming. Your guns are upgraded progressively, and each have their own pro and cons. Your most basic guns are still very useful near the end of the game when you have access to upgraded ammos. The crafting system is there, but I find myself only crafting a few items and ignore all the rest. The sentry bots are kinda OP though, they are very useful in a fight and their ingredients are cheap and common.There are plenty of mini-games to explore during your main-quest downtime. There's a racing game that is actually pretty good! And there's a collectible card game where the cards are part of the game's collectible items scattered throughout the world. There's an arena for you to kill mutants for money when you just want to kill stuff.Although it is considered an old release now, you will still need a powerful rig to run this game. The graphics are very good even when compared to today's standard. The gameplay itself is good, but the menu controls feels like a bad console port, mouse sensitivity is very inconsistent.For achievement huntersThe Scorchers DLC is needed for 100% completion. Minimum 2 playthroughs are recommended if you want to collect all the achievements. Single player achievements are all quite doable, and all of the missable achievements are no longer missable after years of patches. Except a few will require some luck and patience if you aren't very good in that mini-game. Multiplayer is dead, 3-player boosting is needed for 100% completion. Also, 2-player coop buddy will be needed for the coop campaign.The ending is kinda disappointing.Other than that, this is a very good game.My score: 9/10

content:
er 24, 2016
												Pay no mind to the bethesda badge on the box, this is actually an id software game (and it IS in face developed by them). So straight out the door you should immediately remove fallout from your mind, and while you're at it borderlands (although the world is similar). Look at the games id made: Doom, Wolfenstein, and Quake are the ones that come to most minds and should be a great example of what kind of game this isNo, there is no real RPG element to this game. No there is no crazy loot system. No it is not a huge open world (although it is probably the most open world-ish of any id game). No it is not a multithreaded complex story. But then again, did any of id's games have any of that? So please stop thinking it's a bethesda game before you buy it, you'll thank me.So what IS this game then? It's an id game. For its time it had amazing ground breaking graphics (and still looks great to this day). It has very tight and crisp combat with very well done controls, perfect level design, and amazing ai. And when I say amazing ai i mean I put it in my list of games with best ai. It's not mind blowing because of it's complexity and intuition, but because of the variety and character it gives all the enemies.So what's the downside? This game is one of those games where a developer obviously is trying something new to the point where you feel it isn't in their typical style. As a result a lot of the "fluff" content and features feel not only mediocre, but also unnecessary. Also because this game does not focus primarily on level design it's not something I see myself going back and playing again and again like I would with the old doom and quake titles.In short I do consider this a great game, but certainly not id's best form. The combat and level design are really at the quality only id was capable of (I say was because id is no longer id), and the new tech that Carmake put in this is pretty awesome. It's a blast and, while short lived overall, it is well worth every penny of the $10 price. It might even make you feel hopeful about the game industry again, you jaded ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

												If you don't expect what it can't deliver, it's an amazing game.  Stunningly beautiful environment art and great guns with good variety (and I find myself switching all the time).  Good level design.  It's quite a rigid and pretty heavily scripted world but it's beauty never ceases to amaze and the gameplay keeps being fun for a long while. Story is nothing to rave about and the characters are forgettable, but the setting of the game is so well presented, it never really becomes too much of an issue.  Overall, if you like good old FPS action delivered with a level of fidelity raised by a good margin, Rage is a really solid pick.

er 18, 2015
												Having finished the game I'm conflicted to 100% recommend the game.If we consider a game having a beginning, a middle and an end, then this game has a strong beginning, a heavily declining middle and a completely missing ending.Without spoiling anything of the story:You expect the final to be your last stand, having your strongest weapons at the ready only to find yourself finishing the game via cutscene.Personally, the ending was a letdown and I would consider it a key event which should trigger the finalphase, but it was the end of the game and I doubt we will ever see a fullfilling ending.All in all this game is a "somewhat" in every category it represents.An O.K. shooter with utility ammunition or gadgets which you will only ever use once to progress the story.Acceptable graphics once you follow the guide posted on steam to improve the visuals of the game.Weapon upgrading is shallow and only for the base weapons every other weapon stays unmodified and yet more effective than any of the upgraded weapons. (Excpect for the shotgun. Shotgun is god, especially with the alternative ammo.Story starts off somewhat strong but in the end you are the maid for everything; a simple goon that does what he's told.Enemy variety is scarce. They may look different but behave the same. They either charge at you fast with a melee weapon, slow while shooting with heavy ordnance and armor or hiding behind cover and shooting with their forehead exposed for a clean shot.The minigames are there but are neither lucrative nor rewarding.The DLC is available early and awards you with a "one shot, one kill"-weapon. Noice.In conclusion:It's a borderline OK game, because graphics have to be improved from your side otherwise your experience is kinda "blurry".Worth the buy on sale but with an unsatisfying / abrupt "ending". You have been warned.PS: The video showing the devs of the game boasting about the features of the game is highly exagerated. Having experienced all listed features it's a meh : an attempt has been made out of 10.

18, 2014
												I just finished my third play through of Rage not because it’s such an awesome game but because it’s a 20 gb installation and I’m going to get my headache’s worth before I finally uninstall it. I actually bought the physical DVD version (free after rebate!) and it was a pain getting it installed and registered with Steam. Those of you who buy the game through Steam shouldn’t have any problems though.I heard that Rage got a lot of flak when it came out because it’s from Bethesda and people thought it would be an HD Fallout game with drivable cars. Instead it’s a mostly linear shooter with some crafting elements and side quests. The graphics really reminded me of Doom 3 (ID Software developed the game) right from the start except with the game taking place mostly in the sunny outdoors.  I suppose it’s technically “open world” but there’s no built in game map, so when you’re cruising in your car you really just follow waypoints. The world’s not that big anyways though. Rage is NOT an RPG, so there is no level up system or skill point system. Instead you rely on your array of weapons and different ammo types to blast your way through. Non-spoiler story synopsis: An asteroid hits the Earth and a bunch of “arks” are seeded around the world to wake up after the catastrophe. You play one of the ark survivors waking up and exploring the post-apocalyptic world. This means mutants, bandits, and high tech “new world order” enemies. Really, the story isn’t very well explained through gameplay. Kind of spoiler: There’s no final boss! You’re just playing along in the last area and after holding off a swarm of enemies the game’s over. I was surprised since I had been hording up ammo and didn’t get to use some of the special ammo I was saving up. In all I think the game took about 12 hours to finish but on this my third run I’m skipping some of the side missions. Like I mentioned earlier, there’s no level ups anyway so I won’t really be missing out on anything but story. Overall I’d give the game a thumbs up. Good graphics, a decent challenge, and pretty cheap nowadays (I think it’s about $5 on sale sometimes). Multi-player is dead though, so factor that into your buying decision.

												I tried to like this game. I really tried. I played it ages ago and got up to Kvasir and then just stopped out of lack of desire to continue. Started fresh with the hope of finishing another game in my library and this time I'm knee deep in Subway Town's missions, but I got to a point where I just can't.The biggest crime this game does is being mediocre. It's a competent shooter with bad design choices, poor and convoluted writing, monotonous unskippable dialogues, bland characters, and even worse animation of said characters. But by far the weakest part of the game are the enemies.What broke the camel's back for me was the god damn Muties. I just... It's so frustrating to have to go through quest after quest that just has these shottie fodder running at you over, and over, and over, and over... Just to end it off predictably fighting a kraken mutie, and then run back through the same path you went in, cause yay boring level design. Bandits atleast have you facing off and picking them off from a distance while some either rush you or hop on a turret. FYI, car sections aren't any different. Once you've done the Wellspring races, and got annoyed by the bandits attacking you on your commute between missions, you're not getting anything new.But even then, there is no variety of gameplay styles. They give you crossbow and a section early on in the game where you have the option to do a somewhat stealth run, LITERALLY tells you to go stealthy, and then tears it away before you barely had a chance to pull the trigger when enemies start showing up with head gear and need two shots to drop. First shot hits, enemy shouts out before you get to lock another bolt in their skull, then you might as well get the shotgun out and go rush face.It's just... Dull.

content:
y 24, 2015
												I am slightly conflicted when recommending this game. People may enjoy different things out of a game than I do.As per usual with my reviews, I'll take my time to lay out why I recommend this game.I bares noting that I finished the game on the ultimate hardest difficulty, only available to owners of the Scorchers DLC.Rage has a combat system that I regard as fun. Especially in the beginning, assuming you went the hardest difficulty, the game quickly plays the resource game. I was challenged often to use my ammo sparingly, keeping my real good guns for emergencies.Money is on short supply as well, so it becomes a balancing act of fighting and earning money to cover your costs.The really strong weapons, like the shotgun (which remains a solid option throughout the game) will run out of ammo fast if you only use that. Sadly, this balance can be ruined by an exploit. It's a little convoluted, but workable. I tried it and felt I ruined the experience a little bit for myself, having large stocks of ammo now. There was no way I would waste 500 shotgun shells halfway through the story. If you feel honorable enough, you can avoid doing it.The combat itself is enjoyable. The guns feel like they have weight, and rightfully so. Hitting something with the full blast of a shotgun will annihalate a small enemy, and stun normal ones with a second killing them. Using a grenade to stun the really big enemies is a valid tactic to then unload shotgun ammo into them.But if you play on a hard difficulty, you'll not be running and gunning. In fact, much like the enemies, you'll be looking for cover often and peak out to exploit their unfortunate positioning, if any.And if you get shot? Well, the revive mechanic is there to save you, zapping you back to life if it has a charge.This is a good mechanic to balance the cheap lucky shots the enemies sometimes like to dole out.Storywise, the game is solid. It's not the best, but it tries to be comprehensible and cohesive. It feels like a potential that wasn't fully tapped into. This is noticeable in two things. One is the missions, where they objective is little more than progress through area's through, well, shooting and reaching the end. Then make your way back, often using a shortcut.But the worst part is, however, it's ending.Now, I would not skip on buying this game because of it. It's literally the last mission that is completely ♥♥♥♥. You break in a facility, spend a few hallways killing and pushing buttons and then tough out a minor gauntlet. No final boss, nothing to really write home to.Everything before that mission seems fine and as the same quality as the rest of the game. Which makes it even more mindboggling. I cannot fathom why something like this was ended in such a way.It begs the question if it wasn't rushed or something.The same devs made Wolfenstein: The New Order, and I can taste some of the influences. Taking cover, the guns feeling good... But while Wolfenstein was more like a hallway shooter, pushing you forward into levels constantly, Rage has a bit of an open world aspect. Not as vast as you'd hope, but big enough to rummage around and see the sights. However, mission handling and such always happen in cities and such. Even races.Races are moderately enjoyable, and are required to upgrade your vehicle. But all in all, they're not something that ultimately stands out as extremely enjoyable, but a good enough time waster if you feel like trying. The races vary from time trials, racing combat to hunting random checkpoints that appear on the map. The enemy AI, especially in high difficulties, can be a real challenge though. So if you want those achievements, maybe do those on a different difficulty.I found Rage a worthwhile experience. The combat and gameplay, which matters more to me, felt good. Most of the weapons fit archetypes that you should be familiar with, but most of their design fits the theme. Except the shotgun. Damn thing looks like a modern polished weapon in a world of rusty and dusted weapons. It doesn't look high tech either like the late game villain's weapons do. Odd one, that.The exploration and story could have been better, but the atmosphere is very well done. There's lots to do, a few things to gamble in a few games, and tasks to do. The people in the cities don't repeat their lines, and often have interesting things to say. Not to mention that they seem to be all named. As if they were placed by hand.If the positive aspects I've described call to you, then Rage may be a worthwhile experience for you as well. As a game of age, it'll now be more often on sale, so be sure to grab it at your convenience.And if you want a game where the combat also feels just as good, Wolfenstein: The New Order will be the next game I may heartily recommend.

												It's quite hard to review RAGEI wish steam had more options, it's not really "Yes", but it's definitely not "No" Graphics: it's not that bad, the sky is uhm... just a "wallpaper", a static texture, yeah, they worked hard... some textures are quite embarrassing and sadly it's glitchy too...  overall as I said, it's not pure trash, sometimes looks really nice. Music\Voice acting: nothing impressiveLocations: some locations are really nice, some locations are like "Ehy I feel too lazy today, I'll just copypaste some random corridors, that's ok ?"Story: what I said about laziness ?  I can imagine what happened in ID's offices:"Ok people, let's add those... uhm groups of people here because of reasons, then this guy will ask you to go there to pick that item because... he... needs it ?! Ok then we'll add a giant in this point, because you know, giants are cool, Well then we can... oh guys it's lunch time, gotta go !" "But we have to write the final and..." "Nevermind, the final is simple, the protagonist goes somewhere and kills everyone and he saves Rohan, that's all""Rohan ?" "Rohan, Megaton, Narnia, whatever, I'm late, Bye guys" Gameplay - shooting: it's nice, a bit repetitive but nice. Great potential not really used by ID, again laziness, tons of corridors to clean, just a few different "encounters", nice weapons feeling, different ammo for each weapon, a lot of extra items, nice IAGameplay - driving: Ok, it's not awful... it's bad compared to the "shooting gameplay" and tbh it's quite useless, maybe with a better implementation...Gameplay - in general: the dialogue system it's pretty bad, invisible walls (you can't jump a ♥♥♥♥♥ rock, really ?!), subtitles... ok let's pretend subtitles don't exist, side quests are pretty meh, some minigames are nice, but nothing extraordinary. Overall: tons of defect, sometimes it feels like devs were too tired to take it seriously.RAGE it's a Fallout\Borderlands wannabe, but it fails. The game is good enough to be finished.RAGE could have been a masterpiece, but ID decided to not invest... actions and consequences, RAGE is just ok.

number of helpful: 32 of 42 people (76%) found this review helpful
content:
2, 2015
												Rage is the perfect example of how a bad launch can irreversibly ruin a game. When the game was first released in 2011, the "mega textures" looked great - when it worked. Most of the time, it didn't. That ruined the game for me, and apparently many others as well. Fast forward to 2015. With all the problems patched, Rage runs perfectly. Plus, it looks gorgeous - even by today's standards. In fact, I'd dare say Rage is the best looking FPS game in my opinion (even though The Order: 1886 and Battlefield have more amazing tech, Rage has incredible artistic direction).Pros- Great selection of guns - Guns feel real, weighty and powerful- Incredibly interesting cast of characters- Interesting, varied and intelligent/believable enemies- Amazing graphics, even by 2015 standards- Great level design with varied levels- Fun distrations around town (i.e. the game's hub area), including a surprisingly addictive card game- Good range of difficulty levels- DLC that's actually worth the price! Cons- Given the intersting array of characters, the story really doesn't live up to its potential- WAY too few boss battles- NO RAGE 2!! (Ok this isn't really a con, but we need a Rage 2!)In summary, this is one of the finest FPS games ever made. There isn't an epic story to be told, but if you love to shoot stuff - this is as good as it gets. Old school gunplay (without any modern "gun carrying limit" BS) with new school gameplay variety and graphics. Rage is a steal even at full price. If you're a fan of FPS games (or even if you're not), this is one game that needs to be in your collection.

content:
2, 2016
												From the perspective of a storyteller and lore junkie, RAGE is cause enough to RAGE. It seems to get the recipe right: Post-apocalyptic setting, competent voice acting, guns that are fun to fire, enemies that are fun to dispatch, huge cars with huge guns, and good graphics and sound work. So where it goes wrong?The world is dull. It's about as derivative as post-apocalyptic settings can get and simply boring. None of the characters are particularly memorable (except for Dan Hagar and that's only because he's voiced by John Goodman, whom I adore) and the setting is... To say it's barebones is to be generous. There's very little world building and it offers no cohesion, nothing beneath the wallpaper of pretty graphics and animations. You'd think Apophis' impact would create an unique setting with special mechanics, but as it stands, RAGE could very well stand in for a particularly sunny day in Fallout or a mysterious new Zone of Exclusion in a game based on Roadside Picnic (yes, I could stay STALKER, but that's not a direct adaptation, now is it?).Perhaps the worst offender is the Authority. You are constantly being told how the Authority is bad and evil, but the game never actually shows it beyond a handful of comments about hunting Ark survivors (who usually join them) and their leader doing a Bad Thing by messing with the Ark timers. Oh, and they wear red, black, faux-runes, and their flag is a barely modified Reichskriegsflagge. So, Nazis AFTER APOCALYPSE, fought by a Generic White Military Dude. As derivative and boring as the story is, the gameplay is pretty solid. Scrounging up supplies and crafting stuff to fight enemies more effectively is fun, the alternative ammunition adds variety (well, when it isn't a simple damage multiplier), and the foes you fight offer for a varied experience (with the caveat that they tend to be bullet sponges by the end game). Still, there are far better alternatives on the market. Far Cry comes to mind, which does everything RAGE purports to do, except better.

content:
3, 2016
RAGE is such an amazing game, maybe not story wise but the gameplay, the world, the visuals, the women, it's all good.I enjoyed the game very much, as it is quite similar to games like Borderlands and Half Life when it comes to the plot.It is not the most original(est?) concept there is. You are a survivor from a worldwide apocalypse and you become to hero who saves the day. We've all seen it before. But the story never was the strong point of this game.It's the actual gameplay itself, combat is very satisfying and the game is visually VERY appealing. It also works flawlessly on toasters alike. RAGE isn't really open world either, well I mean, it does have open world aspects to it but I wouldn't consider it to be a true open world game like the other Bethesda titles such as the Elder Scrolls games and Fallout games.But i do like the fact that you are able to interact with almost every NPC there is and can do minigames that mostly consist of gambling. There is also racing and bounty hunting.Keeps the game interesting.. For some time that is. You see, the game itself is quite short.And to make you even more doubtful wether you should buy this game, the ending of this game (NO SPOILERS)is one of the worst I have ever seen. It's like they planned to release a sequel soon after, but never got around to doing so. That and the fact that the plot (story line) is confusing and hard to follow and often makes very little sense, are the only reasons not to buy this game in my opinion. But hey, it's always on sale and full priced at 9.99 USD currently. So i guess the length of the game is justified with the current price tag.There are also bunch of sidequests to do so that the game won't be done in under 10 hours.I would also recommend buying THE SCORCHERS DLCas it lets you continue the game after the original endingand gives you a new side story (quest) that will keep you busy for few hours. Also, as mentoned before, women in this game are extreme appealing to look at. And THE SCORCHERS adds another hottie to your collection.It's a fantastic game ruined by a ending that leaves you feel unsatisfied and gives no real closure, none-the-less i will still recommend it, considering how cheap the game is.

content:
r 12, 2011
												Mr. Rebounding Health, I want to ask you something.  Are you ashamed at all of how badly you ruin tension, pacing, excitement, difficulty, level design and strategy in video game experiences?  I would have enjoyed RAGE immensely more had you not wiped your feet on the experience.  Okay, sure, the story, characters and ending were bland, but as a game, it's pretty good, and it's a beautifully optimized 10 - 16 hour experience.  The enemies are quite smart and evasive, I got to hold 10 weapons at once with varying ammo types and the baddies responded to where they were hit and were ultimately satisfying to kill.  Hell, even the driving portion of the game was phenomenal, so much so I actually couldn't wait to travel and participate in races.  Then you came in and took away what could have been intense, exciting combat and instead, gave me tunnel vision with how easy and ultimately dull you made the shooting.  Now, thanks to you, I can only half-heartedly recommend RAGE.  Thanks a bunch.

r 9, 2014
												This review is split in 2.Vanilla Game....great game, although a little on the easy side, even with Ultra Nightmare.  The hardest part of the game were the last 2 DLC levels with the Scorchers.  All in all, very fun game, great graphics, solid performance, and amazing shooting mechanics, as expected from ID.  Minigames are worth spending the time to play, and even though money is abundant, the side quests are fun to accomplish.  Racing mechanics are well done IMO, and i do not use a controller.  8/10Game with Rebalance mod 2.0......Oh my, this is what the game should have been.  It may not be fair to do a review of a game WITH a mod, but considering IMO this is how the game should have been i will include it.  ReMod2.0 makes items more expensive, ammo less powerful, and the regenerating health is GONE.  Engineering items is now essential to survival.  This mod + Ultra Nightmare is tough as nails and i loved every moment of it....9.5/10

The world is believable and immersive.Highly recommended.

												Rage is fun to play, it's not a GOTY but it's a good FPS with some RPG elements: crafting, inventory. AI is really great, it's fun to see enemies and your robot(s) follow you, climb, hide, etc.You should totally play it, size can be problematic with slow or limited internet but it's a great experience ;) GraphicsThe graphics are good, but the texture caching is some time (most of time on dual monitor setup) a little ugly, if you see what I mean ... The Mega texture give good decors, but you can see that cars or rocks are paint on the texture (it's flat). Since it's Carmack, you can forget physics for objects: table, chair, some bottles are stick where they are.LengthThe game have a good length I've ~20 hours for the main story and side quest (the only things I haven't done are: little games (boring) and most of races). The last DLC add 2h30 of content, and you can still play after you've finish the main campaign. BTW it isn't a real open world, you can drive around, but you'll encounter many close doors and missions are in a close area each time: sewers, refineries, etc.SizeThe size on my hard drive is: 23814 Mo (with all the DLC: Authority pack, sewers and The Scorchers).

Roll credits.
