content:
20, 2014
												This game is problematic. It's great all-around, but some of the complaints about it are warranted. The design is brilliant, but the execution just isn't quite up to snuff. Blowing off mutant heads is better than ever, and id has really kept up with the times. The gameplay here is completely unique to id. Some of the more blatant errors have to do with the balance of the weapons later on in the game. The machine gun/ironsight/cover play looks like it should work, even into the Gearheads lair, however this is not the case and suddenly you must change your strategy. Up until enemies get armor however, you can effectively just melee through the game if your aim is good enough. I was able to complete normal without purchasing bandages or saving mid-level, first time through the game. More subtle some of the maps don't make cover and terrain visually clear. Obstacles sometimes only come up to your knees, and you can jump over other stuff that's up to your thighs, it's a real pain to have to learn this in the middle of a firefight. Combat is not a place where you want to fool around with a player's ability to flow. Please only player clip for good, not evil.But these problems are far and away the exception, and not the rule. id is the best, this game is really quite good, and visually stunning. The uniqueness of the game far outdoes the slight problems with it. 10/10 would buy againps: this is one of a few fpses released in the last 5 years where the campaign isn't simply a drawn-out multiplayer tutorial. buy now!

number of helpful: 43 of 66 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
r 10, 2011
												Addition to the review: I notice that a lot of people are saying my review isn't helpful, I am not saying this isn't a good game, in fact I quite enjoyed it when I played it on my 8800GTX, but the game has serious technical issues that hinder many people from playing the game and I have not found a fix that works. I can recommend the game itself because it is a lot of fun, just not on PC due to myself and everyone I know having SERIOUS issues with the game.RAGE... while it is a well done game, it is hindered by game breaking technical issues that they have not fixed and the game came out quite some time ago. If you read through the forums, you will find that a big problem with the game is the way that it caches textures with higher end graphics cards. This causes extreme pop ins for textures that really ruins how good this game looks and destroys your frame rate. This only seems to be an issue with higher end graphics cards. I have experienced this issue on the following cards: Nvidia 280GTX (and two of these in SLI), Nvidia 560 GTX, Nvidia 560 Ti, and the Nvidia 660 Ti. Normally I wouldn't bash on a game for an issue like this but for it to be such a massive and common issue really ruins this game and I can't say I would recommend it to anyone with a higher end rig because of this. Now if you have a lower end rig (ran this without any issues on a Nvidia 8800 GTX), you may be able to run this game without any problems but unfortunately there are no guarantees. I cannot recommend anyone buy this unless they are willing to roll the dice with this broken game. I really hope id Software can step it up after losing John Carmack and fix this engine. Go play it on consoles if you are dying to play it, you can probably get the Anarchy Edition at your local Walmart or EB Games for $20 or less on PS3 or 360.

number of helpful: 20 of 25 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 15, 2016
OverallWell, it is not a bad game. At least better than most of its era, but do not expect too much from it.It displays to you as a open word free roaming fps with car races, crafting, and a lot of collateral activities, more like mini-games.The game has indeed all of this features, but no one of them is deepened enought in durability e quality.They just put a bunch of different stuff together and developed them enought to make them look long and complex enought to persuade the casual player they are good and many, therefore this game is immense and cool!I bet every Hardcore player noticed that and reacted as I did.So, don't be surprised if you find reviews that describe this game as conceived to be a demo for their graphic engine more than a game itself, or to be an "introduction" to post-apocaliptic games for newbies.That was an overall, now let me talk about some details and the reason why i liked or disliked them.-----------------------------------------------------------------------GraphicsAgain, game for casual players therefore worths to spend half of the budget on it.It is really cool indeed, expecially textures of the rocks. The game is plenty of rocks and I really liked the way they look.FPS weaponsThat is actually the main element of the game. If you speed-run it you will spend 90% time shooting and ony 10% in racing and exploring. There is nothing particular here, you got the canonical set of weapons. Only thing is you can craft and find different kind of ammo for some of them. Three or four of them transforms your weapon in a different one. Well, actually this happens mainly with the shotgun, who can become a granade launcher or a laser rifle. Nice feaure, not deepened enought, like everything else.FPS fightsThe game is linear, but if there is something I liked it was the enemies AI. Most of them just run recklessly to you screaming and swinging their weapon, but they attemps to dodge your shoots, with jumps, flips, preventive dodges, almost of the times successfully! It gives you a reason to sharpen your reflexes and don't waste (too much) ammo.CraftingYou have less then twenty recipes in the hole game, including an handful that is an enhanced version of a previous project.Considering you have cod-like health recover, 2 charges of respawns that recharge in a minute or less, and lot of weapons, what makes you think crafting a wingstick (kind of a boomerang) or a bandage is of any need?Also some of them are not balanced. Let me tell you of the auto-turret which enemies will knock over istantly! You can place it and literally count up to three to find the turret on the ground, totally useless.INSTEAD there is the sentry-bot that is definety overpowered! It a spider-like robot with a machinegun that is hard to kill, hard to hit, can even melee attack, follows you like a pet, extremely powerful, efficient, and with perfect aim. You can drop it on the ground an almost make him finish part of levels for you! Oh, it costs as much as the turret.And lastly, the remote controlled explosive car! This is a fun one because enemies will see it immediately and one-shot kill it, no matter the distance. It is also has a short range explosion. 'Nuff said.ExplorationTotally useless. You actually have only a city and the arounds that includes entrances to fps levels, and race tracks. No reason to hang in there. Also, jumping (on feet) is useless: there are barriers everywhere and it is impossibile to try to be in places where you are not supposed to be. I literally counted that only ONE TIME I needed to jump to reach a place.CharactersThis is really a great point for this game! Every character is characterized, on its design, voice, way they talk, and they fight (if enemy). I really like of colourful this game is on this point of view, and even be surpriced of how much an npc can be detailed even if you meet only once.RacingVery simple but fun. Consider races more like kart-games-fashioned destruction derbys.MultiplayerWell, it's dead now, but i remember I played in 2013. It was focused on car races. They were fun, but the ease you unlock all the contents and the total lack of skill of players constantly pushed me to think devs already know it would be dead quickly. I even felt the lack of ambition in making something long-lasting.LongevityI beat the game in around 20 hours, consider it a completionist time. I am not surpriced if I'll hear of some speed-runner that beats the game in 4 hours or less. With my total time of 40 hours (including multiplayer) I think I long passed the expectations on longevity of developers.PlotI should say "spoilers ahead" but there is not much story to spoil. Plot is a disaster and you totally realize only when you beat the game.Story: Earth is destroyed by a meteorite (surpriced it was not a nuclear war). You were cryogenized and wake up in this post-apocalypse future. You are saved by a nice tought guy that only for coincidence was in that recondite place you were. There is the Authority who dictates the wolrd (even if it is not true). You join the resistance, then you literally just enter the Authority core base and press some buttons. No final boss fight. No horde of guards to stop you. Not even a red alert situation. Not even a out-field voice of the bad guy that curses you or a call from friends to tell you saved the world. Just that: buttons-cinematic-credits. You have done your job now GET THE HELL OUT OF HERE people have to work, ♥♥♥♥♥♥! That was my impression on ending. Also for 80% of the game you just do what you do because you can, no plot involvement.------------------------------------------------------------------------ConclusionsI bought it for 3,50€ while on sale in 2013. Today its full price is 10€ so it can easily be even cheaper.If you spend as much as I did and don't expect too much, you won't be disappointed.

number of helpful: 17 of 20 people (85%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 6
												I remember when Rage was a highly anticipated title. The follow up to Doom 3 that was years in the making. When Rage came out the reviews were pretty mediocre. At least for a shooter that took years of development by the guys that mastered the genre.  Nothing really appealed to me about Rage, I'm not the biggest fan of "open world" games and the post apocalyptic setting has been done to death. But on a whim I decided to install Rage and a couple hours I was still playing it. Needless to say it a huge surprise this was me.  The good? The game looks amazing (though less so with up close textures) and ran smooth as butter on my OK PC. The gunplay is awesome. Tons of weapons and each has a distinct and satisfying feel. There is tons of stuff to do. Take contracts, race for upgrades, minigames or build things to help you kill stuff. Rage has you covered. The bad? Yes, the abrupt ending is indeed terrible and screams for a sequel (which will probably never come). Apparently the game was designed with a controller in mind because selecting turrets, grenades etc is wonky and not explained to you how to do it (Hold the F1 key, mouse click what you want to use). The racing parts I thought were only OK. Overall though I had a ton of fun with Rage. The $9.99 MSRP is absolutely worth it. A sale makes it an even better value. And definitely get The Scorchers DLC. There you get an actual boss fight at the end which was really well done. Even with its imperfections, Rage gets an 8.5/10 from me.

number of helpful: 110 of 187 people (59%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
er 6, 2014
												You would think with such big names behind it as Bethesda, id Software, and Square Enix, this title would be well worth its playtime in cash; unfortunately this is not the case. While the game-play is about as fun as any other post apocalyptic sandbox and the art is certainly a drawing factor, it is simply not all that fun to play. It is surprising just how quickly I found myself getting annoyed at the "go fetch this" quests and overall clunky mechanics behind some of the tasks. The challenge is not apparent on any difficulty and areas that are marked by NPCs warning of the dangers that lie ahead are little more than small scripted events where you fight a dozen enemies one at a time.That is not to say this is a terribly made game though. It delivers a mad max kind of vibe that seems to be trying to pull off some off mix of Elder Scrolls: Oblivion mixed with Borderlands. Quests, while predictable and somewhat unchallenging, offered some form of story progression and content delivery. Side missions like the racing ones featured in this game offer an interesting and fun diversion from the redundant primary mission progression, but were short lived and quickly showed their redundant nature as well.All in all I really wanted to like this game. Everything I experienced within the world Rage presents left me wishing it was good, but like any polished junk, at the end of the day it is still junk. 4/10 Buy at your discretion.

number of helpful: 40 of 62 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
er 26, 2013
												Gameplay wise I really enjoyed RAGE. Its a nice mix of solid shooter mechanics with racing thrown in. It mixes up the experience and keeps the game feeling interesting throughout. The gunplay really shines here. Standard fair weapons with some uniques, but each with unique ammo types and functions that feel very satisfying to use. The explosive shotgun shell rounds for instance, or the electric bolts for the crossbow to name a few. Gadgets like the wingstick are fun as well. Combat is almost always in small corridors. Larger areas are mainly for travel or vehicle comat. Its not a bad thing but rarely will you ever do your fighting out in the wilds. The racing aspect feels pretty decent. Its got some fun challenges and upgrading your car is fun as well. It mixes the pacing up which I enjoyed. Graphics wise it has a uniuqe look. They use the mega texture technology to have no "repeating tiling textures" and for a more unique look. It does look very good, but it it lacks in other areas such as dynamic lighting, decent shadows, and high resolution textures. Still its got a very unique look compared to other games. Now the game is not perfect at all. The story and characters are very poor. The story barely exists at all. Some HUD features are obviously from the console and the game could make much better use of PC options. Standard PC features like mouse smoothing and FOV have to be changed via console or autoexec.cfg files. Really sad in this day we still get this crap from devs. Challenge is another problem. Im not an amazing gamer, but I played on hard and didnt have a hard time with anything except a couple encounters. Still in the end once you get your FOV and mouse set, and are playing the game its a great experience. Very fun simple good old fashion shooting with some racing to spice it up. Really recommend espicially now when its so cheap and is 5 bucks on sale every other month or so.

content:
r 17, 2016
												I finished RAGE two days ago, and I've spent the time since thinking about it. If you've read the other reviews of this title, you'll have seen the most common complaints:- no ending. The game just stops.- no character development- no explanations or justification for what you're doing- no real plot- no ability to resume playing the rest of the game once the main quest line is over- persistent graphics pop-ins- somewhat awkward save interface- very awkward weapon and inventory interfaceMy biggest complaint is that the game is clearly not finished. Playing the game in 2016 and most of the bugs are fixed, but this still leaves the gaping problems in the way the game works. To quote Shigeru Miyamoto, "a delayed game is eventually good, but a rushed game is forever bad". How I wish that John Carmack and friends had spent a little longer fleshing it out. Then, RAGE might feel like a more viable proposition. As it is, once the game has abruptly ended, you will feel cheated. Cheated that you spent time strategising when no strategy is needed. Cheated that you spent time economising when no economy is needed. Cheating that you spent time improving when no improvement is needed.Save your money, buy a different game.

er 28, 2013
												Rage has some interesting parts, but the package as a whole is a mess. The color of the world is dreary but every NPC you meet is somewhat cheery and treats you like their best friend. While I love racing games and did not expect realistic vehicle behavior, Rage's MarioCart-like take is off the wall arcade. The power ups add more chaos to the racing that's already silly in comparison to the shooting. Even the shooting isn't all that good. The AI is interesting in that it seems to react to the situation, yet it's still dumb and easy to defeat. Bad missions, bad driving, and a setting that isn't coherent and reminds me that there are other similar games with much better story and tone. There's probably a lot of games that have been and may be $5 on sale that I would take over Rage. The Rocket Rally races are just random nonsense where there's no consequence for dying and bares no relation to the rest of the game. I either end up playing whack-a-mole as enemies pop out from cover or just walk up to them with a shotgun when they are crouched. Mutants you just wait for them to run straight at you.

content:
er 30, 2016
RAGE: an enjoyable and visually pleasing, Mad Max inspired first person shooter with some Borderland style vehicular action thrown into the mix.The GoodGraphics are on point as is to be expected from Id. NPCs are nicely detailed and there are some awesome vistas but sadly some textures don't look as good from up close. Character animations are amazing.The gunplay feels sharp and controlled. Weapons are interesting and can use different types of ammo. RAGE has an open world feel to it, even though it's essentially a linear shooter. Different areas are connected through a central wasteland that you navigate with your vehicle. Id succeeds in making this game feel big.The BadOne of the downsides is the console influence. There are quite a lot of invisible walls. The health regen system is present to make fights more forgiving (even a resurrection system like Borderlands)  and the game menus are clunky to navigate with your mouse.The racing aspect feels a bit forced and unnecessary and the same can be said about the crafting system. On the other hand, they work fine and give some slight advantages to the player. (Fat Mammas!)There is not a lot of variation in the enemy and monster line up. This creates a certain repetition.

content:
, 2016
												-Description-Story:The asteroid called 99942 Apophis is on a collision course for Earth and it will hit the planet at August 23, 2029, destroying civilization as we know it. The only hope for humanity to survive this event is to burrow down to ground with these Arks and submerge when the Earth is habitable again.  You are one of those survivors who were selected to enter one of the Arks. You submerge from the ground in the year 2135, only to notice that all your fellow Ark colleagues to be dead from the Ark malfunction and that the Earth has become a savage place, filled with raiders, mutants and things that has a dendency to kill you.The main story is somewhat average. It starts very strongly and keeps you in its grasp, but the ending was a little disappointment and anti-climatic for me. Not only that, but the ending also had a huge cliffhanger.Gameplay:The game is somewhat similar to the Borderline series, mixed with some Fallout's apocalyptic atmosphere. You can scavenge the world for items, which you can then use to build different items, depending what recipes you've discovered.The game has main quest line which you can follow, but there are also several side quests, which offers you money that you can then spend at vendors for items and car parts.Pros:+ Apocalyptic world and locations+ Infranty and vehicle mechanics+ Vendor system+ Crafting system+ Interesting characters+ Strong story, but...Cons:- ...Anti-climatic and gliffhanger ending- Main story is kinda short- Lack of character progression- Stealth gameplay could have been better- Not as challenging as I would have hopedDo I recommend?Yes. It has it's shortcomings, but if you enjoy playing apocalytic games, you'll probably enjoy this one too.Verdict: 8 / 10 - Good game( 1 = do-not-bother game5 = average game10 = must own game)

content:
er 25, 2013
												I really, really wanted to love this game but instead I could only like it. Post apocalyptic shooting with vehicles and open world elements from the people that made Quake, sounds fantastic right? That's until you actually start playing. You're dropping into the world with the barest amount of exposition and rescued by John Goodman who within five minutes of meeting you, gives you a gun and asks you to wipe out a gang. Vehicles don't exist beyond mini-games and the odd moments where you need to traverse relatively short distances to mission "dungeons." You ultimately join the rag tag group known as "The Resistance" who fights against the tyrannical "Authority" (honestly guys, hire a writer and come up with better names) in the most cliched manner possible. The game does have it's standouts. The gunplay feels good, the animation is excellent and blowing up other cars is enjoyable. The characters are very well constructed and they make you want to just sit and talk with them but instead are used as one-shot interactions. John Goodman's character disappears after the first hour of the game. The game was unfortunately not everything I wanted it to be but it was still an enjoyable experience.Get it for $5 if you have a rainy weekend.

content:
er 21, 2013
												I feel this game is very under-rated and under-appreciated. My first contact with this game was thanks to my local Game store where I picked this up second hand for only £4 (xbox 360) early last year. Within the first 5 minutes of playing I was completely absorbed and I fell in love hard. I've since had to re-purchase the game via Steam for another nostalgic playthrough and I don't regret it one bit. The game is based in the future amongst a wasteland filled with survivors, mutants, monsters and patrol units, not to mention bandit cars. You play a character that has crashed down to the wasteland from an intelligent craft which pre-dates the war. The war that is, that turned the land into wasteland in the first place. With your andvanced Ark technology implants and a funky selection of arsenal, you play through to liberate the wasteland and help the survivors as best as you can. Shotgun, machine gun, cross bow, sniper rifle and grenade launcher are some of the weapons that the character can play with throughout the game. My personal favourite are 'boomsticks', a boomering shaped object with blades that can be thrown to cut through advancing enemy heads with the chance of the stick returning to you for another throw. The story line and game start of very well but honestly I found the middle and ending not to live up to the first half. It was good, it was full of action but I just felt there should have been more, a bigger climax. Still I think it is well worth a play for any fps game fans. Plus it also has bonus games inside such as car racing (and fighting) plus gambling games ie cards, dice, roulette. Also has optional side missions.

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
2016
OverviewsighOkay, this was a tough one to rate. I gave it a "yes", but hear me out first: It's good if you're expecting DOOM, with a tiny bit of open world that was injected in. If you're actually looking for a game based on it being open world, then this is not the game for you.This is DOOM. With the added freedom of a tiny bit of exploration (though there's not much to discover... at all) and some racing aspects, which was.... fine, let's say.My reasoningLet's just go through the cons first.* Graphics, although nice, were poorly executed (ie. pop-ins)* The "open world" isn't much of an open world. At all.* The characters had SO MUCH potential, but they all ended up kind of dull. Like some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 90's caricature, but without much personality.* Story wasn't very interesting, and didn't have much explained.* Without spoiling anything for you, the ending was... well.... it wasn't much of an ending. I was saving up all my best weapons, and then suddenly... the game's over. It did not feel like an ending. No boss fight. The final quest felt like just any other side quest.With that aside, I want to say that, with the exception of that last point, as well as the point about texture pop-ins, those flaws are okay and can be overlooked.. IF you treat the game like DOOM. I played it on nightmare difficulty, and I have to say it was just as fun as DOOM itself. It really was. It also came with a few mini-games which I thought were also terrific. The racing aspect of it is no Need For Speed, but it's still a nice addition, and was enjoyable.So to recap: if you're looking for something like Fallout, turn away now. If you're looking for something like DOOM, however, I highly recommend it.

content:
er 15, 2016
												This will get a positive mark for 2 reasons, which are probably only worth it if Rage is on sale.  One and one thing only made this game an absolute blast for me, too bad I didn't discover it until the end of the game after I'd already beaten the game and loaded a save before the last mission to complete all the side quests and Sewers DLC.That one thing is the Dynamite Bolts for the crossbow!  I'll explain at the end.  The game and the world looked pretty good.  The gameplay, guns and quessts were just interesting enough to keep playing, but ultimately I was disappointed.  When Rage first came out, I remember all the commercials and such that kept showing these big epic battles versus these huge nightmarish creatures, and these epic "fight for your life" vehicle battles.  But these mechanics either fell flat or were almost non-existant. Overall, the vehicle stuff was boring.  It's easy to max out your vehicle's equipment and armor via the "racing" mechanic and once you've done that you are pretty much unstoppable when driving around the wastes.  I resorted to ramming into enemy vehicles while holding the Boost button to make enemy cars explode, just to make it interesting.Worse, is the fact that all those adverts suggesting that the game was littered with epic fights against these huge monsters, was in fact only ONE epic fight against ONE monster at the end of ONE particular quest.  In fact, that quest was the ONLY really fun and cool quest in the entire game as you always find yourself constantly encountering said creature as it lumbers/rampages through the city.  You always seem on the verge of getting caught, noticed, or accidentally killed by its random actions until you finally encounter him at the end and are forced to fight.  The whole atmotsphere and feel of that entire level was absolutely fantastic.  If the developers has made the whole game feel like this quest, I think people would have loved this game.The Problem:  This one quest is maybe halfway into the game.  The final objective that ends the game is downright dull and boring by comparison.  Yes, as everyone says, the end doesn't even feel like the end and is completelyh anti-climatic.    If only the developers had made the end game as exciting as the Epic Monster Quest Battle I talked about in the previous paragraph.Dynamite Bolts!  The one thing that that made me not go "meh" over the game, maybe second thing if I include the 1 Epic Monster quest.  I had largely ignored the different bolt types for the crossbow other than the basic one for stealth sniping.  But as I was going through and just completing all the sidequests (don't know why I cared), I got bored using the same guns/ammo over and over.  So to change things up and make things a bit more interesting I swapped to the killing from medium range distance with the dynamite bolts.  This is wherre hilarity insued.  The bolts hit their target and then explode after a few seconds.  It was easy to use them on human npc's because they tend to use cover and shoot from a disance, unlike mutants who charge you causing you explsive damage.  Anyways, I found out that if you use the dynamic bolts, the npc's get scared when hit.  Once they get hit, they yell things like "Oh No!" or "Son of a B----!" or "Oh Sh--!"   Most of the time the npcs physically react to the bolt and start running around in a frenzy, or his buddies try to scramble away. Sometimes the individual body parts react to where he was hit.  So hitting a bandit in the arm could make him start flailing the arm wilding around, yelling "Oh Sh--!" then explode.  Some times the explosions lead to these "laugh out load' ragdoll glitches where the npc body would catapult across the map, or smack another npc, knocking him over to act woozy from damage, etc.  After I discovered this, I spent the rest of the night laughing uncontrollably as bad guy after bad guy experienced the horror of my Crossbow of Kaboom! The one Epic quest and Dynamite bolts made this game worth the $4.99 Steam Sale.

number of helpful: 21 of 32 people (66%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 18, 2014
												A game with a bipolar mix of great ideas and some pretty heavy misses. I'll start off with the good, get into the mixed, then get into the bad. Overall, though, I think it's a great game.So, the game starts off with a pretty epic cinematic of an asteroid hitting earth. You are one of the chosen few to be put into a life-sustaining pod of sorts to be released when it's safe to live again. How lucky! Everyone else in the pod died. Not lucky. In the meantime, civilization has adapted to a post-apocalyptic scenario by survivng in small pockets of the wasteland. Some people mutated, others formed gangs, and others complain about "the authority" being a general pain in the ♥♥♥. Really, they're called "the authority." This is the entire plot of the game.The gameplay is actually great! I had followed this game for about three years before its release, and I soaked up the tidbits that they released of their design philosophy. Carmack really admired Half Life 2's weapons, in that the sound they made gave you a real sense of how powerful they are. I think the weapons are one of the best parts of this game. The shotgun has bass, and it LOOKS beautiful. The crossbow looks like a technological marvel, and the sound portrays silent but deadly. Even the crappy starter pistol portrays "Yeah, this gun is crap but it'll get the job done for the first few stages." Also, all of the weapons are fun to use. There aren't many (they all fit neatly on the 0-9 keys), but they're well done.My favorite part of the inventory is a wingstick. It's a bladed tri-tipped boomerang with a target acquisition microchip. You sling it out (like a boomerang) and it'll do its best to locate and subtly track an enemy near your crosshairs when you threw it. Sometimes it'll bounce off walls and still manage to behead an enemy. Sometimes it'll break on the enemy and knock the wind out of them. Sometimes it cuts their head clean off and returns to you, ready to be thrown again. It's the best secondary weapon I've ever used in a video game, in both functionality and fun.Additionally, they spent a lot of time creating a wide range of possible movements for enemies. This means that enemies are, by and large, unpredictable. The same kind of mutant will stagger and roll in one way, while another will duck, jump, roll, and then try to hit me with a stick. Also, they die in different animations. It's not as dramatic as id said ("you won't see the same animation twice" was really overshooting it) but it's nice detail.Also, the car aspect of the game deserves a lot of praise. It's post-apocalypse, so of course everyone attached rocket launchers to their cars. You get homing rockets, and can explode bandits' cars - and the explosions are beautiful. The cars also handle really well with a controller. To be honest, this game's car sequences could have been an amazing game on their own. You have a regenerating speed boost, you have kneecapper tires, upgradable car armor, multiple cars to pick from, car races (time trial, normal race, rocket combat race, and a neat kind of "point" race). The game left me wanting more of the car content.Now, for the mixed...It's clear the devs didn't really know what they wanted this game to be. It's a fun FPS with a really fun driving experience, but the racing aspect kind of gets dropped after an hour of gameplay (at which point driving just gets you to the next FPS objective). Also, it wants to take itself really seriously as a shooter. Stealth? Aww yeah, wingsticks and the crossbow are silent, go ahead and have fun - the game actually explicitly encourages it. Except there have been multiple occasions where I've been sneaking and enemies know the split second an ally silently dies across the room, or enemies in one area KNOW where I am and where I will be coming from even though I'm crouching silently. This is paint-by-the-numbers stealth. You'll stealth where the game wants you to stealth, and even that is kind of half-baked. The crossbow is fun but just not viable unless it's the first enemy in an area, which is a shame.Next, the areas are VIVIDLY beautiful. They've put so much effort into making detailed canyon lighting, ambient graffiti and statues, and just general neat touches that make everything come alive. But everything looks good from a distance. When you get up close, you'll notice the textures have this weird black dot patterning (examples are in my public RAGE screenshots). I'm running a "great" (RAGE-rated) Nvidia GPU with the latest drivers. I think it's just an afteraffect of id's grand idea of "megatextures" which seems to have been ahead of its time. That's another topic, and I won't get into it - this paragraph pretty much sums up its relevance. There's also massive texture pop-in if you use mouselook, and that's never been resolved. Oh well.Last, but not least, the bad parts of the game...Areas are shockingly linear. You will see slabs of rock that are reasonably sized for jumping. You will see paths in levels that you could reasonably assume you could go down.  Maybe there are a few doors you could force open, or something you could climb if you actually tried. No. The game has ONE path that you will always take, and it's frustrating. The game is about exploration in story, but it's really not in actual gameplay. This is made worse by the fact that they hide collectibles - cute nods to past id games, collectible cards to boost your ego, and crystals meant to be sold for money - off the beaten path. Actually, not so much "off the beaten path" but "on the one path you're allowed, to the side where you have no reason to look." Again, it's "exploration by the numbers." You'll explore the way they want you to. Even in a town, you can't save time by jumping around. You need to walk down the stairs, down that one corridor, down the other stairs - it's like I'm playing a responsible citizen simulator. Let me jump 10 feet over those stairs. Let me jump this 2 ft high wall along the corridor. I need to waste so much time wandering around a town with no guidance, the least you could let me do is save some time.Next, the game will just NOT work on an AMD GPU. On release it worked with terrible performance, and within a few patches (and despite tweaking it as much as I could) the game would NOT run on a mid-level AMD GPU. The game relies on CUDA cores. If you're not playing with an Nvidia GPU, you're going to have a hard time. They never fixed that.Also, the game was sold with the promise of day-one mod support, which was an outright lie. Mod tools were not made public available for (iirc) three years after the game's launch. If there was day-one support, as promised and advertised, the community could have done some wonderful things here. As it stands, it seems that most people have just moved on from this game, and that's honestly a shame. Based on the footage they released, the mod tools looked great.The last gripe I have with this game is the multiplayer. Let's see. id software...kings of the FPS genre. A FPS game. That means the multiplayer is going to obviously be...half-baked vehicle combat!! Wait, what? There's no kind of TDM or even just campaign co-op (although I think this is undoubtedly best done as a single-player experience). Instead, the game has vehicle combat in circular maps, which is really an odd direction for it to have taken. I know that I praised vehicle gameplay, but this doesn't relate to any kind of racing. It's literally car deathmatch free-for-all, which is enjoyable up to a point, but really just ill-fitting as the only multiplayer offering. There's also co-op in a number of sort of vignettes of game areas stripped of context and filled with tough enemies. That's cool, I guess. There was never really any driving force to try that other than achievements (and even at that, I just gave up on it). The game's multiplayer has been dead since three months after the game's release, so...

												Now, i just want to start out by saying, the PC port in this game is awful, if you have a console, you should get it there, but if texture rippling doesn't bother you, than let's get started.Rage is a very great breath of fresh air for FPS games, It blends in nice open levels inside the overall world design of the game. You can have up to 4 weapons equipped at times, and they all feel powerful and immensely satisfying, They have complex recoil movements and different weapons are used for different situation. It's FPS aspect is fun, frantic, and intense, though you will be finding yourself covering behind objects a bit too frequently.The Graphics are very well done, the objects and everything looks good in the game, but you may need some help from mods to get rid of the texture rippling.The story is the weakest point of this game, as you play the game, it is backed up by either way too generic characters, or promising ones that you barely get any dialogue from. Even though the world is somewhat decent in size and filled with crowds. It felt rushed and unfinished, and put together at the last second.But, the game is good overall, i never usually put scores on games, but since this review is a bit crazy, i would give it a 7.75/10

content:
5, 2016
												Despite being a game I can recommend, this is a really interesting, nuanced title. A retro offering in more ways than one, it is crucially retro in the way that it is simply not a perfect, uber-polished shooter, and that this becomes a virtue as it delivers a title that stands out from the crowd, has a point of difference and, if one is prepared to compromise somewhat, a real charm.So what do I mean by RAGE being a retro, unpolished title? Well, let's look back to the first half of the 00s. This was a time when, before a relateively select span of companies (EA, Bethesda, etc) begun to dominate the industry, there existed a teir of titles that is somewhat less evident these days. A sort of B-teir, these games were identifyable by their newbie or unknown developers, somewhat strange production objectives, relatively unoptimised or scratchy graphics, etc.Take a look at Operation Flashpoint. Produced by Eastern europeans, the game was by no means a beautiful, watertight package. Don't get me wrong, as I said in my OpFlash 2 review the original Flashpoint was the best title in the whole of the ARMA and Flashpoint series combined, but this game was not perfectly made! Cutscenes and set pieces were all built within the simplistic mission editor engine, the English language script was iffy, models were boxy and only vaguely humanoid, textures were cloudy and the foliage was all just a collection of two-dimensional sprites arrayed rotationally around a Z-axis. Everything looked vaguely amateur, especially when held up against a game like Halo: Comabt Evolved, but as I've been hinting at thus far this was by no means an indictment of the gameplay experience: Operation Flashpoint was an era-defining, industry-leading title in it's own, specialised ways.And while RAGE does take on the look of a AAA title, at least in screenshots, it is in actually a half-baked, simplistic, technologically incomplete offering. It is an experiment for the IDTech 5 engine which, while a success in certain targetted areas, is by no means a holistic gaming experience.So why am I recommending it? Because it is a really fun, lightweight, occasionally stunning and even thrilling title.First of all a word on the graphics. This engine is obviously an intellectual triumph. Famous ID mastermind John Carmack came up with some magic method that allowed game artists to basically do whatever they wanted with a setting at no cost to performance, and the result of these innovations in RAGE is that it is a bloody georgeous game - at least when viewed in stills. Landscapes simply cannot be faulted, nor can the really intelligent way that lighting has been handled: this game can be really breathtaking.The environments, the lighting, even the movements of the characters are all really well done - but it isn't perfect. Character models move in a really expressive way, but the way they distort to accomodate this movement is somehow unrealistic and spoils immersion. Likewise the pace with which you move through environments, and the relatively low attention you are asked to pay to them (it plays like a rail shooter more often than not), prevents you from truly appreciating them and feeling as if you are part of an environment. In sum, and this is a point that highlights the quirkiness of this title: The game looks great, until you're playing it, then the visuals become forgettable until you stumble upon the occasional well-made set view.The gameplay is also pretty simplistic. Intended clearly to be a vehicle-heavy game, there are races and Mad Max-style road battles featuring limited vehicle physics and auto-aim guns. The shooting play is solid - greatly boosted by the elusive movements of your impish enemies which make aiming a really active experience - but repetetive. Missions are short and not too difficult (though occasionally you come up against big bad enemies who can be a real exclamation point) and in general there is a really light touch on the gameplay on the part of the creators (you would have expected more from Bethesda), something which isn't called for, since the gameplay is so clearly lacking something.So, I'll have to meld this hodge-podge review into a coherent final statement: This is a great, lightweight game. Get it when it's on sale. Get it for your weaker laptop to play on international flights. Get it for the fun gameplay, get it for the occasionally stupendous visuals, get it for the very low drain the game will exert on your mental resources. Don't get it if your machine can play Witcher 3, or somesuch, and can afford those games too.7/10

												Surprisingly brief. It is a great shooter/racer with alot of little mini games you can have fun with from the battle card game you can play to the hand knife roulette type game all the way to the simple guitar memory game. I found crafting and the battle areas also to be quite fun. Ok now for the down side, The game was buggy as hell when I first picked it up but it got less buggy after some graphics card driver updates. I never once met the mysterious general running the bad guys, The last battle was also more of a gauntlet with no actual boss fight to speak of. Kinda left me surprised and disappointed. It actually felt like the game lost funding and so they just ended it with a happy ending cut scene. Do I recommend it? Yes but know what you are getting into and try to get it on sell. Right now it is 4.99 on the summer steam sale and that is a good price for it. Enjoy it while you can and make it drag out as much as you can but it will end. If you want a better game, get Borderlands (any of them), won;t be as visually impressive but will be more fun and complete and less buggy.

												Despite the hugely anti-climatic ending that WILL leave you disappointed, Rage is a very under appreciated game, that got a lot of hate due to its crappy PC port on release. Most of the problems it had were fixed, but it still feels like a console game. And playing on PC, that is unacceptable.  If you're able to get past the graphical issues, Rage is a very well made game. Think of Borderlands but without the RPG stuff: that is Rage. At first it may seem like an average game, but as you play it you'll discover that it's a lot of fun and it has a strange charm that will hook you up before you know it. I can't tell where that charm comes from, because thinking back, it's not better than similar games like the mentioned Borderlands, but it's still fun, which is what matters when playing a game.  Sure, it's rough around the edges, not for perfectionists, but if you play a game to enjoy it, trust me, you will like this game. Also, if you have the chance, get the Scorchers DLC, it makes the game better and adds content to the endgame, which the original was missing.

												Having played 690 plus hours of this game (so far) confirms my total commitment to another brilliant production from the id people.  The fact that you can enjoy not only different difficulty levels but also vary your playing direction every time you start a new game is a bonus. Yes, you must follow the given format to complete tasks and levels but they also can be varied in actual excecution (You don't have to do what you are asked or told to do in the order given). There is quite a deal of information there that will assist with gameplay and the acquisition of money required to purchase upgrades.In short 'Rage' is a great game that can be left alone for a while and comfortably returned to at a later date and played again and again. Great graphics, good story line and flexible playability. Extra DLC's would be great to expand this game as it lends itself to more missions.First time through took some 30 - 40 Hrs and this will vary depending on how much or how little you feel you want to do. The game is extremely flexible and I would rate it 9/10.I have uploaded many screenshots that will giva an indication of what to expect.Have fun.

content:
y 31
IntroductionRage is smi-open world FPS game. The main reasons to get this game is the gunplay, level design,ai and enemy animations.GameplayThe gunplay in the game is really good because if you shoot an enemy leg he will start to crawl to behind cover while at the same time try to shoot you, if an enemy charges you and you shoot him in one side of their body they will spin and at the same time go foward due to their momentum and headshots are truly satisfying where the enemies heads just explode in a really statisfying way.You play as an ark soldier that has regenerating health and has an emergency defibrilator that creates an emp blast that stuns nearby enemies so it basically gives you a second chance but it has a fairly long cooldown. A good portion of the game you spent going into bandit's hideouts and kill them and sometimes collect some quest related items and in that department the game has a fairly large enemy variety. The second kind of enemies you fight are the mutants where the small common ones usually charging at you in wide angle so that way it is harder to shoot them instead of just going at you in a straight line, and then there is the large mutants that are kinda like mini bosses that are quite tough and deal a good amount of damage. And finally the last kind enemies that you face are high tech soldiers with plasma guns and shields.Besides that you also have races that give you tickets to improve your cars and change their appearance based on the upgrades that you get and also have a few diferent paintings to choose from.And finally you have a decent variety of minigames that fit the game theme and one of them is a card game where you play with the cards that you collect throughout the levels, so in that way the game collectables are actually used for something and if you miss one that is in an area that you cant acess anymore the game shops will sell you that card for 1k dollars which is quite alot but the minigames can give you a decent amount of money so it isnt so bad if you miss one or 2.StoryThe story is alright but it is good enough to fit the overall gameplay theme. The ending some people dont like it but in my opinion it kinda fits because the whole game you are just a lone wolf that deals with stuff that people ask you to do in exchange for armor, weapons, money and recipes that will help you make cool stuff. However if after the ending the game continued it would be just an all out war between 2 factions which would be pretty much a completely different game so in my opinion it ends where it is suposed to.ConclusionRage is a pretty good FPS that i strongly recomend to play at ultra nightmare dificulty which is the highest if you just want  to have a truly great FPS experience however the only issue that I have with that dificulty is that the time trials are bit bs because they literally ask you to make perfect run in the first and last time trials but out side of that it is a quite enjoyable experience.

content:
3, 2015
Solid FPS with some nice Open-world and RPG elements.Don't expect too much from the story. Even though the whole post-apocalyptic universe this game is set in seems very authentic and well done, there could've been done so much more in order to make the story more compelling. There are a great amount of interesting characters, both enemies and allies, which add to the atmosphere.The gunplay overall is not on the level of Killing Floor 2 for example but above average nontheless. The guns handle well, the sounds are realistic and shooting feels satisfying. Different types of ammunition help spice things up especially later on in the game.Throughout the game, RAGE wants you to believe it's an open world shooter. Between quests, it does a relatively good job at it. During missions, however, there are a LOT of invisible walls which can get annoying at times. Most missions consist of going into a cave/dungeon/city/building and pick something up/deliver something etc. and then go back to the quest giver. The levels are generally linear but well designed. You don't have to run back the way you came which prevents the player from losing attention quickly. There are not a lot of areas that I felt like I want to get out of immediately.If you're planning on playing RAGE on hard difficulty, I wouldn't bother. All they did was turn the enemies into bullet sponges. It doesn't necessarily make the game harder, but you just end up wasting a lot more ammo and it just doesn't feel right to see a bandit without any heavy armor take a couple dozen bullets before eventually dying.Overall, I didn't feel like quitting the game at any point, the game kept me interested enough to play it for about 13 hours. If you're into games like Fallout or the Metro series this might just be something you should consider picking up.

												Borderlands meets Fallout without the charm of either.  I've been playing this for a few days now and I have to say it is interesting but a bit inconsistent.  The save from death system is a bit of a pain, and doesn't always work.  You get a chance to save yourself after being blow up by a rocket, but not falling from a not-so great height.  The lack of an auto-save is infuriating, or should I say, again, inconsistent.  There are checkpoints, not that it'll ever inform you that you've hit a checkpoint, and when you transition through a load screen you get an autosave but the missions are so long it's basically a useless auto-save.  The game is still worth playing if you can snag it on sale like I did, but in the current world of constant auto-saves just get used to having to save your game manually every 5-10 minutes or face the 90's world of starting over two hours ago.

												A post-apocalyptic setting, you know I love it. The plot is simplistic but "effective". There's nothing here that you haven't seen before but what is there is done well. For some reason or another this lone mutant always spawns and never attacks me. He just comes out (hope he washed his hands) and slowly patrols the hallway. It throws me off everytime. Do I have to kill him? Should I? He's not threatening to me, not right now at least. Even if I block his path he doesn't attack, he just stops and looks at me until I step aside. This mindless shoot-em-up made me think about the morality of killing virtual creatures.

content:
ber 26, 2014
												Perhaps it's a bit late to write a review, considering the game came out in 2011, but I decided to do it because of constant negativity surrounding the title. Let's take some common misconceptions out of the way from the get go: Rage is NOT an RPG game and it's NOT an "open world" game. Its design is mostly reminiscent of games such as "Quake II" or "HeXen", which used hub levels. In Rage, the wasteland is the hub level. Long story short - the game is an FPS full of action, as expected from id Software.What I really liked about the title is that despite features taken from modern shooters (iron sights, regenerating health) they don't really define the gameplay. You can switch off regeneration via the game console and iron sights aren't really needed - I beat the whole game using solely HUD cross hairs. If you REALLY want a challenge, I highly recommend id.dav81's fantastic "Rebalance Mod", it's hard though, you've been warned.The gunplay is excellent - weapons "feel" just right and enemies react to being shot accordingly to the wound's location. The graphics and music are also on a very high level - the atmosphere of post-apocalyptic wasteland and its danger is palpable.There is plenty of additional side-quests and mini-games to try, but their number is well balanced not to divert the player's attention from the game's focus - action. They help in building the atmosphere and immersing the player, that's all.The only downside is the ending of the game. It feels rushed and not thorougly thought through. However, at the time of this writing (September 2014) Rage is still the best single-player FPS game I have ever played. Great graphics, balance and, most importantly, gameplay. The ending didn't change my opinion, because in this game's case the journey truly is a reward in itself.I wholeheartedly recommend it to all fans of FPS games.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
y 14, 2014
												This game was...underwhelming, especially after hearing people compare it to Fallout. It feels like started out like a great game, but the developers got bored with it.  Rage plays alot like borderlands, but without the fun of co-op, building a skill tree through level progression, or finding better/interesting weapons.  -The vehicle combat in the game is pretty stagnant and just ends up feeling like a chore when driving from place to place.  +There's some content to explore outside the main story; a handful of sidequests/jobs and mini-games that might keep you busy for a little while, but have no real impact on the game.+The combat can be chaotic fun, the game offers a variety of ways to kill baddies.  There are a handful of interesting boss fights.  Some environments can be used to your advantage to surprise enemies with fire, electricity, spinning blades, etc.  There's no way that's really significantly better than the others at dispatching enemies, however it can be fun to use these things in combination.  My personal favorite toy in the game was the sentry bot.  The only disappointing part to combat was that it was too easy.  I played through the game on normal and NEVER used a healing item because your health regenerates quite quickly.  And if you do die, your character has a built in defibrillator that will instantly revive you (as well as killing surrounding enemies).  So I would highly recommend playing on a harder difficulty setting.-If you're looking for a good story, this is NOT the game for you.  Where the environments are interesting and varied; the story is very vague and un-engaging; it merely exists as a medium so the game can pit you against seemingly endless waves of enemies.  The ending of the game is by far the most disappointing aspect of the game. (Minor SPOILER ALERT:  there is no final boss, just a few waves of easy enemies.)  The game ends just as the story is getting started.  You have no real choices or impacts upon the world.  Your experience through the game will be the exact same as everyone else, which is why I'm not recommending the game.  I paid $5 for this game on a sale, and I wouldn't advise you to spend a penny more than that on it.

content:
r 7, 2016
												Often described as "Borderlands meets Fallout", RAGE comes to us from the godfathers of the FPS: id. Due to a number of technical issues at launch, this game never got the credit I felt it deserved - the fundamentals are done really well, but there are some shortcomings as well: Guns sound and feel really solid - as you would expect from an FPS master like id. AI is decent as well - maybe a bit predictable, but their movement is fluid and natural. A well fleshed-out world, containing mini-games, crafting, a wide variety of locales, and more.BUT The ending is obviously a setup for a sequel - seems like this will never happen, thus it feels unsatisfying. The decision to make multiplayer racing only is strange from a company of id's calibre. Even today, optimisation is poor - I still get drops on a GTX 970.If you have issues, I recommend trying the below guide (all credit goes to OP):


RAGE Graphics Fix & High Res Textures 
A Guide for RAGE
By: Laetteralus

			For those of you who own RAGE or bought it recently due to a Steam Sale you may have noticed that the texture pop-ins can be unbearable. Almost to the point of not wanting to play it's annoying.		


Highly recommended to FPS fans.

content:
16, 2016
												This game is like the kid who got straight 'A's in school, knew all the answers to every test, then went to university, smoked too much pot and dropped out in the second term. In other words, it's a disappointing under-achiever. It looks very pretty (even though it's getting on a bit), and it provides the illusion of some sort of open world, but that's all it is. An illusion. You're ultimately just shuffling from room to room and looking at what's going on. Of course, "it's a corridor shooter by ID! That's the point!" You might say, but it's even disappointing in that regard. You have too much health, there's too much ammo, the enemies are too stupid and there is basically no way to actually lose the game. I think I fell over about 3 times in total. And I mean "fell over" - I never actually died because you get a 2nd and 3rd chance through a "defibrillator unit" which wipes out enemies and revives you if you can manage to mash the E button at the sound prompt. And when I did fall over, it was because I couldn't be bothered using cover when I should have been. On top of the fact that you self-revive for no penalty, you get an endless supply of bandages that you can stuff down your throat to instantly restore your health. I used about 5 of those in the entire game, because it was just so easy. Of course, I was playing on normal, and I *could* have upped the difficulty (and I did for a while), but disappointment on top of disappointment, the higher difficultly levels just give the enemies more HP. This doesn't actually make the game difficult, it just makes every fight take longer and become not just easy but actively boring.I think the actual worst part, and what left me with a sour enough taste in my mouth to leave a review, was the storyline and the ending. The game is hurtling along, introducting all sorts of characters, many of whom are absolutely brilliantly realised and fantastically animated, and then it just stops. Suddenly you're on the end mission, you're handed a minigun and told to go activate a satillite uplink in the enemy base. You do so, get a 15 second cut scene and that's the end. There's no boss fight, no challenge (because you just mow everything down with afore mentioned minigun) and you don't even meet the big bad leader of the Authority (the badguys). Seriously, you hear his voice, once, and that's it. You never even see him. There's absolutely no sense of closure, no sense that you've finished up the story, nothing. It just stops dead and gives you the credits.I suppose I could also mention the races and vehicle combat. The races are ok. They're fun for about 30 minutes, but again way, way too easy and end up just a chore. This is compounded by the fact that the loading times are atrocious, so you spend almost as long waiting for the race to load as you do racing. Great. The vehicle combat exists. It's... there. That's about all you can say about it. If you want a corridor shooter, go play Wolfenstein: New World Order. It's slightly longer, has almost the same story line, but is way more entertaining, occassionally actually difficult and has Nazis to murder. What more could you want?If you've run out of everything else to play, and want to waste 7-10 hours clicking on bad guys, there are worse ways to spend your time than RAGE, but that's not exactly a recommendation, is it?

												This game left me feeling conflicted in a bad way. So much promise, a neat post-apocalyptic setting, but there were too just way to darn many "buts":"The graphics are gorgeous, BUT despite fantastic hardware I had to manually tweak config files to get it to work decently""The gameplay was smooth, BUT for those times when it would freeze up every two seconds inexplicably""The NPCs are interesting, BUT no one cares  or says a thing when you return to base from beating the game. Most of your team isn't even anywhere to be found.""The combat mechanics are cool at first, BUT then you get to fight the same three kinds of minions a thousand more times.""You get all kinds of cool guns and keep waiting for the big bad guy that you're going to need them for, BUT the big bad guy never shows up, you saved all your cool weapons for nothing.""That boss fight in the middle of the game is awesome, BUT  it's the only one. ""Your reasons for helping people start off as a means to survival, BUT later on you are just treated like a lacky and sent on 'get-me-a-beer' and 'make-me-a-sandwich' missions.""The gearhead boss will taunt you and you can't wait to kick his ♥♥♥, BUT he's just a dude in red armor who dies like a flop.""They build up a subplot of the mutants being curable , BUT  the doctor inexplicably disappears before the end and  the subplot is left completedly unresolved.""You defeat the bad guy base at the end, BUT never get to face 'the-bad-guy', just a bunch of faceless minions.""You defeat the bad guy base at the end, BUT those ***holes are still camping out in your town when you get back and still flipping you dirt.""The environment is complex and interesting, with huge vertical maps, BUT you can't fall to your death because of invisible walls.""Your character can jump like a pro basketball player, BUT still can't jump onto a shoebox or other small rocks and stuff.""You can build stuff from components, BUT aside from door lock breakers, you will probably never need to."Can I recommend it? It was fun, to the middle, but such a let down at the end. I don't want my friends to be let down, so sadly this game gets  a NOPE. A Bethesda + ID game should never have so many unsatisfying "buts" in it. 4/10

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 24, 2014
												id Software has written several pages of videogame history, creating the archetypal '90s shooter with Doom and bringing the third dimension to gaming with Quake. John Carmack and John Romero have created such legacy for themselves that their promises and opinions are to be taken seriously today, even after all the years that have passed since they went their separate ways. So when John Carmack lets it be known that he is about to deliver a shot heard round the world it is quite understandably taken as an accurate description of future events.RAGE is known to most gamers rather from the circumstances surrounding it than the actual game itself. To call the pre-release buzz a hype is a true understatement. Many believed the hype only to be disillusioned on release, with "is this it?" being the collective response. And as history has shown, the reaction was justified since RAGE came and went without impacting much of anything, let alone becoming legend. Now that the circumstances have changed a quiet appreciation has grown around the game as it it taken for what it is and not what it's creators meant it to be.The world has ended and the player character awakens to a wasteland, as is custom, and meets the people and the factions that have survived or emerged in the meanwhile. Unfortunately there is no imagination or surprise involved in any of this. There are The Raiders, The Authority (!) and The Resistance as well as The Mutants and finally the common folk. Everything is so generic and lifeless that the names in capital letters are also the only description required. Even more unsettling is listening to the NPCs talk. An abstract, Lydia-like cheer has descended on the survivors and not a single line of dialogue sounds like actual speech. A vendor says "All my stuff is A-one premo" in an attempt to simulate humanity with literally everything else being poorly disguised information about the game mechanics involved. Fortunately the protagonist is just as wordless as Gordon Freeman or the Doom Marine before him so there are no attempts at drama. The main story is so straightforward I am hesitant to call it a story and all the characters are merely their occupations. There are no themes introduced or points made. And although many many women dress extremely impractically to say the least there is absolutely no romance or sex anywhere, not even married couples among the NPCs. All the writing involved in RAGE is words, nothing more, and my mood always soured when I had to stop playing the game and listen to the people in it.What makes the world of RAGE even more unwelcoming are the excruciatingly slow and dull opening hours. There are so few places to go, weapons and tools to use and things to do that it takes some self-discipline to soldier on. This is undoubtedly where the synthetic if not downright artificial nature of the world shows its very worst. Fortunately the first day of gaming is misleading: as the world in which you can wander in gets bigger the game gets better as well. The farther away I proceeded from settled areas the more I enjoyed myself. The levels are highly linear but well-designed and even the typical ruins and bunkers are interesting to explore. I was most impressed by the ruins of a great city that felt like nothing had been spoken in them for decades. Exploring these streets was the equal of any other post-human gaming experience and conveyed more meaning than any amount of words could have done.While all the characters are just happy automatons they were at the least well-made automatons and much thought has clearly gone into them, despite well-known influences showing here and there. The animations were exemplary in many cases, especially those of the melee chargers found on many levels. Mutants charge forward in berserk parkour and should they get decapitated they keep running for a few more paces until realising that they have died not a moment before. The gameplay in RAGE is the traditional first person shooting seen many times before and since. It is made enjoyable by the large variety of weapons and quick-use items as well as the enemy behaviour. Only those equipped for close combat will charge forward, while those with firearms shoot from behind cover and finally retreat and regroup at the next defensive position with fresh troops coming in as well. Enemies will also get visibly injured and hobble around in pain or shoot from a sitting or lying position in their last moments. Doing this to the bad guys requires of course appropriate tools and RAGE delivers. There is a large arsenal and while it mostly consists of time-tested pistols, assault rifles and shotguns they universally look, sound and feel good in use. The basic ammunition types are nothing compared to the specialist ones you need to craft or buy at a high price. My personal favorite was the crossbow with four different types of bolts. One of these variants was a mind control crossbow bolt which lets an enemy to be walked to his comrades in remote control to be then exploded by a button press. This is one of the best But Of Course weapons in recent memory and there is undeniable glee in using it. The craftable quick-use items are even better and I was able to use most of them at a constant rate which is to say I appreciated the system very much. The first one accessed is the Wingstick, a throwable weapon looking something like a cross between ceiling fan and huge shuriken. It has limited guidance in flight and will return to the source to be used again later. Decapitating a charging mutant with one and retrieving the implement gave me a self-esteem boost against my better judgement.Controls felt natural and all the menu systems were ideally clear and informative. It is most unfortunate how blurred things can look on close inspection, especially the clutter items. RAGE looks great in motion, however, and my game was a stable one as well. There is a command console and mod support for the technologically skilled. I used a keybind to hide my HUD and weapon to take screens as my only modification. A full third of my 300+ screens are from my RAGE playthrough which is certainly a testament to my gaming experience as a statistic alone.RAGE has one major DLC, The Scorchers, which merits a separate mention. It plays to the strenghts of the base game, with spectacular level design and highly intense gunfights. The story is kept to the bare minimum, thankfully, and the missions are well integrated on the main campaign. The weapon added is also one of the very best available, useful but well-balanced and with three distinct forms. The titular Scorchers also feature some of the most amusing battle chatter available and must be quoted here. Melee berserkers tell you that they love you during their charge and shooters remind themselves of their "Happy place!" when wounded. Should a comrade fall the survivors exclaim in sorrow "We lost what's-his-name!" and remark how the player needs more therapy. All in all The Scorchers is a highly polished addition to RAGE, equaling the finer levels in the base game and even surpassing them in places.RAGE is one of those games that feel better out of context. It did not change the course of game design and will not give gamers reason to reinterpret the enjoyable hobby in question. But it is beyond any doubt a well-made shooter experience, carrying on certain traditions and expanding on others, all the while being an imaginary world well worth the visit if only for the places alone.

content:
17, 2013
												RAGE sets you in a ravaged wasteland world that is home to mutants, bandits and the Authority which all want a piece of you or should I say, a nice chunk of you. The wasteland environment looks gorgeous both in the way it has been designed and the graphics itself which easily helps with emersion. There are perhaps a few iffy textures when it comes to some of the interior levels, but if you can look past that and enjoy the wasteland, it's easily cancelled out. The character models and weaponary also look fantastic.Apart from the main story, the game offers some decent side missions, events and numerous amounts of things to collect. Schematics, recipies (these allow you to craft various things as long as you have parts), collectables, mini games, stunt jumps throughout the wasteland and of course, racing events where you can earn racing certificates to be used in upgrading your vehicles. There are also various ammo types you can use with your weapons.There's a few co-op missions you can do with one friend or a random. They're fun, but unfortunately a little short. There's also multiplayer by way of racing, but as to be expected, the multiplayer portion has fizzled out. The ending could be viewed as somewhat disappointing in the fact that it's left rather open and perhaps there could have been some stronger emphasis on the story, but all small negatives considered, the gameplay is solid, the graphics fantastic and there's plenty to keep you busy with for quite some hours. Having played three playthroughs of RAGE on Normal, Nightmare and Ultra Nightmare, I can say I thoroughly enjoyed the game each time.

Don’t worry, if you’ve already finished the main story in Rage, this DLC also brings in a new feature that allows you to continue to explore the Wasteland after you’ve completed the main campaign.When you load up your game you’ll be given a mission that asks you to investigate a new gang of bandits called The Scorchers. As you investigate this new threat you’ll meet up with new allies, gain access to new weapons and visit new locations. The great thing about The Scorchers is that the missions integrate into the main game, and the new areas all branch off existing areas in the game. You’ll still be able to visit the same shops, and talk to the same people, in between each part of the Scorchers mission....Nailgun is coming...

content:
y 12, 2013
												Rage is a fantastic game with an interesting story line, the intro towards the game is brilliant and makes the game moving and interesting to play on to find what happens. The game does have bad points but also bring good points, my bad points towards the game is, it’s too short, you will spend around 8 hours on the game and you’ll complete it, if you do the side quests and try for 100% completion, it may take up to 15 hours. When you get into your first town area, it’s hard to find your way around the area and can take up time, me personally I don’t want to get lost and waste time trying to find a place where I need to be. However in the towns, you have a lot of stuff to do, such as go to the merchants and buy ammo, items for building items and also you can play mini games to earn extra money in the game. They is also a race events that you can attend to which gives something extra to do in the game and something to complete.The ending of the game seems dull and could have been better and could tell more information on what happened.The graphics towards the game is amazing with a lot of details towards the scenes with shooting and driving around in the care.The mechanics of the game for me personally were hard to get used, but eventually I got used to them, they even easier with a controller. Driving is fluid, walking is fluid and both seem realistic.The game reminds me of Borderlands and a slight hint of Fallout, with rage having it’s own elements towards the game.I am happy with buying this product and would recommend this to anyone who enjoys shooters with a different atmosphere.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
er 27, 2013
												The game is pretty fun. The shooting is awesome, the variety in weapons is neat, and the enemies are apocalyptically crazy! For whatever reason, I had the profound thought when I first started this game that the shooting just felt really good. It felt comfortable and just great in general, beyond what other games have done.The driving works well enough, and blowing up enemy cars is always awesome, but there's just a little something missing that keeps it from being great. It was neat to get to use my apocalyptic car to race others, it was a good change of pace sometimes from blasting psychos and mutants. I enjoyed that I could customize my car up a bit, adding upgrades and changing out weapons and such.The world is kind of open, but not in the way The Elder Scrolls or Fallout or Far Cry are, it feels much more linear than that. The places where you can drive feel open but like there are only certain paths to take. Each area you explore on foot has some room for a little side exploration to discover hidden stuff, but it doesn't have the same sense of adventuring as other games do. You can do whatever you want, but there isn't much more to do than shoot up your enemies. To make up for what I'm going to say next a bit, the game does have a unique storyline, interesting characters, and the graphics are really beautiful. It was interesting listening to the voices of all the variety of characters, they had neat dialogue and were voiced well. Unfortunately, even though the characters were neat, the game just couldn't make you care less about what was going on, why you were doing what you were doing, or make you want to care about any of the characters. The storyline is unique, but it wasn't done well enough that it gripped you.Overall, it's a fun game and definitely worth your time, but there is definitely potential for so much more. I'd love to see another game in this franchise.

												Graphics and the general "mechanics" of the game were good, but there just seemed to be something lacking throughout. The story felt like a very weak attempt at blending elements of other post-apocalyptic worlds where everyone decides to go back to gang culture. Not one of the characters felt real. SummaryGOOD - graphics, racing (if you like that part)BAD - storyline, pace, originality
