content:
29, 2016
												I liked this game. It gets a lot of flak for not being a "landmark" title like people seem to expect from id, but that doesn't automatically mean it's terrible. But it's not fantastic. [Note: I did not play the co-op or multiplayer modes]The world is one of the more interesting post-apocalyptic settings I've seen in a video game, with obvious inspiration from Mad Max but with its own twist on the setting. The characters aren't really anything special, just basic NPCs that tell you where to go and what to do, then inexplicably disappear. Despite the cardboard characters, the world itself feels very lived in and real. The various throw-away NPCs scattered throughout towns comment on the events of the game as they unfold, they walk and move around so they don't just stand in one place for weeks on end like many other games, and some even move to new locations entirely.The plot and story start out simple and strong. It's nothing amazing, but it's done well enough that it works. The entire first half of the game is spent doing odd jobs for the various citizens of the wastelands (mostly killing ♥♥♥♥). Turns out, that's just a way of gaining notoriety so they can explain the terrible second half of the game. Roughly half of the way through the game, the game thrusts you into an anti-authoritarian resistance movement that has literally zero connection to the previous arc, with very little buildup to this sudden switch. You go from a wasteland survivor to ragtag rebel toppling a technologically superpower (that's never been done before!). What really blasts the story's coffin into the dirt is the ending: there basically isn't one. You go to a building, press some buttons, and there's a cutscene. Literally no issues brought up throughout the game are resolved. Literally none. You do not win. You do not lose. The ending is totally irrelevant to the overall story.Mechanically speaking, the gameplay is solid. The combat in general is really fun and just feels nice. I did feel as if certain weapons (the assault rifle, pistol with normal ammunition, the DLC nailgun's default mode) were totally useless once you get alternate ammunition or different guns, but they still served a purpose in the long run. What really surprised me is the variation in enemies. There's really only "two" enemies in the game: mutants and humans. But each faction of the humans has its own unique look and sound and combat style, which makes combat with different factions feel very refreshing despite the enemies more or less having the same set-up. I personally wasn't a huge fan of the vehicle combat, personally. Late in the game, the opposing vehicular forces mostly just spam missiles and shields and it's just exhausting to fight them. That being said, the vehicles themselves felt very nice and responsive - even with mouse and keyboard.tl;dr It's a really solid and fun game. Don't go into it expecting a masterpiece and you'll probably be impressed. It's not a bad game, and it's definitely above average in terms of quality and quantity of content. Very much worth its current price, and most definitely worth it at a discount. Anyone who disagrees is a bad person!!

content:
r 24, 2014
												well... I bought this game expecting a fallout-esque post apocalyptic adventure game from reading the reviews, and what I got was more along the lines of a modern DOOM with the look and feel of fallout, with the dungeon design of Oblivion/Skyrim.and what do I mean by that... well: The game is set in a post apocalyptic wasteland after an asteroid has struck earth, there are people buried in things called "Arks" much like the vaults in fallout. The guns, landscape, and enemies you face scream fallout.so the gameplay: Not fallout at all... I almost feel like the ability to aim down the sights of your gun is out of place in this game. It is extremely fast paced, I equate it to DOOM or another oldie FPS because I spent a good 90% of the game running around with a shotgun and my boomarang knives rather than hiding behind cover waiting for a headshot, and I am perfectly fine with that. I can't really describe the rush of throwing a wingstick at an enemy for the first time to have it take off their head and come back to you perfectly, It did not get old.and the level design: I really enjoyed the level design and it reminded me first and foremost of Oblivion style dungeons. That is to say that they were very straight-forward and hard to get lost in and wrapped around themselves wonderfully so that there was no backtracking to get back out. One thing you might frown upon is that you get sent into the same dungeons multiple times, even if they do send you through different paths and give you different enemies to kill, it seemed a bit lazy on some of the levels, but was executed perfectly on the Dead City level. The overworld is boring, The car segments boring - but take this with a grain of salt because I hate pretty much all racing games except MarioKart This game gets a thumbs up at it's discounted price which I got it with the DLC for 6,24$  I really wouldn't recommend it for any more than 15$ because it is only about 10-15 hours of good gameplay, unless you love twisted-metal-ey racing

content:
er 26, 2013
												Thanks to Steam's free-to-play weekend I gave RAGE a jam, what first drew me to download and play it was Snoop Dogg, RAGE is Snoops favourite game.I was a little reluctant at first because as a gamer I can become easily addicted to chasing achievements and didn’t want to delve into yet another post apocalyptic FPS, but RAGE is seeming more like a diamond in the rough.RAGE is a FPS developed by id Software. It uses the company's OpenGL-based id Tech 5 game engine and was released in October 2011.The game is set in a post-apocalyptic near future, following the impact of the asteroid 99942 Apophis on Earth. The game has been described as similar to the movie Mad Max 2 and to video games such as  Borderlands.The mixture of FPS shoot and loot based missions and demolition derby type racing is just enough to be entertaining, if you get board of the same go to point [A] and kill random bandits to recover some junk missions you can enter a race, zoom round a circuit and bash and crash your way across the finish line to earn more upgrades.In RAGE's story, the asteroid 99942 Apophis impacts the Earth on August 23, 2029, leaving few survivors. Human survivors have come together to form settlements around oases and other practical or habitable locations, including race tracks. These fragile homes are diligently defended by the inhabitants against bandits and mutants, which are divided into various gangs and organizations of their own.RAGE has two multiplayer modes: "Road Rage" and "Wasteland Legends". In Road Rage, up to four players compete in a free-for-all match that takes place in an arena designed to make use of the vehicles. The objective is to collect rally points that appear around the arena while killing your opponents and stealing their points. Legends of the Wasteland is a series of two-player co-op missions based on stories that are heard throughout the single-player campaign.So aside from the basic gameplay and plot overview my personal opinion on rage is to give it a go, even just a few casual missions and there are fun or get right into the game and get all those delicious achievements.If you find yourself really getting into the RAGE universe, Bethesda and Dark Horse Comics announced a three-issue comic book series based on RAGE, also there is an entire novel based on RAGE game.Enjoy killing bandits and making the roads a safer place, but watch out for Mutant's...

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 1, 2013
												Just a bit miffed, I’d sayThere’s a great game in here somewhere, struggling to get out. Unfortunately it never quite succeeds. RAGE was hyped up enormously prior to its launch and I was one of those gamers who looked forward to getting around to playing it. Don’t get me wrong,  I enjoyed the game but I was always aware that it could have been so much better. The story is standard post-apocalyptic fare and, more notably, the script lacks humour. The gameplay and combat, while good at times, are never outstanding. It tries to create the illusion of open-world play but in fact it’s pretty much a corridor shooter with defined routes and little opportunity to explore. The graphics are also deceptive: the landscapes look good from a distance but close-up the textures are disappointing. It should be noted, however, that the background music is quite impressive. There are echoes of both Borderlands and Fallout 3 here, but RAGE is a subpar game when compared to either. It’s a shame that the people who brought us the excellent Doom series failed, on this occasion, to match their earlier success. I’ve no doubt, however, that they will regain their form in the future.3.5/5

												It isn't a bad game perhaps I was expecting much!!I have played through the whole game in 28.7 hours, completed each and every side quests (left a few), but after 28.7 hours of my life that I devoted to this game in hope of getting something, i was left with an empty stomache and with a bad taste in my mouth. Rage is a fully open world game, which involves sweet elements like the old school arcade type racing & fast paced combat. At first when I started, the opening sequence blew me away, the graphics looked sharp, art design and every graphical fidelity was top notch. I could see vast landscapes, people, bandits running around in their buggeys and all sort of ♥♥♥♥ and It made me super hyped up that I want to explore every bit of it. However that soon came to an end.ProsThe game looks stunning considering the fact that it came out 4 years ago. It does an awesome job of introducing new combat mechanics and enemy types. This isn't just an open world fps game, it also involves old school arcade style racing, something that reminded me of some of the classics I palyed back when I was small. This game might not have tonnes of guns but holy ♥♥♥♥!! it has tonnes of different bullets!! (Yup! you heard me......Bullets!!). Each enemy type requires you to switch ammunition type. Heavy bullets for heavily armored, insanely heavy bullets for insanely armored. This requires you to plan ahead before infiltrating a bandit camp, stocking up on ammo, best suited for that faction and resources. The game has a good variety and amount of enemy types that it will throw at you to keep things interesting. Weapons are awesome and every enemy reacts differently to different weapon, shoot their legs and they'll stumble and fall or shoot their faces and they'll try to reassure that their face isn't missing by touching it with their hands. The enemy ai is good, really good.The game also has a decent crafting system which let's you craft items on the fly. You usewhatever parts scrap metal, junk you can salvage from the wasteland and dead bandits to create turrets, medkits, lock grinders, RC bbombs etc.THE MULTIPLAYERSince I am playing the game 4 years after it's release, I couldn't find any matches online, Sorry!! ConsRage creates an illusion of being an open world I say this because at first it will tempt you by showcasing these sewers that are scattered all around the wasteland, the bandits carrying on with their work, doing their business but then it hits the speed breaker. When you finally get to explore these things you realize that their aren't that many sewers in the whole god damn game, and one of them unlocks only for one mission. The game will have you infiltrating the same camps again and again and again and again........ and for some f***ing reason you encounter enemies exactly at the same location you encountered them before, so even before you can see them you can fire a rocket straight to the location you had your last encounter and it will work. The world is big and filled with detail but there is not much to it, it all ultimately feels so dull because it lacks the depth feels too much abandoned, there's not a whole lot of things to do in it and it always holds your hand, restricting you from exploring it. Some of the locations which look interesting are locked out even though you could see the enemies shooting at you from a distance. I mean to say why give the players access to a place, which isn't ready to be discovered for another 2 to 3 hrs, so early. The sidequest are probably the weakest part of the game, the game itself is like stuck on a replay button, you do things which you have already done over and over again until you say "f*** this....I'm out". The end mission also feels a ♥♥♥♥♥slap to the players face, because the ending does not liveup to the hype that was earlier built throughout the campaign, the excitement to see the fate of the world, the future of your protagonist, what happend to your buddies etc, it's just so out of place and will leave you scratching your head. The NPCs look interesting (but are not) and have fluid animations but they don't have much to contribute towards your immersion and the world itself. This makes me feel so bad, this game feels like a wasted opportunity at the least, it certainly had tonnes of potentiol to become the next fallout people were hoping for.<SPOILER WARNING>   and don't even let me remind you how pathetic and cheap the end mission is, when you are finally ready to rumble in rages final round, you hear your companions warn you, saying things like, "no one knows whats in there" or things like "whatever they are hiding in that facility must be big" hearing all this got me pumped up, and since they gave me a big f***ing gun to handle with the mess, I started to believe that an epic boss battle awaited me. I stocked up on all my resources, built every sentry turret I could afford and then the big moment came but guess what!! you get to fight chimpanzees, yup! you heard me mother f***ers!! you fight chimps (mutated ofcourse, if that was the plot twist you were looking for)......"they litterally give you a futuristic big f***ing plasma gun to kill chimps", WTF! VERDICT 7.8/10Sorry! but I just can't give it an 8, even though 7.8 pretty much means the same, In the end, I would just say go ahead and buy it. It is a fun shooter, which will really hook you to it self, as combat is certainly the one part of the game, where Rage shines. Just don' t expect much given that it is an open world game published by none other than "Bethesda".

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Story: Now a massive asteroid hits earth in the year of 2029. There is several areas that have pockets of survivors that are forced to begin a new civilization. The world is populated by human survivors of the impact, who have come together to form settlements around oases and other practical or habitable locations, including racetracks. These fragile homes are diligently defended by the inhabitants against bandits and mutants, which are divided into various gangs and organizations of their own. Now you the ark survivor comes into the world in the year 2135. Now this game gave me the feel of Fallout which I liked very much. Now people may say fallout rip off. Which I admit ok. But really its not exactly the same. It might start nearly the same but its just a different game. Any way. You fight your way through three area's to help bring the world back from the brink of its near destruction from the Asteroid. I liked this. A nice fit for survival.Game Play: The game primarily consists of FPS and driving area's, with the you using vehicle's to explore the world and travel between missions. Combat is in first person view. You are armed with a variety of firearms from pistols to a nice rocket launcher and my favorite weapon wing sticks (They are like boomerangs). You get different ammo for each weapon. Which you can change to your style. There is two types of enemies Shooting and melee, no need to explain what they do since its easy to figure out. Now there is several vehicle events for you to participate in. Races and checkpoint rallies. Racing events may or may not have opponents, and some of them are armed races while others are not. You have the ability to augment you cars with various items and upgrades you can gain by completing events. Rage also some (RPG) elements, inventory system, looting system and Also able to build a wide assortment of items using collected recipes. There are also side missions and a number of other minor exploratory elements to the game.Now this game is not fully open world like many out there. Yes you are restricted. But there is still a lot you can do. So do not let the closed world put you off. The game is fun and an interesting story to it to.Controls: Easy and simple for anyone to use. Not much else to say on that. Controls can be customized to how you like it of course via keyboard and mouse. The Graphics: The Graphics are really great. The characters and weapons had me drolling. Never seen such good graphics on my system like that and I am not usually some one for graphics.Music: It was good for the game. But for this game I turned it off so I could pay more attention to the game, sometimes I find music distracting in games.Bugs and Glitches: Right this was a big issue. Poor pc compatibility with this port. Rendering issues on the graphics and glitches in the sound along with (CTD's) But with user tweaks and fixes the game got better there was still issues but not as many for me it was just CTD's caused by my xfire. Technical issues with the PC version has led to articles explaining to users how to "fix" Rage's problems. AMD had released drivers that attempt to fix some the issues. Then on October 10, 2011 patches for the Windows version were released which added various graphical options to the game and fixed a number of driver-related graphical issues.Reply Value: Sadly I do not find any reply value in this game at all. Its a one time play in my books.Overall: Now the story is good in my books. Game play is good to but there is room for improvements. Controls are easy as I have said. Graphics are amazing. Music is good. Graphics really great. There is bugs and glitches in the game and most are fixed via user help and drivers and a patch. Even for a poorly ported game. This was quiet fun and exciting for me. The ending was nice to shows for a possible squeal. But I am not going to tell you the ending. So my rating for this game will be 7 paws for this good game.

content:
1, 2015
												I just love post-apocalyptic games. This one is in particular one very atmospheric one. In the world of RAGE everything is just about your "clan" and racing. Though I am not really a racing gamer, the racing parts in this were kinda fun. You got different cars, to equip and to arm. Then you take it to the road. I just finished all the racing events in Wellspring the night I started. Although the "Rocket Rally" competitions are really getting on my nerves...The other part of the game is about the dangers of the wasteland, especially bandits and mutants. There are some small civilized groups and there are several bandit clans, which each got their own tone. Some are cannibal like, some are in control of the power plant and raise high prices for the energy. It just all really fits well together. The two main things that bothered me was the main story, which at first is nice and you get to love the characters, but later in the game is a little too "rushed". The later the game, the faster everything is done.  The other thing was a complete lack of decisionmaking you get to do. You are more of a mindless robot than a symbol for humanities best. All in all a solid game with good atmosphere and characters, that will not get too repetitive.

content:
er 27, 2013
												RAGE is one of the first open world games i've actually enjoyed, while all the others mainly consist of travelling miles to an area then killing a few enemies, RAGE keeps travelling to a minimum and puts most emphasis into its amazing combat. Every shot feels powerful, as every bullet sends your target stumbling and limping. The first person combat sections are usually set in corridored levels full of enemies to mow down, making it a blend of Borderlands 2 (the driving, setting and open world) and Quake 4 (the frantic action set in the fairly common linear area). I recommend this to anybody who likes FPS and open world games.

content:
ber 26, 2014
												Rage is a mixed bag. There were times, when I was thinking "Wow, this is one of my favourite games", and then there were times, when I was cursing the devs for lack of balance (or my lack of gaming skills – depends on your perspective). But I definitely would recommend this game as a great example of FPS.Features:- Great setting that really provides a genuine sense of a post-apocalyptic world.- Decent amount of weapons with different kinds of ammo (a pistol, an assault rifle, a shotgun, a sniper rifle, a crossbow, a nail gun, a rocket launcher, a machine gun, a pulse cannon).- Crafting options that improve your statistics and arsenal (health upgrades, armor upgrades, wingsticks, bandages, turrets, sentry bots, bomb cars, EMP grenades, lock grinders, mind control bolts (!), health boosts, damage boosts etc.)- Four types of vehicles: a quadricycle, a buggy, a pick-up truck and an armored vehicle. The latter three are upgradable and eventually have three types of guns (a mini-gun that shoots bullets, a rocket launcher and a pulse cannon).- Three types of character customisation. Not that it matters much.- Fun side-missions- Mini-games (a card game, a knife game, wingstick throwing, roulette, poker, a kind of board game and banjo play). I basically played only the card game, the others were too boring.- Racing challenges where you can earn racing certificates required for vehicle upgrades- Interesting characters and enemies. There are basically three kinds of enemies: bandits (Vasted Clan, Shrouded Clan, Jackals, Ghost Clan, Gearheads, Scorchers), mutants and the Authority. Each of them require different approach.- Easter eggs and hidden arenas with references to previous iD releases (Doom and Wolfenstein). See the guides and YouTube for more info.- Sexy girls with funny monologue lines- A trophy room- Collectible cards (hard to obtain, but you have no other choice if you want to win the card mini-game). There are two achievements for that: one for collecting all cards and one for beating the most difficult deck.- Multiplayer and co-op. They're basically dead. Couldn't connect with my friend to play the Co-Op missions- An option to change difficulty during the gameplay.PROS:- Great, vivid graphics, but, as far as I've heard, they're better on consoles. Though, this is true only for landscapes, because the close-ups are lacking detail (e.g., blurred text, simplified texture).- Tactical gameplay. It's not just straightforward shooting. Your weapon and ammunition choice really matters, you need to use different approaches for different enemies. You can rush forward and take your chances with fast and strong weapons or take your enemies out one by one from cover or you can throw grenades and set back or you can take their heads off with wingsticks or a shotgun or you can stealth-attack with arrows and wingsticks - the choice is yours. You can even use turrets and bomb cars or mind-control enemies turning them into suicide bombers.- Interesting (though a simple) storyline with gradual and smooth progression but and abrupt ending.CONS:- Too much focus on racing for my taste. Also, some of the rally point missions and the third mail delivery mission are too difficult in my opinion. I managed to complete all of them, but seeing, how AI drivers steal rally points right under your nose half the time, was a bit frustrating at times. - Everything is expensive. You're constantly out of ammo or out of money. I had the same problem with Wolfenstein: NWO. I guess it's a kind of iD/Bethesda thing.- Some of the missions are too challenging. Challenge is a challenge, but when chordes of armored mutants are rushing towards you and you don't have time to properly aim and you require a whole magazine per enemy, it's no fun at all.- Video tearing on camera turns. You either need to lower your video settings or try manual configuration (see the guides for more info).- An abrupt ending of the storyline. Leaves a feeling that game was not fully completed.Nevertheless, I think that iD is a great developer and all their games are great, with RAGE being no exception.My overall rating: 9/10. And, yes, the DLC is worth the money.

content:
er 29, 2013
												RAGE is an FPS made by the legendary ID software, responsible for Doom and Quake. This is their latest game, and while people say it's awful, it's only because ID made it, and the expectations were unreasonably high. This game feels like a watered down Borderlands, with the exploring and shooting fun. Not too much stuff to do, but the game is at a short, good length. I would say 10-15 hours should take care of it.The game plays like an ordinary FPS, running through places, shooting things. the game takes place in two separate hub locations, which branch off into different areas. The shooting is great, but the exploration is lacking. There really isn't much stuff to look at, making any collectibles and stuff pointless. The base game is quite enjoyable. It's just a normal shooter in a semi open world, don't expect anything more. There is a lot of racing sequences and driving, so be prepared to do some races and car combat if you want to get anywhere in this game.The multiplayer.....uhh.. The co-op missions are quite fun, but there's only a few of them to do. The road rage multiplayer is passable, and it's basically a ripoff of Twisted Metal.This game is beautiful, but suffers pop-in textures. Luckily, no matter how good your computer is, it should run very well. I have a terrible computer and I was able to run it in 60 FPS. This game is excellent, but don't set your expectations too high, because RAGE can only jump so high.

content:
er 27, 2013
												I remember hearing and waiting for this game back in '08. I actually remember them announcing that Rage would be coming out sometime in April, 2009. Yeah, that's how long I've been waiting for this game. Long and behold, it's finally here.For those who didn't know, this game occupies 3 DVDs. That's right, the game weights 21 GB. Well, at least Sony's Blu-Ray format doesn't have that problem. I am also extremely glad that the developers didn't trim down the game so it could fit on one DVD (you know, if it can fit on one DVD for the Xbox, then it can fit anywhere, kind of like what happened with the trimming down of the GTA 4 world map because of the DVD format.)Anyways, the new engine is astounding. The textures are amazing, especially the faraway ones. I get a stable 60 FPS with my Fermi, 8 GB Ram and 2.93 icore. It is very nice to see a new engine and not some re-used or re-updated albeit old inherently engine like Unreal 3.0.However, do not expect this game to be open-worlded in the same sense that Fallout 3 and New Vegas are. The world seems large but you are only confined to small and medium sized areas. As you play, more of these areas become available and you can go back if you want to, but this game is mostly linear when it comes to navigating the world itself.There is not enough exploration to go around but I absolutely love the environments - none of the environments repeat. I love the abandoned buildings, hotels, sewers, back alleys and such. It is something that I always wanted to experience in the last two Fallout games but couldn't because of the lack of the said environments, because of the recycled areas with the same textures and objects and because of the outdated engine. This time however I can't stop taking snapshots via Fraps and Steam.There are several types of enemies. Some of the punks however speak with a British accent and have British flag tattoos, but most of them look the same (a homage to Mad Max and Doomsday (2008) perhaps?). There are some other medium and large-sized mutants.I like the fact that there are several vehicles and that you can customize them. There are also several ammo types for each weapon, however all I really ask for is for head shot to equal instant death, which is not the case in this game unless you use a shotgun up close.You can also create some new items that will help you advance in the game as well as access some closed off areas so do not hurry to sell every junk you find because you might need it.As far as the weapons are concerned, well I'd say that most of them get readily available within the first few quests, so you do not really have to work hard to get them. Plus the ammo is not that scarce for some reason, so do not expect any Metro 2033-kind lack of ammo. Also, half of the weapons look like they were taken from Crysis. I would also expect some weapons to be home-made.There' s no way to skip the occasional cut scenes or hurry up the monologue, BUT if you take a few steps away from the person giving you the quest, then the quest becomes readily available without you having to hear the whole story.The enemy AI is good. They dodge bullets, take cover, retreat, advance and throw grenades - everything that you really need. It is also satisfying to blast some of the melee-wielding enemies. They don't always rush at you either, they actually try to surround you.This brings me to another point. The gameplay itself is what truly shines in this game. The fire fights and the shooting just do not get old. It is extremely satisfying to fight the hordes of mutants. You can craft sentry turrets and sentry bots(like in Doom 3) to help you out. You can also craft various types of special ammo, and since there's no weight limit, there's little reason to sell junk that can be used to construct the dozen or so different things.When you die, the nanomachines that were implanted in you moments before the asteroid collision and the subsequent hypersleep serve as a defibrillator. Meaning if you die, you can revive yourself once or twice before the defibrillator recharges. There's a tiny minigame involved that determined how much health you get once you are revived. And by health I mean how red your screen is before it turns normal since the game has regenerative health.The characters you encounter are all unique. They all have different clothes, voices and personalities. Some give you new quests, some just do small chit-chat. The secondary characters even have names.There are some easter eggs scattered around including a few that pay respect to Fallout, like the bobble head and the water purifier chip.The minuses:Let's get this out of the way: You can't see your legs and you cast no shadow.Oh, and you are also mute. All you can do is listen.I like the fact that you do not have any maps or minimaps when you enter new unknown areas ( I don't like excessive HUD), but friendly towns could use some indicators because it causes some confusion when you enter a new friendly place and are trying to navigate between the newly introduced characters and quests.When you drive a vehicle you get a third person view, however you cannot look around or behind you which really constricts your view.The sky looks amazing although it is static. It's like a giant wall paper.The dead bodies disappear quickly, but at least they won't do so unless you loot them. So if you want to increase realism, do not loot the bodies.I don't think I've encountered a single checkpoint or an auto-save. That's right, your entire progress depends on your manual F5 saves, what's more is that every time you save, it takes 4 seconds for the screen to unfreeze. Annoying but necessary. So if you forget to save and die, you will have to repeat your last progress from your last save.The game is also extremely easy. I'm playing on the hardest (Nightmare) mode and I steam roll over everyone and everything. The quick regenerating health is part of the issue.The most important thing is the lack of a good and consistent story. This game nailed almost everything but the main story. You wake up from cryosleep and you get thrown into the semi-open world of fetch quests. For some reason people around you assume that you are a killing machine who is able to take out hordes of enemies and fetch supplies. No one ever explains why you should be doing the things you are doing. One might think that there is no need for one coherent story in the huge 21 GB single player post-apocalyptic world but I beg to differ since this is not an open-world game. You cannot bypass quests and go wherever you want, there ARE constrictions.Overall, the game feels like playing a Mad Max movie with the elements of Borderlands, Fallout, and Some Metro 2033 elements. But that is not to say that any ideas were stolen or re-used for this game. Rage is its own kind of animal, it is unique and it's got plenty of peculiar style. The world is believable and immersive. And the game itself gets better and better as you play it.Highly recommended.

y 27, 2016
												Rage is lacking. I did enjoy some of its parts, but mostly it was just that feeling of unused potential.Pros:-	I liked the fighting system, weapons felt okay-	Locations were well-made-	Plot was a bit blunt but turned out okay-	Ability to drive vehicles – I enjoyed that part of the game the most (I always missed that in Fallouts)-	Games world’s atmosphere similar to Fallout’s (but definitely inferior in all the aspects)-	Cities were alright-       I like the graphicsCons –-	Boring races… Seriously that could have been done much, much better…-	Bandits on the roads – annoying-	Not opened world (something that only pretended to be opened, but was really few closed locations connected by closed roads)-	World was boring and too small-	TOO SHORT! Game ended so suddenly…-	Compatibility problems – some of the add ons made my game to crush in my native language (was okay when I changed to English)-	Dreary NPC-	Gameplay “on rails” – no choice where to go or what to do… Just go forward with what game had for you.-	Side quest were… boring…Conclusion,Well, I expected something better…. But maybe my expectations were just a bit too high after playing in masterpieces like Fallout 3 or New Vegas.RATING 3.50/10

content:
er 26, 2013
												Surprisingly, after hearing so much negative press, I find that RAGE is quite enjoyable. The gunplay could use some work at times (a magazine of 7.62x39 should be more than ample to take down a human, when all shots hit the head), but the driving is quite good for a game that's a mix of shooter/driver. I haven't completed the entirety of the campaign yet, as I'm playing through the DLCs at the moment (both of which follow the campaign instead of adding end-game content, though Sewers is part of the base game now) but the story is not nearly as hackneyed as many have accused it of being. It feels like Mad Max, Borderlands, and Car Wars had a disturbing little baby.The weapons are nice, there is a good selection of generic staples (the assault rifle, machine gun, shotgun of course) in addition to some fun takes on things like the crossbow and pistol (which uses a removable cylinder and multiple caliber options--not possible but pretty fun in a video game), minigun toting spider drones, turrets, RC car bombs... it's taken a non-RPG shooter and given it some pretty entertaining, though not genre defining, upgrades.All in all, though it is a Bethsoft published product... it's worth purchasing when on sale.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
er 28, 2013
												This game is great!  After purchasing, I immediately played through it 3 times, trying out the 3 different character classes,  increasing the difficulty and finding more hidden locations each time.There's plenty of variety to the game and it's loads of fun.  The story is sufficiently engaging and the world has an immersive atmosphere.It delivers very well as a shooter and the driving isn't bad either.  The weapons are great - they look/sound good and feel terrific.  Combat is very satisfying.Some (all?) of the guns have alternate ammo types (ie: armor piercing, explosive, electric) which you will learn to use strategically (or to completely steamroll the enemy).It features a fairly unique open world which is fun to explore in your upgradable offroad vehicles which you also get to use to partake in violent races through the badlands.I also think the game looks beautiful as far as settings, NPC's, weapons, vehicles, etc go.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Put "Rage" on your wish list and buy it on sale. "Rage" is pretty mediocre. Not *bad*, just mediocre. It plays like an extended tech demo (which is probably is seeing how the marketing is hyping the game engine) that is, it takes the "kitchen sink" approach to game design, lacking focus. Everything you could want to do with a  game engine is represented and is polished to a glorious shine and it is shiny, just mediocre. The first person combat is entertaining enough. The driving sections are OK-ish and not actually broken in any way so they get a pass, I guess. There are RPG elements, but they don't *really* matter. There is crafting, which also doesn’t really matter. There is an evil authority, there are vicious mutants and there are good and noble rebels - which in game are called "The Authority", "The Mutants" and "The Rebels". You see? Mediocre. What wasn't strictly mediocre was the enemy AI which would (depending on enemy type) rather effectively take and use cover. This made the combat sections with those enemies stand out from the rest of the game, but not too far out, because this game doesn't really get to far past mediocre.  I would also like to point out that for the PC you will most likely have to create a config file to fix several graphic and performance issues. Once this is done, the game will be beautiful and run very well, but a player should be able to run a game out of the box without having to do this, so instead of "Rage" getting and outstanding for polish, it again achieves mediocre.

ry 5, 2014
												The only reason I brought this game was for the co-op.I literally thought the co-op was the campaign, which it is not.You can do the co-op in less than 6 hours and then multiplayer which is fun for abit before you realise that there are only few modes and maps.Graphics: They are actually very good for this game and have a weird style which makes this game very enjoyable with the added graphics. Audio: I find the audio very unique with some very well made sounds from guns to voices...Controls: Very easy to get used too, which is a pickup and go game, seriously it's easy. Game: The campaign is suprisingly fun though, so you will have fun playing it.  It just really really cries to play the campaign co-op which I hoped it would have. The campaign it seems to be very very long, I've been at it hours and not made a dent but has taken me on a wild journey already. The game is decent made, with lots of hidden secrets and thing put around which you might not notice, like a character wearing a Doom T-Shirt.  Fallout 3 bobble head.  Characters names from games, Quake walk arounds etc.This game is unique and fun to play and I hope they make a Rage 2 but do full co-op.Would I recommend this game? Yes because it is a very unique game and worth the money to play if you are after a long story driven diverse different wasteland game.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												A fun and intense first person shooter set in the future of wasteland earth. So, it’s a little bit like Mad Max then? Well, it’s about 99% Mad Max-like. I mean you’re going to see insane weaponry, vehicular combat and bandit gangs, so it’s safe to say that this is a Mad Max themed shooter, but definitely not a movie clone. Graphics: 10/10For a game that is nearly 5 years old, it still impresses me on how good it looks. It’s not “perfect” by any means, but its good enough that you will think that this game is newer than it looks. Not to mention that you don’t need an overly powerful graphics card to run it; a GeForce 9800 GTX or an AMD equivalent is just enough to get playable framerates. This also goes for both the CPU and RAM. No need for a fancy £1000 rig to enjoy this game. Storyline: 7/10You are emerged into a wasteland earth full of bandits, gangs and mutants. You are seen as the ‘hero’ of the game and you learn more about the places and the people the more you play further into the story. It’s the generic story where you defeat all the mutants and gangs, whilst doing unrelated side-quests along the way and eventually “save” the world. It’s nothing new to the table in terms of storytelling and I wouldn’t personally call this one “story heavy”, the game is an experience and is for experience, not to be fully immersed in it. It certainly delivers that experience in a decent sense. Sound: 10/10The sounds of gunfire, the roaring engines and the clarity of the voice acting is at its best. Every bit of soundtrack has been fined tuned to sound how they were supposed to be heard. I am proud of what id Software did here. What an impressive achievement. Gameplay: 9/10It delivers very smooth and very polished gameplay that many is sure to enjoy for hours. The controls are responsive and the game difficulty is well balanced. The only downside is that you have to keep checking if you have enough ammo for a weapon as ammo in this game is very scarce, especially at the start of the game. Price: 10/10For the price of £12.99 and an additional £3.49 for a DLC, it is reasonably well priced and is definitely worth buying. Although, I suggest waiting until it goes on sale to get it.

Overall a Very Good Gun & Run Game. Recommended for any Hardcore FPS/Shooter Fans.

												Visually Rage is a work of art. The id artists are responsible for some of the most amazing environments and artwork I have seen yet. number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
er 18, 2013
												RAGE is a difficult game for me to recommend or even describe my thoughts on. On one hand, there is one main (and important aspect) to the game that the game nails in spades (imo). However, on every other hand the game fails to deliver with…just about everything else. For me: The most important aspect to a videogame is that of its gameplay. With that in my mind on games, RAGE, to me, is the biggest counterexample to that claim that I have ever seen and played.The basic premise is an asteroid fell to Earth and ravaged the planet creating the homeland and setting to the main game, the Wasteland. You play as an Ark survivor who awakens to find the rest of your Ark members dead. Afterwards, you activate a panel that opens the door and step out into the desolate world. You enter the Wasteland and encounter some of the enemies that you will be fighting later on your journey and after being saved by Dan Hagar (played by John Goodman). You and him set off for town to begin your adventure and help in the ongoing battle against the bandits who rule the Wasteland.Right off the bat, story wise, you can tell this isn't going to be any more than just a slapped on, Grade B, generic story that's sole purpose is a background for you and your rampant annihilation that you bring onto the enemies of the Wasteland. To be fair, id isn't really a company well known for their story telling, characters, or even their open worlds like say the Fallout series. However, in RAGE it feels like id was putting more emphasis on story and characters than their previous works; it felt as if id really wanted to break free from their simplistic shooter roots of just running and gunning with barely and reasoning behind except, "Screw it! Why not?" That and the modern warfare market the FPS genre lives in now makes it difficult for future FPS games to not include it in the main game. Either way, the singleplayer portion of RAGE story wise is painfully average at best with characters that are barely memorable or interesting; they leave absolutely no impression on you and are there solely to have you help them in the form of missions. Missions in the game aren't really good either, they're your standard RPG-esque affair of, "Clear out X area." Just like about everything else in the game, missions are typical, offer no variety, and ontop of everything else is uninteresting and stock; it makes for one very average package. Voice acting is decent, some voices sound rather strange for the setting they're in and some voices don't feel right with their character design but otherwise the voice acting isn't too terrible, but, with such stock and uninteresting characters it hardly matters. Again, this wouldn't be too much of a big deal given id's previous works but considering how much more emphasis id has put on the world and the characters this time around it's a shame that this is the end result.The big surprise for me, though, was in the graphics. Graphically, RAGE is stunning; the textures are crisp, the detail is insane, and the models on characters are incredibly well done as well as their animations. Id's new Tech 5 engine is quite a looker and is better than most of the other engines FPSs and games in general are running on these days. What really stuns me is just how well the graphics worked for my PC; I'm not well versed in PC terminology and graphic fidelity but here's what I will say: I can barely play Skyrim on high without my computer struggling to run 15 FPS let alone 30; RAGE, however, was buttery smooth throughout my whole time playing it. The game didn't lag for me, I didn't need to downgrade the graphics, and, besides a few graphical issues here and there, looked absolutely amazing and ran impeccably well given my machine. Graphically, RAGE looks incredible but visually, it's very unappealing; that does more or less have to do with the setting at hand rather than the art department’s fault plus I’m not a fan visually of post-apocalyptic settings. Even if I was I feel RAGE would still disappoint me on that ground; it lacks any personality and doesn't stand out from the rest. It has no defining characteristics and is just as stock and generic as the characters that inhabit the world. Yes, it is a post-apocalyptic setting so it's rather hard for the game to have "personality" but, come on. You can't say that no games set in the post-apocalyptic future setting don’t have personality. Again, going back to the Fallout series, some of the games have personality to them and are much more interesting than anything and anybody in RAGE. Graphics are great on RAGE and look great on my PC, it's just that the graphics that make up the world are uninteresting and lack any real defining characteristic that sets it apart from the rest.As stated previously, the biggest aspect that this game and id knock out of the ballpark is the gameplay (well, half of it at least). Keep in mind, I have not played a previous id title before RAGE; I have seen footage of their other work but I have never really played any of their other games so I have no previous knowledge on how well their previous FPS mechanic offerings have been. I can say, though, that between all my other FPS games that I've played previously, RAGE might just be the best that I've played in that aspect. Every gun feels excellent and meaty to use, gunning down enemies is a blast, and besides one gun (shotgun wasn't really as good as I was hoping it would be) all the guns sound great to fire; though, in my time with the game there were barely any guns outside of the pistol, shotgun, assault and sniper rifle, and rocket launcher. RAGE isn't as fast paced as Doom or Quake so there is a little bit of weight and slowness to your character but even with that restriction the FPS mechanics in RAGE are some of the best I've seen since the original Crysis.On top of the excellent FPS mechanics, RAGE also offers racing and car combat gameplay. Driving mechanics, for the most part, aren't to terrible; there were some weird moments like whenever I made a reversal U-Turn so that I could go back and destroy the bandit's buggies I turn a little faster than when I'm turning normally so instead of a 180 degree turn around it was like a slight 270 degree instead. It was weird and frustrating but for the most part the driving is pretty solid in the game; it's just not as good as the FPS mechanics and is really only used as a means of travel. Car combat I found, mechanically speaking, OK but personally for me I just found it rather boring more than anything else. Also should mention that I have not played a single second of the multiplayer as, from what I've heard, the multiplayer focuses more on the driving and car combat aspect. I also didn't play any co-op because, I had no idea co-op was even apart of RAGE. Though, honestly, co-op is co-op, it's practically a given at this point that with friends co-op can be an absolute blast especially if co-op focuses more on the FPS part of RAGE than the multiplayer did.Overall, RAGE is a difficult game for me to like. It nails the FPS gameplay and the graphics are great but everything else in the package ranges from decent to below average. There's barely any creativity to the game, you don't care for anything or anybody in the game, strange design choices, while OK not a fan of the driving or car combat, and because of the emphasis on story and characters the game pulls you out of the gameplay more so than it should. RAGE is not a bad game, but it is a very weak game given the id's broad history. Keep in mind I only played it for 12 hours if even that, maybe later the game picks up the pace but from what I played these are the feelings I am left with. If you can focus more on the meaty and excellent FPS mechanics more so than I could then you'll probably find RAGE a more enjoyable game. If not then there's not much else that the game really has going for it so my advice: skip it.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
2016
												There are so many amazing things about this game, it is entirely underrated. Unfortunately a lack of marketing combined with the overall lack of content are what ultimately made this game less successfull than its 2011 classmates such as Skyrim. With that said, to this day this is easily one of my favorite games that I have played. What the game lacks in content is makes up for a million times in character, beauty and overall fluid gameplay.In comparison, RAGE vs. Bioshock (any of them) Rage wins in actual gameplay and mechanics while Bioshock would win with the strong storyline. They are  both incredible games, but put the stoy-type that Bioshock has into this game and honestly you have the perfect FPS game.I'll start with Cons:-The game is short, there is no way around it.-There is more more that they could have done with the 'racing' aspect of this game. It really is more of a mini game within the game but it offered versatility in a fairly constricting game.-This is a FPS with linear story progression, there is very minimal sandbox-type capabilitiesThe Pros:-Gameplay is just delightful-Weapons are varied and the bow with environment interavtivity and ammunition types is just increible.-The various ways to approach every single fight whether it is through exploding remote cars, guns blazing, etc... The game boasts strong versatility in gameplay.-TONS of mini-games within the game that are all pretty fun.-The story is very entertaining-The game is full of vibrant characters and monsters-The art style is great-The graphics are just beautiful considering a 2011 release date.-The engine was truely a pioneer, boasting ZERO, I repeat, NO replicated areas or terrain types. (To explain, in most games, areas are replicated, reconfigured and reskinned. For example, in Fallout you may notice that a lot of areas are quite similar. This does not happen in RAGE as the engine was developed to be able to specifically alter each area, each rock, each spray painted wall.)

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
er 4, 2015
												RAGE is a mix of FPS and Driving genres, set in post-apocalyptic desert setting and with some dose of RPG elements, this comes in form of inventory and hub world. Yep, still developed by id Software, who mostly were doing FPS games, and released in 2011, published by Bethesda by that time. It runs on id Tech 5, main point of which were mega-textures.There were few versions of RAGE. If you pre-ordered then you would recieve Anarchy Edition. You can also buy it separately but no on Steam. Anarchy included few unique items to make players more powerful, including Double Shotgun. From what I understand some of Anarchy editions came with code for Sewers DLC. You could also buy this DLC separately on consoles. There are also some comics and "making of" videos, Collector Edition came with those. And then there was Campaign Edition for Mac OS X that included Anarchy Edition content plus Sewer DLC, but was singleplayer-only.While Steam version is not Anarchy Edition, it comes with Sewers DLC for free. And that's good, because this DLC gives sewers levels that are filled with mutants which can challenge you only in the very beggining. Not something worth after beating game.As far as I know the only good difference between consoles and PC is that consoles support split-screen for multiplayer.The thing is that this game apparently was hyped as being really open-world RPG, but in the end people got hub of corridors between each traditional level, making people dissapointed. And because id is a brand and people expect revolution, even though id only did it with Doom1/Quake1 long time ago. And since people want everything post-apocalyptic game to be either Fallout or Borderlands, well, it got underrated.Technically, it had a lot of problems at the launch. John Carmack came up with new feature called Mega-Textures. You may think of it as super-detailed textures, but what it means is that artists can can place something nice in one spot without it looping all over the wall. He must have been expected that hardware people would be the one who would rush to give proper support for that feature, but RAGE wasn't Quake 1 and no one cared. And so majority of players experienced huge issues with textures pop-in, where everything will take seconds to become clear when you look at it. Thankfully, game was patched around and hardware moved ever since, so it should be fine now.At least it shows that programming fancyness of John Carmack is better at developing cutting edge VR tech than games, where "can most average players hardware run it" is more important.It also has a multiplayer component. Which is being run by lobby system. And community of which is quite dead.It has two modes. No, not Deathmatch and Capture The Flag.The first mode is Road Rage, which is competetive and uses Racing genre of a game. Has a few sub-modes and is designed for 4 players. Didn't get to play it. Just check YouTube for gameplay.Second mode is Wasteland Legends - cooperative FPS. It's designed for 2 players and seems to use unique short missions. Or you could play them in singleplayer, alone. Well, not all that unique, it uses assets from single-player, but it's not same layouts. Plotwise they tell stories of behind-the-scene events, something silly like "how Dan got Sniper Rifle". There are no inventories, few weapons, you occasionally come across supply which will max out your ammo, if you run out of defib then your friend will have to come and revive you. Not much value for singles, better drag a friend into it.And yes, as many people will tell you, plot isn't good. For RPG. If forget that this is mainly linear FPS/Racing game. So it does job fine. Then again, seeing the hype it was dissapointed. But don't worry, setting combined with amazing graphics are still fun. Seeing all the new amazing NPC designs and hearing the way that each enemy clan communicates with each other, as well as finding out in what enviroment they live, is what was the driving force for me. Game also has great atmoshpere. It goes from surviving wasteland, to more of feeling of just well-stocked desert and then ends with more of techy and resistance feel.The bad thing is ending. If you played enough id games then you will be smart not to expect epilogues. And then many games have some "you are awsome" ending, teaching players to appericate journey, not the ending. But then this time they forgot to put final boss or any climax battle in. You just got this cool gun that can shoot BFG rounds and you just derp through weak enemies. Still, not a huge flaw.As for gameplay, it's a classic id shooter. Well, in modern linear level design, where you have one path and any other path is usually filled with knee-tall trash that you can't get over. But the shooting and action itself is great fun. Do people still consider having 9 weapons at same time as old-school?Weapons can use different kidn of ammo types. Like shocking water with elector-bolts. Or beating the hell out of heavy armor guys by loading your pistol with Fat Mammas.And you have a few items you can use, most notably explosive RC cars, placing turrets and using wingstick. Wingsticks is a boomerang that homes at enemy, is strong and can even return succesfully. It's Rage's title weapon, so to say. Shame that whether it breaks or returns seem to be based around randomness than skill.Animations of enemies makes it feel like proper FPS too and not some RPG, with them getting wounded while running, falling onto ground and shooting at you from there. It's mostly hitscan-abuse type of game, but at least regenerating health keeps it sane. And defib, where you can still revive after death. Most common enemies are melee ones that rush you straight or ranged ones that hide behind cover. What is great is that later they take more hits than your average modern FPS cannon fodder and can maneuver around, while giving a look of intellegent enemies by communicating, making it dynamic. It also helps that each clan is a bit unique, like Shadow clan has bandits that are more acrobatic.I once got sneakily killed from shotgun from behind, so it's cool.Racing/Driving part takes a secondary place sadly. It delivers finely, in that you can drive between missions in a hub world or do a racing. Boosting, minigun and rocket-launching and all that. It has arcade physics and feel to it, aside from having to purchase ammo. But it doesn't have much aside from shooting rockets at enemy. And racing events don't have many tracks and don't seem to be too crazy, they just kinda get repetetive after a while. It still a good part with explosions and ramming, just not deep. If they had some physics rampage and destroyable objects, then at least it could be as "aw yeah" as Flatout games.You also get some open-world stuff that are very few towns. Where you can grab some quests of racing. Or play some not interesting mini-games. Cards one is kinda cool. Or you can take a job quest, which is mostly redoing the beaten levels. Still cool lively locations, but don't put focus on them. Don't forget to purchase some ammo and ingridients. Game has too many ammo for few weapons to be survival, but very few for stuff like Sniper Rifle. Oh, and you can craft. This game also gives a bit of survival feel by making you scavenge, picking various trash in missions to sell it later.Main issue with it is that it doesn't manage to mix FPS and Driving well. Those are kept separately. Hub and races for cars, missions and towns for on-foot. Which may be good, as FPS people have to beat only 2 mandatory races. But still, could make it more interesting this way.Oh, and music provides background for action and varied but nothing to remember. And there were like, two bosses.But overall, if you come here for your linear id Software FPS with a bit of racing and not some Fallout or Borderlands, then you will have fun there. Hub world with linear missions are still good games.

content:
ry 17, 2014
												I am really baffled by how much Id missed the mark on this. Aside from the blatant copying of Fallout and Borderlands, the game doesn't really do much to peak any interest in the post-apocalyptic-FPS-barren-wasteland-desert-survival games. Like, Doom and Quake, Rage just continues to throw enemies at you as you trek through the same areas over and over (and sometimes backwards). Yes other games make you return to the same areas (Borderlands) but Rage's linear single hallway design makes it tiresome. The racing feels so out of place and the in-game economy is very broken. Yes it's pretty when you're looking at stuff far away, but when you're close it's really gross. No wonder Carmack left Id.

content:
r 16, 2014
												This one's a mixed bag for me. For one, the story is pretty good, considering the usual stuff we get in FPS at least. It's interesting, well written and it's got good dialouge. Just don't expect Metal Gear levels of depth and you'll be fine. Gameplay-wise it's also on the good side, with varying locations and enemy types as well as good boss battles. Don't go in expecting this to be fallout though, as much as it is "open world", the world is fairly small with not a lot to do in it, compared to other open world games.The AI is servicable if predictable, they will however react to getting shot in different ways depending on where you shoot them (yes, that includes groin-shots). Overall, pretty good again. This game also has a fairly big focus on verhicles and racing aswell as vehicular combat.What kills it for me is the port. The mouse acceleration and -smoothing is oh so very strong with this one, and you need to dig in the config files to get rid of it. And trust me, just setting mouse sensetivity to zero doesn't help. The performance is equally bad. Even on my GTX 760 I can't play this game on any higher than medium setting without having the framerate go lower than 30. And the texture pop-in is massive, it can take take multiple seconds to load texture if you turn.Conclusion: I'd recommend this game for anyone who was gonna use a controller anyways or is willing to fix stuff themselves. I've had my fun with it (~20 to get through with the campaign and some of the sidestuff) and don't regret the purchase.

number of helpful: 12 of 21 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
r 26, 2015
												Rage is an interesting game considering its pedigree. It was a game that was released too late. Allow me to explain.Rage had many features that were standard in the industry by the time it was released, which made the game feel like it was either behind the times or just not developed with enough substance. I felt it impossible to not compare it to other games that were released in the same time frame and felt that it brought little unqiue gameplay mechanics to the table. The tropes of older games are also present such as bountiful backtracking, red shirt enemies and linear layouts disguised as open world.Had this game came out a few years earlier I think I would have received it better, but the entire time I was playing the game, it reminded me of something better I had already played. So take my "Not recommended" with a gain of salt.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
24, 2014
												Gaphical Fidelity: ID outdid themselved with the visuals of this game. The texture qualities themselves may not be astounding. But the vastness of the world and details of each individual component make it quite a breath-taking sight. For me, it is still one of the most visually appealing games i've played. The artstyle is damn impressive.Performance: As much as i'd like to say all good things about this game. The texture popping is something that was an issue on release, and still has not been properly patched till this day. It's not a major issue, and not too noticeable on my computer rig, but it doesn't exactly make ID look like they put a lot of time into fixing the game.Design: I love the character and map design. Each enemy type has so many different variations, it doesn't feel too repetetive when fighting them. Plus the characters you talk to are each unique and memorable in their own way, wether it be serious and rought around the edges, or kind of goofy.RPG Aspects: This is something that kind of looks like it was shoved in last second. Don't get me wrong, it works, but it feels unfinished. You don't have any stats you can mess around with for your character. The clothing you wear is picked out of 3 different variations near the beginning of the game, meaning not a lot of variety. There are basic upgrades for armour, and for your individual weapons, but they are very basic. The coolest part would probably be the item crafting. Even though it is quite simple. It makes you go looking for the unique parts required to make certain items, such as the explosive RC cars, lock drills, bandages, etc.Story: Honestly, story could have been better. It sets the tone quite early on and I quite liked how it began, but without spoiling anything, the ending was a bummer and quite of left you hanging. Plus, you can't continue playing after the campaign to explore which I thought was silly. The ending really allowed for it...Voice Acting: Voice acting was fantastic, I don't have any issues with it. Frankly they had me at John Goodman.AI: The enemies AI was frankly one of the best parts of the game. They aren't your typical baddies that just stand there or rush directly at you. They were far cleverer than I expected. I found that enemies with melee weapons would duck and weave to avoid your shots, plus jumping, rolling and climbing to make them quite adept at reaching you without being hit. Any with ranged weapons wouldn't just stand there, but use cover wisely. Retreat if you were bearing down hard on them, advance if they found they had an advantage. Not just that, sometimes they would work together; for instance, the Authority had units that defended with a energy shield, and other units would hide behind him for protection.Weapons: The weapon design was quite good, but what made the guns so much fun to use, is their sounds, kickback, and also the phsyics implemented when an enemy was downed. If you shot an enemy in the head, their helmet would fall off, shoot them in the leg, they'll limp or topple over. Hit them with a shotgun, they'd go barreling through the air. As a FPS, I absolutely approve, and found the shooting aspect solid.____________________Presentation: 7 (Clearly high production, but story was weak and not all the characters were that memorable)Graphics: 7.5 (I would of given this a higher rating if the texture popping issue was fixed)Sound: 8.5 (Sound was overall impressive, especially on the weapons. Plus voice acting was above par most of the time)Gameplay: 8 (Excellent shooting sequences, but I did find the car comabt kind of tedious)Overall: 8 (A large amount of content for Single player, but only about 7-8 hours for the campaign. Does include co-op missions and a car combat competetive mode which is nice)

content:
14, 2014
												Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II is a truly amazing game. From the realistic breast physics to the immersive slap noises that occur during biker segments, it is truly a game worthy of praise. You begin as a Sonic looking for his parents who were killed by Batman during the Great Depression. As the game progresses, you learn more about Batman, coming to the conclusion that he is actually a carton of Mtn. Dew in disguise. It's a great message to send the new generation, informing them that caffinated drinks are the root of all evil.Following the events of Batman's unmasking, Sonic suddenly realizes what his true purpose is, and transforms into Mario because Nintendo is better than Sega. EA drops from the sky and challenges you to a fight before immediately decomposing into a pile of ♥♥♥♥-covered money. After wading through the ♥♥♥♥ and avoiding flying ♥♥♥♥-covered money, you finally find and confront Batman, killing him because Superman will always win.Mario then re-transforms back into Sonic before succumbing to his wounds, stating the core message of the game - that I've never played it.

												The last game directed by John Carmack before he left id Software.  The game between beginning to end has very enjoyable gameplay, variety of environments, a nice sense of an open world environment, excellent presentation but lacks the explosive ending or "boss" that most were expecting from a id Software game towards the end. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 25, 2013
												Amazing game! Great gameplay, stunning visuals and interesting characters. This game just has the full package! The story sets in a post-war, apocalyptic world, and the visuals could not be better. From the landscapes to the tiny details, everything looks great with a unique art style that reminds borderlands. The gameplay is probably the strongest point in Rage, and it was probably the main focus of the producers. And what a great job they did! I was actually searching for a FPS that suited my gameplay style, and Rage just hit the spot. It has loads of guns, some of them pretty creative, lots of different ammo for each weapon, turrets, RC bomb cars, you name it. It has diferent enemies too, which requires you to play a different style against each one, and has some fun bosses too. The roaming areas are open world, while the shooting areas are narrow spaces, clearly telling you where to go (despite sometimes I get lost for a moment, but that's becaus I like to search every bit of floor searching foor goods :P). This game also has a car racing component, which is not bad at all. you can roam in the open world by car (or other ground vehicles) and you can race with them. The driving is quite arcade, keeping it simple, but is well balanced, nevertheless. The vehicles also have diferent weapons to shoot the other vehicles, so there's that. The characters in this game are rich and well done, and despite of what they say to you won't be crucial information, you just want to listen to them, because of how interesting they are.The only downside in my opinion is the story. While it promisses a good story at the start,  the story simply doesn't develop too much, wasting all the potential it had. This game also has some few frequent minor bugs related to the image, like showing the desktop for a fraction of a second (nothing to worry about). Overall, a really great game for people who just want to have a nice session of shooting, repeating their favorite missions on the highest difficulties (and they are challenging) and dont care that much about the story. Highly recomend it! :)

content:
er 26, 2013
												The last game directed by John Carmack before he left id Software.  The game between beginning to end has very enjoyable gameplay, variety of environments, a nice sense of an open world environment, excellent presentation but lacks the explosive ending or "boss" that most were expecting from a id Software game towards the end.  Vehicles have a nice sense of weight and momentum but lacks vehicle selection, and upgrades.  The vehicle combat is excellent especially in arenas which are started in the few cities layed out in the game.  Overall 7/10+ Excellent graphics and good optimization for PC+ Enemy animation and gunplay+ vehicle physics and gameplay+ Excellent controls with gamepad- ending was very disappointing- lack of weapon variety- invisible walls take away from the sense of exploration- (from the - above) feels very linear- final enemy environment feels unexciting

												Very fun yet very basic shooter. That said, I'm enjoying it a lot. Is very classic, for example, you really don't need to use the aim button as in CoD to be accurate, since in normal view you already have almost perfect accuracy. Also is very old school in the sense that you can carry a bunch of weapons with you, and not just 2. The scenario is great I must say, incredibly beautiful and full of detail, so if you're looking for shooting in cool futuristic environments with lots of weapons and also do some fast speed driving, this game is definitely for you.In the technical side, for me works almost perfectly maxed out. I still do see some texture pop up in my face, but is not that bad, and the delay is less than half a second. But if you have AMD beaware and read other reviews first.My specs:Laptop Samsung 7 Series NP700Z7CCore i7 3615qm at 2.3 Ghz8 Gb of Ram1 TB of disk at 5400 rpmGeForce GT 650m with 2 GBs of GDDR5

content:
er 6, 2014
												Honestly, after hours invested; I found myself seeing the whole exercise as pointless. As with many games, there just wasn't enough to keep this first person shooter fan attached after the first few hours. Yah the world is expansive to a limit, but the bad guys were just other AI that seemed to be interested in my doom for no reason other than to keep the game going. It has all the right parts but it is assembled in a way that does not exemplify the genre. I guess my age is showing here; kids would undoubtedly drive around the world forcing conflict for days I am sure. The initial part of the game was interesting but had an odd pace and oddly placed out-takes. I played this game a while ago so if they have changed it or added to the format in some way then it might be worth another replay but I will not invest my money or valuable time in it again. I do not dislike the game, it simply did not fit my expextations. As for other shooters, I will not speculate - play it and find out for yourself.
