content:
er 2, 2013
												RAGE is one of those games that I love to hate. I frequently find myself wanting to punch my screen, and continue on at the same time.I started this game on Ultra Nightmare difficulty because I am somewhat of a masochist. I held my own after learning the mutants attack patterns, and figured I could progess slowly through the game using a decent plan of attack and ammo conservation. I quickly realized that not only would I never finish a Bash TV episode without a hypochondriac's collection of bandages, but I also could not win a race that involved a time clock. I spent the entirety of my UN attempt broke and without ammo in my guns and my car. I was basically reloading the same pathetic attempts to "luck out" without pulling my hair out of my scalp.After 20 plus hours of this anxiety attack inducing frustration I dialed it down to Nightmare and have been progressing at a steady rate. I am totally addicted to the game when it comes to fps combat and enemy commentary. I find myself giggling as much the last time I heard "Hey he killed what's-his-name!" as I did the first. I have found most of the weapons have a direct purpose at least once, and the art style is somewhat of a favorite of mine.The downsides I have noticed as a current player of at least mediocre knowledge of the game would definitely include the racing controls and overall uselessness of most weapons in the game. I am not using a gamepad so maybe that contributes to my problem, but it seems like the more I upgrade my cars the worse they perform. Every situation I use the car in (combat races, open world, time trial, etc) the car seems to perform differently. I assume there is some form of scaling invovled in different scenarios, but I don't know if that's true. Either way it keeps me from grasping a familiarity with the vehicle I have invested in, and takes away from the overall level of enjoyment when it comes to racing. Once I have the story mode racing achievements finished I'll probably avoid it all together on future playthroughs.The weapon selection is farily decent for a standard single player game of this kind. The problem for me is that even on Nightmare (and Ultra Nightmare for a short time) I find myself using four guns. Two of them for all average encounters and two of them for special ones. I used standard buckshot in the shotgun and steel tipped bolts in the crossbow in every fight I find myself in. Crossbow is for human combat, and the shotgun is for mutant combat. I never bother with anything else leaving most of my weapons forever ammo capped. In circumstances out of the norm I use the double barrel shotgun (Anarchy DLC ftw) armed with Pop Rockets, and the pistol armed with Fat Mamas or Killstrikes. The double barrel with Pop Rockets takes down any large scale boss or DLC related special mutants in seconds, and the pistol with said custom ammo destroys armored humans in a similar fashion after I shoot off their helmet using the crossbow. Perhaps my experience will change once I reach the end of the story and battle the Authority, but that has yet to be discovered. I find the automatic rifles to be ammo dumps that destroy my accuracy overall, and even with armor piercing rounds just feel totally underwhelming. The nailgun fits into that category as well, and I haven't used it since I finished the achievements related to it. I know its ammo is retrieveable (rebar only), but so are crossbow bolts that don't take 4 seconds to reload.The crafting system is keeping me interested until I have all the schematics aquired. I mostly only use it for turrets (still trying to kill 5 enemies for the Steam achievement and will probably have to do this on normal difficulty) and lock grinders for obvious reasons. I only spend four more dollars on bandages if I just buy them compared to buying the pieces (Crimson Elite armor from Anarchy DLC ftw) and after earning $40,000 at the poker machine 4 bucks just isn't all that much compared to crafting time. So basically the best part of this system is crafting my pistol ammo. Kudos for putting a crafting system in, but 90 percent of the time I'll just skip it.Multiplayer in RAGE seems like an afterthought. I generally don't get too invovled in fps multiplayer modes due to general lack of interest, but in RAGE the coop was very fun for a few days. The voice chat feature worked great and saved me from needing to be on my Mumble client. My friend and I cleared everything on both difficulites except three missions. We never finished the Bash TV episodes on Nightmare (good God), and due to an end level glitch we could not finish Grab and Go on Nightmare.Also, where are all the people for the races? Even on the f2p weekend I saw no one on it. We sat for quite a while and I tried solo que a few times with no luck. Two Steam achievements I won't get unless I get two more people on my friends list who have the game and we just que up with four of us. C'mon now...so many in game badges based on the multiplayer races and no one is attempting it? Requiring four people before I can even launch the race keeps us forever alone. Seems like a waste to me, but then again maybe I just missed the golden era for this games racing mode.After almost 40 hours in my playthrough (I take my time and try not to miss anything...the first playthrough is the most important to me) I already know I will at some point play this through again. Most likely on Ultra for the achievement and normal to clean up any missed achievements after that. This game offers much more than some folks would have you believe as long as you can get past the occasional pop in and fairly standard story line. I would definitely invest in future DLC or anytihng related to this game.

content:
7, 2013
												Pretty good FPS. Great mechanics and graphics. Ending could have been better as far as the "boss fight" goes.One day, you wake up from your capsule and saved by a local from the bandits. You make your way through the main quest, which is mostly linear, by travelling with various vehicles. The game has fantastic gameplay, graphics, and a decent story. The ending was largely disappointing though. I knew that the final mission was the final mission, but the ending was still very sudden and not as difficult as other "boss" fights. I mean, at one point, you fight a giant monster with just rocket launchers and only have a small room to navigate through, while the giant monster is outisde a gaping hole in the wall. The game certainly has its "wow" moments, and there are neat side things to do, like racing and delivery quests, but the main story could have used a little bit of work.The setting is fantastic though, the world design is great for the coloring and character. It's semi open world, as in you could explore the every corner, but the main missions are the priority. After a while, you go to a different area and you can tell how vastly destroyed and different it is in the color pallets, it's clear that id games put a lot of work in the design.8.9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
9, 2015
												This is a spoilerfree review of the entire game played in singeplayer at pretty much 100% on normal difficulty. This was fun, there is many titles out there that do many things better, but this still was a nice enough game. The post-apocalyptic setting justifies for some mindless shoot people action. The game would have been a lot better as a cover-based shooter. The way it is you basically guess if cover is high enough not to get shot. The quests arent very memorable. Its pretty muh always "shoot enemy type x do thing a come back" While the characters did have a lot of personality none of them where very memorable. There is a small variety of minigames and sidestuff to do, play a cardgame, make cool jumps, participate in a race, allthough that one can become important since you get to most places via car and races are pretty much the only way to earn points to upgrade your car.  The weapons arent anything special either. Shotgun, crossbow, 2 types of machinegun, pistol (seriously who uses that thing once you get the other qeapons?) sniper rifle, rocket launcher and later minigun, some of them with multple types of ammunition. What it boils down to though is that you either use the shotgun or the sniper rifle. The only reason to not use the sniper rifle is if melee enemys are rushing towards you. Seriously, why bother with rocketlaunchers when a few good sniper shoots to the head kill any boss just as well? The crossbow is for a stealth approach in theory, but this suffers from 2 problems: Half of the time the enemies are already waiting for you and later on in the game the crossbow doesnt oneshot anymore, therefor rendering it useless for stealth. You can also craft some cool items, like an explosive RC car, a spiderlike killer robot (just like the sniper you need not bother with anything else once it is upgraded) and others. The races are all managable but require multiple tries sometimes. The story itself is nothing you havent seen or heard of before and mainly serves to connect one place you shoot people at with other places you shoot people at. The soundtrack gets the job done, particularly since its drowned in gunfire half the time anyway. The only soundtrack that stands out is the credit song (that I think is also the theme song? I dont know I always started the game before it had a chance to start playing)There are two main weaknesses: 1: a lack of maps. Half the time a map would have been really really helpful. Particularly in areas like the city where it at least took me a while to finally figure out where everything was leading to frustrated running in circles. The missions themself are so linear and leave so little room for exploration that a missing map usually isnt a problem though. 2; That ending. As I said spoilerfree so here is the main problem: There is a huge buildup. You get the freaking minigun and the special "BFG-Ammo" with it. Sounds like a hell of a fight doesnt it? I even used up all the money I had left on ammo and bandages (health potions). What actually happens is that you gun done a couple of goons and boom done. Not even a boss. I dont even know what the BFG ammo looks like because I saved it up for something epic. Im not even saying that I think the story should have gone on more, just a boss even if its a little one, would have been very nice. The goons you gun down arent even all that hard to beat, I used a total of 1 bandage. The game had many harder sections than this.Still I recomend this game. Why? Because its fun. It is fun running face to face towards the enemy and pumping a shotgun round in their heads to watch them flying. It is fun picking them off one by one with the sniper. It is fun running around wreaking havoc in your car. At least it is to me. I dont think this game should have been much longer though because the fighting is growing rather stale over time.

number of helpful: 29 of 55 people (53%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
14, 2015
												===Note: The Steam Review Police are trying to keep me down and limit my text, so like half of this review is in the comments===4 years ago, I purchased RAGE. It was $30, and this was back when a game dropping to $30 within the year of its release was a deal of a lifetime and not an everyday occurrence on GMG, so I thought it was a great deal. I had heard the horror stories of its launch regarding things like ATI and general pop-in issues, but I figured enough time had passed that those bugs had been worked out. And they had, for the most part, but that wasn't why RAGE became one of my most regretted purchases on Steam. But instead of reviewing the game as I remember it, I decided to replay it just to articulate everything that I found wrong with RAGE.First off, if you have two or more monitors and your primary isn't on the left, RAGE is going to default to try launching on your left monitor. It doesn't matter how big or small it is, or if it's set as your primary monitor (which is what most sensible games launch to); it's going to make it fit until you get in and tell it not to. The engine is also locked at 60 FPS, so if you're like me and have a nice 144 hz monitor and want to get the most of it then you should go somewhere else. But enough technical nitpicking - what about the game?Well first off, I should mention the graphics, because it's obligatory that whenever someone mentions RAGE they have to talk about the graphics because that's the only memorable thing in this game. I could sit here and laugh at how bad the texture pop-in is, or how low resolution the textures are for hours, but I actually can't because I hit the text limit that I didn't know steam reviews had, so instead I'm just going to just leave you these videos I recorded throughout the last few days, and screenshots to accompany them, so you can laugh at them yourself. Just let me know when you're done so I can continue - they're compressed to 720p, but they still demonstrate the effects enough. These are all recorded and screenshotted on a GTX 970 with an i5 3570k overclocked to 4.4 GHz.http://puu.sh/jvyNH/9ed9b1eb9f.mp4http://puu.sh/jvOqm/6589f38244.mp4


megatextures 1 
A Screenshot of RAGE
By: Communist "Joseph Ballin" Layton







megatextures 2 
A Screenshot of RAGE
By: Communist "Joseph Ballin" Layton







Megatextures 3 
A Screenshot of RAGE
By: Communist "Joseph Ballin" Layton




http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=499374777http://imgur.com/a/Qmc3xSee, the thing about RAGE's graphics is that they look great when you're outside, but the game's interiors pretty much universally look like garbage from a game from 2004. Of particular note is that the game has no dynamic lighting that I could see, so instead of giving you a flashlight or something they just made all the darkness the color green, which just makes it look even uglier. Thankfully, this also has the unexpected side effect of making the pop-in not very noticeable, because even if the textures haven't popped in at all you won't be able to tell if it's using placeholders or if that's just how the game looks. What you will notice, however, is how barren the world feels. The items that can be picked up have a noticeable contrast in texture quality with the rest of the world, and since RAGE is a game where you're expected to search every nook and cranny to find said objects, there's no excuse for said nooks and crannies to look so completely awful. Nothing else in any given level can generally be interacted with - you can't break bottles, you can't push chairs, you get the idea; it feels like the entire map is just one big model that you're moving through, and combined with the total lack of any dynamic lighting it makes the interior environments feel extremely dull. Oh, but what's that you say? You want to know about the wasteland itself? The one you've seen so many beautiful scenic screenshots about? Well, the problem is that those are just that - they're scenic wastelands that you drive through, take a screenshot of, and drive past. And that's a good thing, because even if you're outside and you get too close to a rock, or look down, the graphics just don't hold up. Now, regarding the pop-in demonstrated above there is a config that you can put in your launch options to remove it (supposedly, that is - I didn't try it, since I wanted the "full RAGE experience"). The catch? It requires a GPU with at least 3 GB of VRAM. For a game in 2011, this is unacceptable. For a game that looks like it was made in 2004, this is laughable. But with all that, the graphics aren't even the real flaw of RAGE. As I said before, the interiors of the game are generally extremely ugly and bland. But while you might think that doesn't matter because of how much you've heard about the wasteland, the fact is that about 80% of the game takes place in those ugly interiors. For all you've heard about the wasteland overworld, it's essentially one big kodak moment, made for you to take a screenshot of on your way to the next interior. The wasteland is essentially just a big race track from one place to another, and you'll notice that feeling if you decide to play it. RAGE, despite its appearance, is an extremely linear game. Every  area in the game is either blocked off or locked until it's time to go there in a story mission, and half the time once you finish in said area, it locks off again, meaning there's plenty of missable content to be had because that's what gamers want in modern games. They don't even do a particularly good job of blocking the areas off - sometimes paths are just obstructed by almost waist-high blockades that you just can't jump over. Like these.http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=497667786http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=497667076Furthering the linearity is that you aren't allowed to pick up weapons from the ground until you're at the point where you're "supposed" to obtain a particular weapon, even if it's a weapon that you do find later on. I can understand why we can't pick up a fallen enemy's assault rifle which is visually different from any of the ones you obtain. I can't understand why I can't pick up this shotgun, which was lying beside the person I killed.http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=497668166Except while I don't understand it, I do know exactly why I couldn't pick it up - it was because that person was in the area where I was doing a side quest that was all but forced into my hands. The reward for the quest in question was a combat shotgun - not that exact combat shotgun, but the same combat shotgun, except it was blessed with the almighty quest reward status. That's the extent of the linearity of this game.So what about the actual levels, then? What are they like? Well, for the most part they're pretty much just the winding linear corridors you would expect from a standard-fare FPS. There are little bits and bobs that you can pick up to craft doodads and then immediately forget about, and every now and then there will be a neat secret that references Wolfenstein or Quake or something else to remind you that you could be playing a game where you can actually have fun right now. Each level involves running to the other end, grabbing the thing that the person who gave you the quest wanted you to grab, and then leaving through the new convenient exit that wasn't accessible from the beginning. Then if you're feeling really dangerous, you can go to the "sidequest board" and get a "sidequest", which basically involves going back through that exit, going back through the same level backwards, and grabbing another thing for some other person. One or two of the "sidequests" are particularly risky and try to break the mold and put you in a little cage and have you snipe mutants while defending a bunch of idiots. ===CONTINUED IN THE COMMENTS===

												The game is quite scenic and has a lot of character. The NPCs are interesting. Combat, economy, side quests, etc. all good. I made it as far as Wellspring, where I needed to get guns for my buggy to continue the storyline, and getting guns required me to win races with said buggy. This is where I hit a wall, literally and figuratively. The driving pretty much put an end to the game for me. At first with the keyboard, I did pretty well with the ATV, but the buggy was absolute crap. I tried my Logitech joystick, which has given me many hours of driving enjoyment... well, I had to use joy2key to make it work. And, again, driving the buggy was crap. I spent as much time in reverse to extricate myself from an obstacle as I did in forward. So I pulled out a controller. Again, driving the buggy was just not driving well (slightly better than the joystick). Additionally, the controller is just not comfortable because I haven't really used one much since the Atari 2600 days.

												If you are a looking for a postapolyptic fast 'n' solid id Software First Person Shooter combined with entertaining car combat races (like in Mad Max or Death Race) and a whiff of RPG-elements like crafting, RAGE could be worth a look.Don't expect a Borderlands or even an open world Fallout 3 - There is a lot of wasted potential, the story is thin and the id Tech 5 Engine is not well optimized:There are annoying texture popups and ugly environment textures (but awesome character textures...). er 7, 2015
												This game is smooth, which is as it should be with any game coming from Carmack. I was very impressed with the game's technical execution, BUT the substance of the game is lacking, unfortunately. At the time of my playthrough, I believe I had already played tons of hours in Borderlands, which I had also already beaten, so it really felt like a clone of that experience. RAGE definitely has more in-your-face moments than the aforementioned game, which I would characterize as one of the main drawbacks of Borderlands seeing as I could defeat just about any outpost by utilizing ranged (sniping) tactics. RAGE, on the other hand,has more realistic graphics, which comes as a plus basically because there were more visual "WOW" moments over BL. But at the gameplay level, which boils down to movement and shooting accuracy, the two games are virtually identical. Also, I completed RAGE much quicker then BL, why I'm not entirely sure.. maybe because I was used to the gameplay style via BL, or maybe it was somewhat less challenging seeing that most of the encounters were close-up, trying to surprise me -- which was a lesson previously taught by Doom 3 by the way. Overall, I would have to not recommend this game if you have played Borderlands, which came out before this, so...y'know. Otherwise, I give it my full recommendation.

content:
1, 2014
												Rage is a game from Id Software, one of the most iconic game developers of all time; Id is responsible for classics like Doom, Wolfenstein and Quake, and are a household name amongst the gaming community. Rage was pretty highly anticipated before its release, and the game itself created a pretty divisive fanbase.Rage is set in a post-apocalyptic wasteland as a result of a meteorite collision with Earth. This makes for an environment made up of rocky canyons, dusty valleys and dark caves. This setting has been done quite a few times before, but the various gameplay mechanics and impressive use of visuals means that the world is rather nice to explore.You navigate a moderately open world, similar to the first Borderlands. Using a wide array of guns with various ammo types, you'll collect quests from a hub, find the location in the world, complete the quest; rinse and repeat. The missions don't really have much variety as you'll often be completing the same tasks, consisting of killing mutants and bandits to get some item or pickup. Despite this however, the game will make up for it with some surprisingly solid shooting, and enjoyable racing mechanics.The variety of guns definitely works in the game's favour. There are revolvers, assault rifles, shotguns, bazookas, plasma rifles, wingsticks, remote-control bomb cars, grenades, crossbows and sniper rifles. Not many games give you this many guns and I commend the game for doing so. The shooting itself is quite tight and responsive, with all of the weapons handling quite well. Enemy AI is also rather excellent; the enemies leap and sidestep around the levels to avoid your attacks, and it made the shooting really enjoyable and entertaining.The game's best asset is probably the racing. With different tracks and game modes, Rage allows you to use modified racing cars to face off against other foes from around the wasteland. You can upgrade your cars with missles and machine guns, and this made for genuinely interesting moments of the game. The 'Mad Max' feel the game was obviously aiming for was really noticed her, and was one of the more addictive/memorable parts of the game.Rage is a fun experience due to the sharp visuals, polished shooting and awesome racing. With little to no story and unmemorable characters, it is difficult to get invested in this game. If you enjoy mindless shooting and racing with visual flair, Rage will probably satisfy you. 7 / 10

content:
13, 2014
												I was actually in rage when this game came out. It was full of glitches and id software released a game with barely any graphics options to choose from in the main menu. Websites popped-up around the net to provide advice as to how to change the graphics settings by modifying the game's cfg file. I hated this - this was not user friendly and also even to check small changes you needed to quit and relaunch the game again and again.After a while some patches were released and corrected these issues of the game. RAGE, by the way, has a very mediocre story and in my opinion Bethesda being the publisher here did not help the case. You are a survivor after an asteroid almost completely annihilates mankind. Just before the catastrophe a handful of people - scientists, soldiers and other high rank personnel - were frozen and put in a so-called ark that was taken below ground levels. Many years after the event you wake up as your ark automatically hits the surface. You realise everybody else from your team perished and you are the sole survivor. You are immediately attacked by mutants and then saved by a stranger. He takes you to his settlement and the game practically starts.There are several small towns where you can interact with a lot of people. There are dozens of side missions to complete and a couple of minigames, as well. So, as opposed to what we got used to in previous id software games RAGE now follows a non-linear path. Completing sidemissions earns you money which you can use to purchase new weapons or upgrades to your equipment. In addition to this there are races you can participate in. You have your own vehicle and beside the races you can use this to go from one town to the next. I liked how smoothly the developers completed this - transitioning from the FPS perspective to the camera-behind-the-car view happens smoothly. There are really no loading times; getting in and out of your vehicle happens fast.There are two things where RAGE shines, in my opinion:1) Art design: Some of the places you venture through look amazing. An example: You need to go to Dead City to acquire an object. You climb narrow steps in-between huge, collapsed multistorey buildings. You truly get the feeling of a post-apocalyptic setting here. You race in vast wastelands, go down to the sewers to eradicate mutants, participate in a mutant reality show, go through deadly caves in the Scorchers DLC etc. Textures could have been more of high quality nature, still, the game's art design compensates for this.2) Combat: I loved Doom and Quake for their weapons. And how good it was to eliminate waves of enemies. RAGE delivers the very same experience. Enemies hide behind cover and they react realistically: headshots do count and in case you shoot them in the leg they stumble and fall. Some run at you with clubs only and you think it is easy to get rid of them but you realise that you cannot hit them: they do somersault and jump on and off walls and drive you mad. Also, all weapons are valuable. Remember how quickly we stopped using a pistol in Doom? As the minigun used the same ammunition. Or simply because weapons obtained later on were more efficient. In RAGE each weapon has different ammunition types and some upgrades, as well. Believe it or not - the pistol is one of the strongest weapons in the hands of a good shooter. You can craft a very strong bullet that can easily eliminate bigger foes with some good aimed headshots.RAGE can remind gamers of old-school shooters. If you look at it like that you can enjoy this game from start to finish. I am not saying my expectations weren't higher for an id game but following my initial disappointment I gradually came to like this game. Although the story is mediocre and the game has a disappointing end and a short DLC, it is a highly recommended FPS game.

												Rage un juego que inesperadamente me ha sorprendido. Shooter, carreras, minijuegos de cartas, cuchillos, dados y el Bash TV concurso de televisión en donde tienes que ir superando hordas de mutantes. La ambientación post-apocalíptica, los efectos de sonido, los movimientos de los enemigos, las armas y sus variantes como diferentes municiones, el robot araña, los coches teledirigidos, la sensación de como te va envolviendo el juego, todo esto ha cumplido con creces mis expectativas del juego. Y por decir algo negativo pues mencionar que la última misión y como ha terminado la campaña no ha sido del todo muy sorprendente pero bueno todo lo demás compensa.

												Solid shooter, though you deal a lot with bullet-sponge enemies, or enemies of the same variant. Interface is very poorly designed for a mouse and keyboard. Very little difficulty curve, and the game more or less just dumps a ton of upgrades on you without even trying.Driving is okay, but is limited mostly to races which get boring very quickly. All the upgrades aren't really necessary for survival.Completed first playthrough focusing on side-quests and got 10 hours out of it. Bought it for $20, and would not recommend purchasing for anything more than that. Felt like iD was going for a very broad, Borderlands-esque shooter with about 30 hours of content, but ran out of time and shortened it considerably. The game ends when you feel like it just gets going.

 Get the game when it's on sale.  Honestly, the game does an incredible job of hyping itself up, and then dropping you like a sack of bricks. I remember playing this on PS3 years ago, marvelling at the beautiful visuals and the somewhat-unique post apocalyptic aesthetic of Rage. Of course, I never got farther than the Dead City, or else I would never have purchased it here. The massive mutant boss fight was the most fun, exhilarating part of the game. The rest is just new types of small fry to shoot at. The game, however, has excellent gameplay and I had a lot of fun shooting em all up, but the weapon switching system was just so clunky.  And the saddest part about the whole game, for me at least, was the utter lack of a real relationship with Sarah. She just sits in the "trophy room" as a sort of superficial "trophy" after the scorchers and never returns to the outside world ever again. "I don't want to go outside. I want to play video games with you!" Seriously, ID? SERIOUSLY?? AND THE ENDING. ARGHH the ending.

content:
ry 3, 2014
												Rage an example of an amazing corridor FPS(its an 'open world' filled with corridors and the 'open world is another huge corridor linking all the smaller corridors together), it offers a very different experience of corridor shooters, by giving me the choice to continue on with the story or to hang around doing side missions and races, many other linear games does not have this feature, they make you go on without giving you a break, thats why I didn't get bored playing this game.This game is a shiny gem among other linear games, theres some great weapons to use, and I mean it, every single weapon is unique, and each has different ammo types to apply. The game even employs a decent crafting system, u can craft some items like meds to heal or bombs and stuff like that to kill your enemies with different styles. There are few types of enemy in this game, mainly u kill anything that moves, make use of your weapons, there is so many approach to killing besides shooting.The graphics are beautiful from far, it's like a painting come alive, but up close its terrible, its so blurry that u can compare it to the graphics of the 1st Half-Life game. The driving is a bit off, it just doesnt seem real, banging a wall at full speed and u get a little knock back and thats it. I must say the ending fight is kinda lame, I saved a lot of bullets for the boss fight I imagined would be tough, but instead its just dissapointingly easy, its the lamest ♥♥♥♥ I've ever seen, they decided to keep the story hanging there, so there will be a sequel to this. I just hope they improve everything, this game has lots of potential but not enough content.Overall I think that it's definitely worth your time and your money, get it on a sale

6, 2016
												Please note that this review is a little biased, since I bought the game on sale for 5$, and for 5$ it is a damn near perfect. But I will try to judge it if I got it full priced. Rage is pretty much a odd wannabee post apocalyptic middle child. It seems to have broken into the house of Fallout and Mad Max, but didn't have enough time and only managed to steal a few things. It got the vehicle combat done quite well, and the enviroments look very stunning, even playing in 2016. Though combat gets a bit repetitive at times, the game can't seem to decide if it wants to be a run and gun, or a "next gen" cover based shooter. Though the guns feel new and fresh, it seems every enemy has a copious amount of health. But even through that, I played on the highest difficulty and only died twice thoughout my entire playthough, once when I got bombarted by 3 rocket launcher dudes, and once when I tested to see if you could exit your car mid jump. Unfortunately when Rage broke into Fallout's house it forgot to take the open world aspect, maybe its sneak wasnt high enough. Also if you buy this game, don't buy it for the plot, the plot is basically a really bad chinese knock off, diet, watered down version of Fallout 3. But buy it for being Mad Max with rocket lauchers strapped to your car. All together for 5$- 8/10Full priced- maybe 6/10Final note: you may of encountered spelling mistakes and gammaical errors in my review, I could say that english is not my frst language, but it is. I really couldnt give a Mel Gibson about it.  Final final note: I do have a bone to pick with the pick up noise. Every time you pick up a collectiable it makes the sound of gun cocking, and every single time I think there is a baddie behind me. I guess thats what cs does to you.

												Rage is an odd game.Don't get me wrong, it's pretty darned fun, but it feels unfinished, which is uncharacteristic of id.It looks gorgeous from a distance, but up close, the megatexture technology displays its weakness and ends up making every texture in the game look muddy.There's still that odd moment when turning where the engine takes a microsecond longer to render textures in your peripheral vision.For a world that invites exploration, it's remarkably linear, even down to your character not being able to jump over knee-high obstacles.And the abrupt ending is one of the worst in gaming.Still, the shooting and movement possess that unique id solidity, even down to strafe-jumping working like it does in Q3. And the character models and animation are sublime.

content:
er 2, 2013
												  RAGE is a unique experience in the post-apocolyptic genre. It's got gunfights! It's got scaveging/crafting!  It's got... Racing!  What it is, foremost, is a fast-paced FPS, and it does this quite well with a wide selection of weapons and enemies that make you work to put them down.  After the introduction you are left to explore or thrust yourself into the first quest.    "But I thought you said this is a FPS!"  It is, the story is driven in a nonlinear-linear fashion.  Which I thought was a brilliant way to let me decide how I want to play the game.  When I'm not busy running for cover, deciding what weapon (of which there is a plethora of options if you take into consideration the different ammos available for wach gun) would be most effective in the current combat situation, or scavenging for items, I found myself appreciating the the work put into making each location truely unique and beautiful.  It was refreshing to be emmersed in a post-apocolyptic world that is desolate, and at the same time rich in color.  It's too bad that there are inconsistances that broke me out of the trance:      For some reason random areas of both the world and level maps would just not be accessable due to some invisible barrier.  "Why can I jump on top of this flaming trashcan but not the the short stack of tires right next to it!"    Found myself in the heat of a firefight and taking cover to change to a certain weapon/ammo selection.  The act of getting to the right type of ammo or crafting a few things would sometimes take longer then the battle.  "Let's take a five mutants/raiders/authority soldiers!  I'm not ready yet!"  Overall I found the game very fun and emmersive.  I suggest waiting for the game to go on sale to buy though.  It's a blast, but not $20 worth of fun.

content:
15, 2016
												There is a lot to like about this game.  A nice, vibrant post-apocalyptic world, even if it does have weird western and steampunk elements, nice guns that all feel different to use, have great animations and sounds.  The crafting system is simple, not tedius.  And the driving was just enough, not too much especially for someone who prefers shooters over drivers, so this didn't wear on me, which was nice.The basic plotline of a survivor of a near ELE brought awakening into a nightmarish world years after being put into cryo sleep is not unique, but works well enough.  The first part of the game is just doing odd jobs to get things.  Most of those odd jobs involve brutal murder, but hey, it's the world you're in, right?  Unfortunately, the plot is purely driven by the NPC's in the same mold as the Half-Life series, you never utter a single word, there are no cut scenes to drive plot.  So, effectively you have to take the word of these people you just met, that murdering 100s of people is the right thing to do.  Of course, everyone shoots on sight.  But when strangers are constantly conspiring to murder you, who wouldn't?The story goes down hill once The Resistance is brought into it.  Yes, another story with a Resistance, which is fighting against an evil, oppresive and technologically superior supressor power.  This trope is so over used, that it has lost all meaning.  What starts as an interesting survival in the post-apocalyptic wasteland soon becomes the same as every other resistance storyline ever done.  And whilst the gameplay is fun, the story lacks immersion and anything that you'll remember a day after completion.There is no explanation given as to how, in such a desloate landscape, such technology is freely available to the bad guys.  It just is.  There are some nice moments of horror in the game, going through Dead City especially.  Some good FPS battles, and each of the enemy types you come up against does have some nice and unique feel to them.  Mutants, the different bandit tribes, the Authority, The Gearheads etc.  They all look, fight and feel authentic, meaning that even though there is a lot of shoot XYZ, the combat never seems to drag.  It's rare that you end up fighting the same kind of foe more than 1 or 2 missions in a row.Ultimately, i thoroughly enjoyed this game, and even though i got it on special, i'd have been happy to pay full price.4/5

content:
24, 2014
												I recommend this game...but barely. I actually sort of got interested into trying it after playing through The New Order earlier this year, even though the games don't have a lot in common other than their engine...which most people don't care for. Anyways, figured I'd give one of id's only "recent" games a try. Rage doesn't know what it wants to be. I guess that's a common criticism so I'm not breaking new ground here. At a surface level, it looks reminiscent of Fallout 3, with a similar setting and even a rudimentary quest structure. However, this game is clearly an FPS and not an RPG. It also has vehicle traversal, even including racing and time trials. This wasn't what I was looking for going in, so outside of using the vehicles to go from objective to objective, it wasn't something I put a lot of time into. So I pretty much played this as a straight FPS, to the extent I could. I was instantly soured at the layout of the game. You are fairly readily given the ability to explore the Wasteland, which while not a sprawling overworld that you can really get lost in, it does have some size to it and I was happy to be able to simply roam around, look for enemies, get off and find places my vehicle couldn't go. It at first seemed like I had a fair bit of agency to do what I wanted. I found a little nook with a few enemies, eventually I found a body with a piece of clothing marked "Juno". How interesting. I then found a one-way shortcut to a radio tower of sorts that I couldn't get to before. "Oh, this is how to get here..." but I couldn't do anything. Later I go into an encampment and I'm told that I need to find out what happened to Juno, and also that I need to press a button on the tower or whatever. That's Rage. It's not the best setup.Rage is all about being told where to go, and after this first anecdote, I was never in a hurry to explore past where I was told to since having to revisit the area once under orders just seemed like no fun at all. So instantly, the game goes from initially coming across like a fairly open environment to one where you're shackled to where whatever the npcs want you to do. This isn't bad in itself, since many shooters are linear without much choice in direction, but it certainly makes beelining across the Wasteland on the the buggy following the objective dot to be far less engaging. To make matters worse, many of the game's sidequests, conveniently stashed onto a conspicuous notice board, just require you to revisit mission areas, and maybe traverse them backwards with a swapped enemy set. It's a little uninspired. There are a few sidequests that require you to converse with town npcs, but most come from the boards, which I've never really enjoyed that set up.The game performs well, outside of the infamous texture pop issue of the engine. I thought I was prepared after having played TNO but it's significantly worse here. Luckily the pc gaming wiki was able to provide a near-fix, but those first few minutes of getting out of the Arc were certainly an eyesore. The raw gameplay is solid, I love being about to hold all of the weapon types. The game starts out fairly modest with a pistol, a machine gun, a shotgun, grenades, etc. After 5 hours though you're given multiple weapon types with multiple ammo configurations, and even quick use items ranging from emp grenades to boomerang blade and rc cars. There's lot of options, and I found myself willing to change up my loadout just to get a feel for everything. The quick menu configuration I thought was a little clumsy, with having to access the f1-f4 keys and having all of the various items just be mapped to a single button. Changing weapons and ammo, however, felt very natural. There were also a fair variety of enemy types the made different weapon usage quite the necessity (even on normal mode). Mutants that charge you straight on were better taken out with the shotgun and quickblades, while gearheads and more typical enemy soldiers would be better engaged with scoped weapons or grenades. Throw in the later game enemies with armor and shields and it was never really boring until...the end. The ending is supremely lame. I suppose look it up if you haven't played it.The story is forgettable. You're just fetching stuff half the time. All in all, the game is enjoyable once you get a texture pop fix and get over the rather lame quest structure and mini games and racing, And deliveries and sidequests. So yeah, a lot of fat that could have been trimmed. I think the game could have been a lot more polished if it had a focused goal. I suppose that's a bit tautological but I guess I see this game as being pretty exemplary of having unneeded side systems. I thought the crafting items were interesting enough, even if I mostly made the ammo and lock grinders and grenades and ignored the various boosts and bandages. The gambling games and various money sinks like trading cards, however, just seemed unneeded. Luckily that gave me more dispoable income to just try out various ammo types and build crafting items I normally wouldn't have tried. It also meant I didn't have to put a lot of effort into money-gathering events like deliveries and the monster tv segments. I just wanted to shoot stuff, you know?

content:
er 17, 2015
												9/10 - no rage quitting here, you'll probably play this in one goRAGE is the reason I like the STEAM free weekends, because otherwise I would have never played and eventually bought this underrated jewel of a game.It's a mix of post-apocalyptic FPS, car wars and CCG (yeah thats right, RAGE includes an in-game collectible card game thats as fun as addictive). And on top you get to craft all kinds of useful stuff.Took me 40 hours to finish but I'm a slow player and had both the Scorcher and Sewers DLCs. An average player will probably spend about 15-20 hours on the base game and 30 tops on the whole package.++PROS+++ World design, characters design, weapons design, everything is original and great looking+ Engaging firefights in extremly varied locations where tactics count and cover is important(!)+ An AI that lives up to its name, from mutants running on the ceiling to soldiers throwing grenades to get you out of cover+ Original weapons like razor-boomerangs (that do return!) or RC bomb cars+ An ingame trading card game where you have to find/buy/kill for cards you use to construct decks which you play against NPCs for cash+ Car races&fights that are just complex enough to be fun but simple enough to enjoy even playing with mouse/kb+ A crafting system that has you hunt for scraps and recipes to craftt everything from ammo to small robots.+ Conversations are mostly voice acted and human(oid) enemies do a lot of trash talk during fights. VO quality is good and even the music is mostly enjoyable.--CONS--- Too less of everything. Places, npcs, quests, weapons, vehicles....had the game triple it's size, it could have become a contender for FO- Not exactly railroaded but far from open world, regions have to be unlocked and the longer the game goes the more often you drive along the same routes over and over again- The story starts out very good but somewhere in the last quarter it looses grip and logic and the "end" feels rushed and unfinished- Some boss fights can hardly be won by intuition, you will have to google the tactics once or twice- An autosave system you will have to get used to (it's not unfair though)If you decide to give RAGE a try, get the DLCs from the start - imo they are not much fun to play after the base game's end.

content:
er 23, 2015
												It would be a competent but forgettable shooter, but as much as I wanted to like RAGE, the id Tech 5 engine is atrocious.  Wolfenstein had many of these problems, but MachineGames did their best to utilize its strengths and cover its weaknesses.  Here, we get to see just how terrible the engine really is.As far as the game itself goes, it's your generic old-school/new-school mash-up game.  The gunplay is still satisfying, as you'd damn well expect from id, but there's just some clunkiness to it I can't put my finger on.  I suspect this also has to do with the engine, as when it isn't microstuttering and streaming 128x128 textures two feet away from me, I start enjoying it again.  I'm not even a graphics snob either, and it still gets to me with just how jarring and distracting the pop-in problems are.The game puts you in a post-apocalyptic world, where bandits are everywhere and you go around doing quests for different people.  You can also get some vehicles along the way, and carry four weapons at a time.  Sound familiar?  Correct, this game hits pretty close to Borderlands in its gameplay.  Sadly, Borderlands takes what it does and does it well, while RAGE focuses more on its slightly-decent gunplay, so it's more of a "Borderline" than anything.Let me go out and say, I f@#king hate the car physics.  They're just awful.  You've got turbo and a single handbrake that's way too efficient.  Your car is pretty much glued to the floor, the smallest pebble can stop your car altogether, and moving fast with boost only exaggerates the problems I stated before with pop-in.  I dread any and all cars in this game.On an Nvidia card, the game will be slightly more playable with GPU Transcode as a feature.  However, since they cashed out to Nvidia and decided AMD users (even with their own CUDA, "Stream") weren't worthy of a playable game, fellow AMD owners should avoid this steaming pile of sellout ♥♥♥♥ like the plague.  Even if you own an Nvidia card, the unoriginal story and only-decent gunplay still isn't worth full price.  id, I'm seriously disappointed.  How such a legendary studio could come up with an end result like this is honestly pathetic.  I'm sorry to say this, but RAGE is my first victim of the almighty Steam Refund.Also, a little texture compression would be nice.  If you're not even going to have these full textures appear in-game half the time, why do they need to take up 30GB I could be using for games with actual effort put into them?

content:
y 3, 2015
												A mixed bag.  What would have been state of the art in 2006 was dated and poorly designed on arrival in 2011 and is postivly archaic in today's market, but there is a charm to the mostly linear experience that is a hallmark of id software games.  The levels are interestingly laid out and look stunning from a distance, but the appalling "Megatexture" technology which just wasn't worth the time of day, and lazy placement of objects that feel very clearly placed to cheat you out of exploration do end up frustrating you a lot of the time.The first half of the game feels like it's building up to something interesting, but what feels like a severely truncated second half feels uneven, bland and much weaker than the first half.  Missed opportunities in the story, gameplay and design make this an overall failure, but one that for a few quid, is enjoyable enough to warrant playing through.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
4, 2015
What is rage, you may ask?  Let me answer that question of yours.The game is set in a post-apocalyptic future, where the civilization as we know it, has been destroyed by the asteroid 99942 Apophis in 2029. Survivors have created settlements and other habitable locations and have been divided into various clans and organizations of their own. Bandits and mutants constantly roam the world and try to salvage and destroy the settlements.The story is your basic, “save the world story”. I could not get into the story of this game, it did not draw me in with anything special. I found no connections to the players actions except saving the world, but you are not greeted with an explanation to why the protagonist do the things he does. The protagonist is a mystery, who just happens to emerge and wants to save the world. I guess that you do not need more information to why you save the world, but it is a detail I would like to see, as to why the protagonist to the choices he does.The protagonist, is an “Ark Survivor”. You emerge to the surface as the sole survivor from your Ark in 2135, and you are immediately thrown into the harsh world that is left. You are greeted by some bandits trying to salvage the wreckage of your ark, you are in an bad position as you lack weapons and equipment, but fear not because you are saved by a wasteland settler, who will teach you how the new world works. From here on it follows a linear story, where you do quest after quest which takes you further up in the world, and soon people will start to hear rumors of the “Ark Survivor”, and form here on the journey only gets harder as you try to save the world from its misery.It is not that I disliked the story itself, I just could not find myself caught in it. I just followed the quest, did what I was told, and not long into the game I started to forget the story itself. But fear not, the story may have been weak for me but there were many other things that weighted in for it.The gameplay itself is what lured me into this game, this is what kept me coming back to the game. It is very action based, with a lot of gun-play, and a few stealth mechanisms if you manage to pull them off.This action is where all the fun resides. You can find yourself stuck waist-down in a firefight, with grenades flying from both sides, until you emerge victorious or die trying. But you do not actually die, since the Ark suit that you wear through the game has a built in defibrillator, so when you are about to die you enter a second chance mode, where you can revive yourself with a percentage of health and take out the enemies around you.I found that the AI was very good, and they have some of the more interesting mechanics, comparing with other games. Bandits dodge your shoots by doing acrobats, tactically advance and fall back depending on their amount, their health and how much health I seem to have. Mutants however swarm the area around you and charge head in, towards you, and jumps around to confuse you.There are not so many different enemies. There are three main categories, Bandits, Mutants and Authority. Each of the three has a number of different subcategories, where you find a handful of changes like, different weapons and different armor, changes in movement and size. Sure there are only three main enemies, but with the subcategories and all the changes in between the enemies, you get a very dynamic feel towards what you are fighting. There are some bosses in the game, which are a nice asset. One is the huge of a ten story apartment and takes some time taking down until you learn the tricks, and another might just be a bandit in some bulky armor shooting rockets at you. I found the bosses to be a nice change from the regular creeps that are sent at you, and they offered a nice amount of challenge, to keep it hard and interesting.The enemies had some changes with weapons, but what do you get?  You get an arsenal of ten weapons if I am correct. At first I thought that this was not enough, that it became to repetitive running about with the weapons you had, but all of that changes soon enough, when I was introduced to different kinds of ammo and equipment. Some weapons got explosive ammo, some got electric, some even got mind-control ammo. There was so many joyful ways to take down your enemies that I had a hard time choosing which was my favorite. The game rewarded you with different types of equipment, your primary were regular grenades, but you also had EMP-grenades, wingsticks (A triple-bladed boomerang), RC cars and some other things that I did not pay so much attention to.There was a nice amount of side quests that you could do, from eliminate, protect, save, gather, races and delivery missions. They offered a nice variation to the linear and dull story, but there was one thing that blew away all of the side missions and that was BashTV, and arena where you could fight through some of the weirdest, immerse, amusing and engaging rooms filled with mutants of all sorts. I spent a lot of time in this arena, rampaging about with my weapons as I had to dodge enemies, spinning blades from the roof, spikes from the floor, you name it.A game cannot be perfect, while there was a lot of things that stimulated, but there were also some things were dull and for me destroyed the feeling of immersion. The first thing I have already mentioned, and that is the story. Then we have the world. From time to time the world appealed me, with how everything seemed to have adopted to the apocalyptic world, how the some areas felt unique. I found it to be way to empty from time to time, and I saw repeating patterns in how the enemy areas were made. There were no weather changes, which withdrew some of my immersion. I also felt like the textures on the environment were to low res from time to time, and badly made, compared to the weapons, characters and vehicles. I had some trouble with the rendering from time to time as well, seemed like the textures were not loading as they should. Other than the problem I had with the look of the textures and their rendering from time to time, the game looked good. It fitted the scene of an apocalyptic world as it was supposed to, sure there was the feeling of it being to empty at certain points, but what else is there to be expected from a game like this.The controls were completely fine, everything did as I wanted it to, when I wanted it. The only thing I disliked about controls was that the camera was locked when you were in a vehicle, I would have liked it to be move able so you could watch around more. but I managed to look past it and enjoy the game for what it was.The voices were well made, sometimes you got the feeling that some of the voices did not fit in at all, but it was quickly overlooked. The game had a nice soundtrack that kept the immersion in place, and made you feel like you were in the heat of the moment. Then we have the weapon sounds, I loved the sound of the weapons in this for some reason. To me they were very realistic, and the sound of someone blowing up or being electrocuted was amusing in so many ways, that it was close to disturbing.Conclusion:The game Rage, is a very fun game to play, if you are able to overlook the issues that I found. I enjoyed it once I overlooked the issues, and I played through the story in about 8-9 hours. For me this time was well spent, by blowing stuff to pieces, blasting them in the face with a shotgun or trying the stealthy approach with a crossbow. If you are a person that likes the action based games where it is a lot of shooting involved, and do not mind if the story is the weak part, f

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
1, 2015
												I feel this is a title that gets less attention than it deserves, so I figured Id farm up a steam task and do a lesser known game some due justice in the process...RAGE is a game developed by one of my favorite developers of all time: ID Software. Because of this, I have massive fanboy goggles on, and am aware of this fact, and now you are too. Keep this in mind, and so will I whilst writing this.My first impression when playing this game was extremely positive. The opening cinematic, while being incredibly simplistic, does wonders for this game's atmosphere and is just downright beautiful. You are placed into the game without being assaulted with exposition, and I like that, so long as I can get it at my own pace during play. Discovery is one my favorite aspects to any game. The Visuals in this game are fantastic, ID has always been ahead of the curve in the graphical department, and this game really had me drolling with its visi-porn. This game gave me a gamer erection right away, and it persisted for much longer than 4 hours. The meat of the gameplay consists of roaming what remains of civilization while both on foot and in a vehicle with the goal of surviving, learning about your own history, helping remaining survivors that want to help you, and obliterating everything that wants to eat you. Driving, shooting, and shooting while driving are what you do in this game: and those things are FUN. The gunplay is quite good because the weapons are fun, visceral, and ammo is customizable. Each meaningfully unique weapon has meaningfully unique ammo types, making it one of my favorite things about the entire game. Enemy AI being strong also helps make combat satisfying. Driving is fun because cars are customizable, badass looking, responsive, and responsible for lots of great vehicular manslaughter moments. I thought I would dislike the driving, as its main purpose is for what you'd thinks its for: going places. Thankfully, going places is actually fun, and it never takes a painful amount of time, even when you have kill people who get in your way when all you want to do is get to the mission location.Exploration in this game is done in a way unlike any Ive seen. The game is a linear game but manages to not feel like it, and rewards mucking around and looking behind buildings and rocks that you would never need go near in the first place. Random junk like wires and cans all have resale value, and some can even be used to make random gadgets and gizmos on the fly, most of which are there just so you can mess around with more ways to murderize your enemies. The 'Engineering' in this game doesnt feel like a way waste your time or gate your progress, it feels like something a wastes wanderer would actually do given his circumstances and is way more fun than something so mundane should even be. Making RC cars with bombs stuck on them to blow up enemies who arent aware of you is fun, and is just one of 1000 ways to kill your enemies. Enemy and location design is also very good. Some missions are much scarier than I thought they would be just because of the locale and enemies within. While everything has that "crumbly, abused, neglected, dirty, or repurposed" design that most post-apocolyptic games have, it still remains memorable to me even though its been awhile since ive played. Variation in the urban and natural areas keeps it not feeling all samey, at least most of the time. The story remains vague initially, which like I said before, is something I actually like. As you begin to discover and learn more and more, the game becomes truly engrossing, and had me invested fully, since it all felt as though I had discovered it, rather than it being rammed up my bum because I needed it to understand whats going on. Unfortunatley right during the biggest highs this game's story creates, the game ends unforgivably abrubtly. The sudden and supremely limp ending to the narrative and game as a whole is THE WORST IVE SEEN IN ANY GAME EVER. YES, EVEN WORSE THAN MASS EFFECT 3. Overall: The game succeeds at being a wasteland explorating, baddie smoking, vehicle smashing, scavenging and wrecking fun fest. I had a really great time with this one, and I recommend it to anybody who has liked any game where you pick up a gun and rearrange a guy's face with it. This game is very underrated and underplayed.GOOD:-GUN DESIGN-AMMO TYPES-VEHICULAR COMBAT/RACING-VISUAL QUALITY-ENGINEERING/SCAVENGING-ENEMY AI-F%$#ING STUFF UPACCEPTABLE:-ENEMY DESIGN-LEVEL DESIGN-NPCS-LORE-LEVEL NAVIGATIONBAD:-THE ENDING IS ATROCIOUS-A FEW SERIOUS BUGS

												I bought this game the day it came out for xbox 360 (My PC was 100% linux at that point)I played it all the way through and while it felt a bit short I loved every minute of it.I've since upgraded my PC's GPU, dual booted windows, bought it on steam (with the DLC) and am playing through it again.I'm finding it just as enjoyable as the first time I played it and I would like to see more games like it in the future.In my opinion, too many games recently have tried to add far too much content and forgotten to add the fun.These games start to feel like a chore to play and you end up never finishing them. Of course there are exceptions but I have far too many games I will probably never finish because they got boring.Sure RAGE doesn't have the best graphics (although that painted sky is beautiful) nor does it have the greatest storyline, however, it's the kind of game that's genuinly fun to play.The mechanics are fun (I especially like the wingsticks and deployable turrets) and who doesn't like blowing up a mutant with an explosive projectile fired from a massive shotgun? The missions are all slightly different and (at least for me) the game never feels stale or lacking in content.Once you've finished the main storyline and the missions from the jobs board there are always the sewers to clear and now the scorchers DLC which, while quite short, I found to be increadibly entertaining.I get bored very easily and so there are very few games I have played all the way through, let alone gone back to for a second play though. Rage however is one I just can't get enough of.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 28, 2011
												id Software, the inventors of the FPS genre, find themselves in a rough spot, these days. They leave the gameplay innovation to other developers. Doom 3 was already an 'old-school' retro game, when it came out. RAGE is a classic FPS in many ways. The weapons feel good. The enemies are popping up the same way as always. But the fidelity of the presentations is top notch. The animations are maybe the best you can find in new games & the levels are worth exploring, because id tried something new. They left the familiar ground and gave you loot and stuff to sell in shops. And they added a racing game in between the shooting levels, which is quite fun. You won't find pre-rendered textures. Instead, the lead programmer and mastermind John Carmack worked on his infamous "Megatextures", giving artists unprecedented freedoms to craft unique landscapes and levels without the usual restrictions. It's if 2D concept art would have come to life thx to virtual texturing. Worth seeing & playing, IMHO.

content:
y 1
												I can only comment on the single player campaign of the game and I did not buy the DLC 'The Scorchers'.- Game is from 2011 but graphics are fine in my eyes. Well, they are good enough that you also will notice that a lot of textures look low res when you come close, for me this was not a big problem, I had a very old display and system a few weeks ago. If you think a game like for example Skyrim looks bad then you may already be used to something different and please keep that in mind if you continue reading.I had very little texture popping after I found a fix for the issue on the net. Once I bumbed into an invisible car.- Music and sound effects are good too, music I often turn off because I like to concentrate on the effects and ambience but this music I listened to, it was quite fitting, situational and well done.- Difficulty: The game was so easy in the beginning that I switched to the highest difficulty early, you can do this without restarting. I have a tendency to slowly explore and hold my position in a single player FPS if that is possible, this and the fact that there is no gun swaying when you zoom in with certain weapons was the death sentence for a lot of the standard enemies in this game. There is recoil of course but you just need to be a little patient and use your cover. Enemies use grenades but you have the time to get away, they will yell 'use a frag' or something similar and then you know you soon need to retreat a bit, also grenades tick and the direction you need to avoid can be seen on screen once the grenade gets close. If enemies decide to leave cover and charge then you usually will hear about it too. Being patient also meant I did not need any healing besides the auto healing most of the time, the auto healing in this game especially means that scouting will not cost you anything in a lot of situations. Then there were agressive standard melee enemies, mixed sometimes with other enemies and this was a bit more challenging. But you may know what is the standard close combat weapon and it's powerful. The last mission again was a little more difficult but of course you also have the most powerful weapon then. For some reason I did not get myself to use self made rules, if you give Rage a try and are an experienced FPS player then maybe hurry sometimes though there often is no need, you could limit the amount of ammo for certain weapons per mission in the beginning at least, something like that. Later the game got a little more difficult but for me the highest setting was ok and I finished the game with a lot of unspent resources in my inventory.There was a side quest that was a challenge and there may be more side quests and/or races that are difficult, I did not play through all of them because side quests from the job boards often lead you back to an area you know already. And I am bad at race games, winning the easier races though was sufficient to be able to buy enough upgrades.- Characters look good and one in particular was done well enough to let me hope for some more story telling at a certain point, though I did not expect a story rich game. The tension after all did rise after that, there were 3 boss encounters, the atmosphere changed to be more threatening and a tougher fight. It's ok when a game has its climaxes and its weaker moments, the alternative can be boring.- Story: Do you know the line 'Skip that if you want.' ? It's the beginning of the 'story' of the first Doom iirc. The developers have come a long way, skipping text is required regularly now (joke). Seriously you should not try to skip the story completely although - to quote a line in the game - 'no one reads' in the world of Rage. Not going to spoil it, I just suggest we don't let it come to this. Though the game is not too short imo the story was almost over when I found the main purpose for a hero in the wasteland, from that perspective the game seems unfinished. Overall the story is very shallow.- Easy difficulty does not mean it is a game with weak level design, after exiting the wasteland everything is quite linear and some places indeed were a little boring but other locations were well done and there are a lot of scripted encounters. Actually 'scripted encounter' is just a category I'm used to, the 'standard AI behaviour' if something like that exists in this game separatly is not bad at all too. Enemies behind cover for example often are not stupid, you just are too powerful for them usually. Compared to what I am used to the AI has improved a little. But I also have to say the last mission is a letdown. It also is quite short..- Some of the buildings look like from a different planet, maybe they hired an architect tired by the restrictions of reality, nice.- No bugs besides the invisible car I think. Well, once two enemies looking at me did not shoot until I got very close which I 'had to do' because I guess sometimes I need to be shot at first to feel better when... yes. Rarely enemies did not correct their position when only partially behind cover and when being shot at.- Violence: I may be getting closer to the point when I simply saw it often enough, be it a simulation only. I already focused in this ID game on the technological progress I could witness for 10,- € because of my very old PC before this one and the developers deserve full credit for it, and I forgot most of the bloodshed already or so it only seems to me because I also know now there are some consequences in our brains if we make violence more than an occasional experience in our life, there is scientific evidence for this afaik and there is a lot of killing in this game of course, the killing of images of human beings most of the time. What I certainly do remember was "The best idea a 12 year old ever had.", it was the description of a weapon. There was at least one other description which I personally would not want to be responsible for. I may return again to an ID game to watch true progress too but I will give a decision and consequence heavy experience more than one try before getting the new Doom if at all, guess I will wait and buy when and if I get the honest feeling that they get what they deserve, from the demo it seems you shoot evil daemons and possibly with good reason, so all right. For me and increasingly it really does make a difference if there is a good reason for the killing. Now there certainly are reasons for the violence in Rage but the justification feels done halfheartedly 'on the way'. It gets a little better at some point when you get an explanation why the main opposing faction indeed needs to be stopped but behind the shallow story the bad guys certainly are out of their minds simply because we sometimes like to be out of our minds in games. According to the achievements 65% of the players have not even seen the said explanation btw, maybe single player is not important for many and/or the game does not update achievements when you get them in offline mode. Anyway, Rage is bad science fiction at best, certainly a game for 18+.- Though not really a new idea the early setting of the game is ok. Asteroids are a potential 'civilization ender' as someone from NASA did say. You pay with paper money called 'dollars' in the post apocalyptic world, that's another thing I did not forget but this somehow was funny at least.- Some people claim to have finished this game in 12-16 hours, in my case the in game timer (not steam) showed 24 hours at the end. Well, I tried to avoid death but that's quite a difference still. And the (last) hope of the wasteland was destroyed anyway 5 times total in my case, 4 times because of impatience if memory serves.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 28, 2011
												id Software, the inventors of the FPS genre, find themselves in a rough spot, these days. They leave the gameplay innovation to other developers. Doom 3 was already an 'old-school' retro game, when it came out. RAGE is a classic FPS in many ways. The weapons feel good. The enemies are popping up the same way as always. But the fidelity of the presentations is top notch. The animations are maybe the best you can find in new games & the levels are worth exploring, because id tried something new. They left the familiar ground and gave you loot and stuff to sell in shops. And they added a racing game in between the shooting levels, which is quite fun. You won't find pre-rendered textures. Instead, the lead programmer and mastermind John Carmack worked on his infamous "Megatextures", giving artists unprecedented freedoms to craft unique landscapes and levels without the usual restrictions. It's if 2D concept art would have come to life thx to virtual texturing. Worth seeing & playing, IMHO.

content:
3, 2014
												I bought this game the day it came out for xbox 360 (My PC was 100% linux at that point)I played it all the way through and while it felt a bit short I loved every minute of it.I've since upgraded my PC's GPU, dual booted windows, bought it on steam (with the DLC) and am playing through it again.I'm finding it just as enjoyable as the first time I played it and I would like to see more games like it in the future.In my opinion, too many games recently have tried to add far too much content and forgotten to add the fun.These games start to feel like a chore to play and you end up never finishing them. Of course there are exceptions but I have far too many games I will probably never finish because they got boring.Sure RAGE doesn't have the best graphics (although that painted sky is beautiful) nor does it have the greatest storyline, however, it's the kind of game that's genuinly fun to play.The mechanics are fun (I especially like the wingsticks and deployable turrets) and who doesn't like blowing up a mutant with an explosive projectile fired from a massive shotgun? The missions are all slightly different and (at least for me) the game never feels stale or lacking in content.Once you've finished the main storyline and the missions from the jobs board there are always the sewers to clear and now the scorchers DLC which, while quite short, I found to be increadibly entertaining.I get bored very easily and so there are very few games I have played all the way through, let alone gone back to for a second play though. Rage however is one I just can't get enough of.

I personally only have few grips with it. Crafting : Although there is not much 19 receipt however I found all very useful Pop-Rocket is my prefer receipt and combine with the "extended loader" upgrade it is a life save when fighting Mutants on mass. And the high the difficulty the more valuable it is to craft.Freedom within a set environment: Personally I do not mind that it is not open-world actually it is better this way for me and you can revisit most locations on foot or in you car.I have never like fallout 3 open world always had the feeling nagging me that this is so much you have not explored yet even if I am pretty sure I have visited all of the marked areas.The Story: Well it might not be a master piece but I rather enjoy it and it brings you along the world to new places. I will not say anymore to avoid spoilers as much as I can.The Races: no not the different specie what I talk about it the in-build racing this scales with your difficulty and you will have to do some to be able to get the equipment need to complete and start some quest. To be honest I do not like that it is force but I can see the reason for it as the difficult would be too high without those items. After that you collect the currency to upgrade you car with other weapons, armor and front grill all of this helps you out in the wastland.BUG: there is a bug here when it comes to earn additional race credits from Sally amoge others I have found that you have to set it to active to be able to earn the credits.
