number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
5, 2013
												The game can't quite decide if its a non-linear open-world game or an on-rails corridor shooter. It's still fun though, especially at the beginning. Racing, shooting, gathering, crafting.... the game even gives you a believable reason for regenerating health.  The setting and gameplay will grab you, maybe not as tightly as some games but still to a degree.It's only at the end that it all starts to fall apart.  While so much of RAGE's setting is fleshed out and detailed a few key things aren't, things like the bad guys.  The obligatory "Evil Empire" you're supposed to be fighting is really ill-defined and only vaguely talked about, except in the context of "well they're evil, duh."  Since the end game deals extensively with them, the game starts to suffer.The absolute worst point of the game is the end.  The ending literally took me by surprise, as in "wait, that was the last level?!"  I will not spoil the ending itself, but I guarantee you will be disappointed. Disappointed not for what happens, but for what doesn't happen, specifically ANYTHING.Still, the beginning is pretty fun, and the underlying mechanics of the game are sound.  I would have been ♥♥♥♥♥♥ as hell if I'd paid full price for the game, but it was well worth the Steam Sale under $10 price I paid for it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 3, 2013
												I'd reccomend you get this game in a sale, if you're interested in a post-apocalyptic linear FPS. It is not worth the full price at any rate.Mainly because RAGE is NOT a groundbreaking FPS. It's a linear FPS that tries to look like open world and fails massively.It's a fun shooter, weapons feel good and are varied (although I ended up using a good old shotgun most of the time). Driving around in a vehicle is enjoyable, and the overal atmosphere is fine.But the world is only open to about ten minutes of exploration. Then you'll find out it's only a handful of canyons connected together and most of the locations are locked and accessible only during certain quests. Everything else you see in the distance is just a picture on the wall. But your movement is limited even when on foot. Most of the obstacles in your path (like railings, chairs, tables, crates and such) are surrounded by an invisible barrier that allows you to shoot through, but doesn't allow you to jump over these obstacles. Which becomes even more annoying when you see your enemies parkour-vaulting over them, popping behind them, or shooting blindly from cover - all the things you can watch but cannot do.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
7, 2012
												Rage, if nothing else, is one of the most solid first person shooter experiences I've ever had. The graphics, despite the game taking place in a desert, is gorgeous. The gunplay is satisfying and responsive. The side quests, much like the NPCs who give them, are varied and colorful. So what went wrong?Plot wise, Rage has terrible pacing. A majority of the game is spent building your reputation. Your only act of significance occurs in the final moments of the game. Unfortunately, even the endgame isn't rewarding.Playing on the second most difficult setting, I died only twice. Rage is ridiculously easy. The AI is predictable and lacks intelligence. The guns are imbalanced. Challenge is something left to be desired.With regards to the mechanics, Rage does gunplay exceptionally well. Even vehicular combat is smooth and rewarding. However, refining the bare minimum won't get you very far. Nothing about Rage makes it stand out. Yes, it is fun. But no, it isn't memorable.Grade: B-

												I would reccomend rage on a sale or free. (That is how I got it).  It was very visually appealing, lots of rich terrain and infastructure. I felt like as soon and I got a feel for the game it was over. There are two main areas with what seemed like a dozen or so quests per area and then it is over. (I logged about 30 hrs, but really 20 of that was pushing the quests).The weapons were pretty fun (like watching enemies dance when you hit them with a dynamite dart in the hand) but again I wanted more interaction with the Authority. I wanted more technology from them coming at me and more difficult bosses.  The weapon ranges were pretty cool and I wish there were some challenges in the game that demanded creativity in the choice of weaponry and bots.  You could basically go through the game and use only the shotgun pop rockets and the fat mamma's and be fine.(another fun one is the flame thrower guys.. just shoot them with anything you have and they will sort-of turn away... when they turn away exposing their fuel tank shoot the valve and BOOM)From 0 to 100 I would rate it in the low 70's.  I won't likely play it again.  Pretty fun though.Seems like a book, or series of books about this subject would be better. I really wanted more detail about the post-apocolypse and how the authority came to power and what sort of technology they had. Didn't get much of that.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 15
												This is THE game that made last year's remake of DOOM possible; DOOM 3 was good, but it still divides fans today.Sure, RAGE may come off as more of the tired, but classic post-apocalypse setting cliches, but id made them fresh again, with their know-how, and from borrowing asteroid 99942 Apophis from the headlines of 2004. Wingsticks are one of the game's trademark weapons, a pity they didn't get quite the following I for one expected them to get.Your rogues gallery of enemies consists of a fairly fresh take on the standard wasteland faire, including the Ghosts, who may or not be the unintentional forefathers of the Warboys from Mad Max: Fury Road. You are also up against the Authority, whose flag, weapons and red-and-black power armor evokes Hitler's SS; then there's the Mutant Bash TV gladiatorial show, hosted by the hilarious J.K. Stiles; RAGE's twists on After The End are the emphasis on vehicles, both to cross the wasteland, and to compete in racing and demolition derby mini games.One of the last adjustments RAGE makes to the recipe is its weapon and vehicle customizations, bought here and there from merchants, or from mechanics with special credits earned from racing. Yes, id put in a version of the BFG from DOOM - and no, I'm not gonna tell you WHERE exactly!Like a nice little bow atop RAGE's neat package, you also have bit roles of John Goodman voicing the first character you meet, and sexy voiced Steve Blum as John Marshall, the leader of those fighting the previously mentioned Authority.Let's face it - without the Scorcher's DLC, RAGE is actually pretty damn short; but with the Scorcher's, you can keep your game going long after the credits, AND you have more reason to hope for a sequel or an HD re-release.Fans of id Software's 26-year track record shouldn't pass this one up."Ashes scatter, Burnin' Jacob's Ladder, I'm afraid I might fade away!"

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 1
												I can only comment on the single player campaign of the game and I did not buy the DLC 'The Scorchers'.- Game is from 2011 but graphics are fine in my eyes. Well, they are good enough that you also will notice that a lot of textures look low res when you come close, for me this was not a big problem, I had a very old display and system a few weeks ago. If you think a game like for example Skyrim looks bad then you may already be used to something different and please keep that in mind if you continue reading.I had very little texture popping after I found a fix for the issue on the net. Once I bumbed into an invisible car.- Music and sound effects are good too, music I often turn off because I like to concentrate on the effects and ambience but this music I listened to, it was quite fitting, situational and well done.- Difficulty: The game was so easy in the beginning that I switched to the highest difficulty early, you can do this without restarting. I have a tendency to slowly explore and hold my position in a single player FPS if that is possible, this and the fact that there is no gun swaying when you zoom in with certain weapons was the death sentence for a lot of the standard enemies in this game. There is recoil of course but you just need to be a little patient and use your cover. Enemies use grenades but you have the time to get away, they will yell 'use a frag' or something similar and then you know you soon need to retreat a bit, also grenades tick and the direction you need to avoid can be seen on screen once the grenade gets close. If enemies decide to leave cover and charge then you usually will hear about it too. Being patient also meant I did not need any healing besides the auto healing most of the time, the auto healing in this game especially means that scouting will not cost you anything in a lot of situations. Then there were agressive standard melee enemies, mixed sometimes with other enemies and this was a bit more challenging. But you may know what is the standard close combat weapon and it's powerful. The last mission again was a little more difficult but of course you also have the most powerful weapon then. For some reason I did not get myself to use self made rules, if you give Rage a try and are an experienced FPS player then maybe hurry sometimes though there often is no need, you could limit the amount of ammo for certain weapons per mission in the beginning at least, something like that. Later the game got a little more difficult but for me the highest setting was ok and I finished the game with a lot of unspent resources in my inventory.There was a side quest that was a challenge and there may be more side quests and/or races that are difficult, I did not play through all of them because side quests from the job boards often lead you back to an area you know already. And I am bad at race games, winning the easier races though was sufficient to be able to buy enough upgrades.- Characters look good and one in particular was done well enough to let me hope for some more story telling at a certain point, though I did not expect a story rich game. The tension after all did rise after that, there were 3 boss encounters, the atmosphere changed to be more threatening and a tougher fight. It's ok when a game has its climaxes and its weaker moments, the alternative can be boring.- Story: Do you know the line 'Skip that if you want.' ? It's the beginning of the 'story' of the first Doom iirc. The developers have come a long way, skipping text is required regularly now (joke). Seriously you should not try to skip the story completely although - to quote a line in the game - 'no one reads' in the world of Rage. Not going to spoil it, I just suggest we don't let it come to this. Though the game is not too short imo the story was almost over when I found the main purpose for a hero in the wasteland, from that perspective the game seems unfinished. Overall the story is very shallow.- Easy difficulty does not mean it is a game with weak level design, after exiting the wasteland everything is quite linear and some places indeed were a little boring but other locations were well done and there are a lot of scripted encounters. Actually 'scripted encounter' is just a category I'm used to, the 'standard AI behaviour' if something like that exists in this game separatly is not bad at all too. Enemies behind cover for example often are not stupid, you just are too powerful for them usually. Compared to what I am used to the AI has improved a little. But I also have to say the last mission is a letdown. It also is quite short..- Some of the buildings look like from a different planet, maybe they hired an architect tired by the restrictions of reality, nice.- No bugs besides the invisible car I think. Well, once two enemies looking at me did not shoot until I got very close which I 'had to do' because I guess sometimes I need to be shot at first to feel better when... yes. Rarely enemies did not correct their position when only partially behind cover and when being shot at.- Violence: I may be getting closer to the point when I simply saw it often enough, be it a simulation only. I already focused in this ID game on the technological progress I could witness for 10,- € because of my very old PC before this one and the developers deserve full credit for it, and I forgot most of the bloodshed already or so it only seems to me because I also know now there are some consequences in our brains if we make violence more than an occasional experience in our life, there is scientific evidence for this afaik and there is a lot of killing in this game of course, the killing of images of human beings most of the time. What I certainly do remember was "The best idea a 12 year old ever had.", it was the description of a weapon. There was at least one other description which I personally would not want to be responsible for. I may return again to an ID game to watch true progress too but I will give a decision and consequence heavy experience more than one try before getting the new Doom if at all, guess I will wait and buy when and if I get the honest feeling that they get what they deserve, from the demo it seems you shoot evil daemons and possibly with good reason, so all right. For me and increasingly it really does make a difference if there is a good reason for the killing. Now there certainly are reasons for the violence in Rage but the justification feels done halfheartedly 'on the way'. It gets a little better at some point when you get an explanation why the main opposing faction indeed needs to be stopped but behind the shallow story the bad guys certainly are out of their minds simply because we sometimes like to be out of our minds in games. According to the achievements 65% of the players have not even seen the said explanation btw, maybe single player is not important for many and/or the game does not update achievements when you get them in offline mode. Anyway, Rage is bad science fiction at best, certainly a game for 18+.- Though not really a new idea the early setting of the game is ok. Asteroids are a potential 'civilization ender' as someone from NASA did say. You pay with paper money called 'dollars' in the post apocalyptic world, that's another thing I did not forget but this somehow was funny at least.- Some people claim to have finished this game in 12-16 hours, in my case the in game timer (not steam) showed 24 hours at the end. Well, I tried to avoid death but that's quite a difference still. And the (last) hope of the wasteland was destroyed anyway 5 times total in my case, 4 times because of impatience if memory serves.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 30, 2015
												Rage, developed by Id Software & Released on Oct 4, 2011. According to Metacritic (http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/rage), it's rank 55th best critic review pc game & 9th most discussed pc game in 2011, respectively.  Does it hold any meaningful  value or worth purchasing in 2015? It depends. The Controls are easy to grasp. Visually, it still looks good to date. Game mechanics is good, fun. Aside from the FPS, you'll have racing and some other mini games to play. The combat system is responsive@really satisfying feel. The AI are fairly smart. You'll get to experience it when you put up a fight against groups of mutants and the humans factions.Rage is set in an post-apocalyptic time. It feels like a combination of mad max & borderland. I'll give you the bad news first. You'll be spending most of your time driving. The good news?  No nonsense farming for random glowing loot & you'll get to blow up lots of enemies/vehicles/mutants while exploring the land -or-trying to get from point A to point B. Unlike borderlands, you'll only have a limited choice of weapons & customization to choose from. Some are pretty nasty & interesting (for instance the Nail Gun or the remote control car with bomb) BUT you'll need to replenish the ammo constantly throughout your travels. You either buy them or craft them from your salvages.The road to richness is a long one, you'll get to play some mini games to to earn cash, a tv arena to earn more cash and a few racing arena where you'll have to invest your time to get the vehicles upgrade parts for your sweet ride.The story is linear but definitely an interesting one. Not as funny/whacky than borderlands but is still refreshing to do them after X amount hours on the road (smashing/blowing up everything that moves). There's Multiplayer option as well however I have yet to try it out myself.My Summary:It was refreshing and fun at first but after a XX amount of hours into the game, it gets pretty boring@repetitive but what kept me going was the story. The interesting fights/scenario you're put into. Late into the game however, there's a sudden spike of difficulty. That's a no-no for me. I wasn't pleased at all with ending. (There wasn't even an epic boss fight!) Despite the awesome guns/combat mechanic - there is no replay value for Rage. It was a sweet, one time experience for me. On the scale of 0 - 10, my personal rating for Rage is a 6/10.

content:
er 3, 2013
												I'd reccomend you get this game in a sale, if you're interested in a post-apocalyptic linear FPS. It is not worth the full price at any rate.Mainly because RAGE is NOT a groundbreaking FPS. It's a linear FPS that tries to look like open world and fails massively.It's a fun shooter, weapons feel good and are varied (although I ended up using a good old shotgun most of the time). Driving around in a vehicle is enjoyable, and the overal atmosphere is fine.But the world is only open to about ten minutes of exploration. Then you'll find out it's only a handful of canyons connected together and most of the locations are locked and accessible only during certain quests. Everything else you see in the distance is just a picture on the wall. But your movement is limited even when on foot. Most of the obstacles in your path (like railings, chairs, tables, crates and such) are surrounded by an invisible barrier that allows you to shoot through, but doesn't allow you to jump over these obstacles. Which becomes even more annoying when you see your enemies parkour-vaulting over them, popping behind them, or shooting blindly from cover - all the things you can watch but cannot do.

content:
r 12, 2011
												Rage is something of a departure for Id in that there is more to Rage than simple FPS mechanics. Sure the shooting is there and what shooting there is is incredibly well done with locational damage and some decent weapons. As well as some amazing enemy animations as well as AI that is impressive in it's ability to take cover. Rage offers more than this though with it's light RPG elements such as crafting and "quests" and the buggy driving mechanics which will come in to play while travelling to your quest locations. Here Id's abilty shines with car combat that wouldn't be out of place in a dedicated arcade racer.What really impresses though are the NPC animations, such as the blind Dr with the shoulder robot or the Mayor of Wellsprings who all show movie quality animations and facial tech. Just be wary if you're an ATI owner as there are some driver issues related to this game. 8/10.

content:
2, 2012
												So after finishing the game that I was really looking forward to, I have mixed feelings with RAGE.PROS:+Great action. +Addictive driving and fun car combat. Fun races too! +Great weapons with good sounds+Impressive graphics once setup properly.CONS:-VERY linear -LITTLE exploration. No free roaming à la Borderlands / Fallout 3. -Few side quests / jobs to do.-No deathmach mode for multiplayer (very unlike id Soft)-Online racing can be tedious to find other players.-No BOSS FIGHT in the last chapter (quite unlike id Soft)-No proper closure of the campaign mode (still no DLC)-ATI Drivers issues at game launch made the game unplayable till months later. (Waited 5 months till the game was playable!)Saddening this game took MANY MANY YEARS in development and it ended up like this. Promising game with many letdowns. OVERALL:A disappointing game with fun shooter elements like id Soft are known for and that it could've been so much more. RATING:7.0 / 10UPDATE:If you loved playing RAGE, you may consider playing the single player DLC which is decent but don't expect more story into the game, unfortunately.

The Game falls short right in the second wordlmap - this is ID´s post apocalypse shoot gallery with vehicle races, but if you tought "ELDER´S SCROLLS!" when you saw BETHESDA in the credits, look more carefully and you´ll see ID´s software is there too. The graphics are amazing and the game is open-world... if you consider a two-square mile canion with uninteractive gorgeous scenarious where you CAN´T GO open-world. You race in normal races and stupid ones where the objective moves constantly - so even if you tuned up your car you end up losing because you have no idea where to go - and battle with them, either against easy enemies or an horde of final ones, inside and outside the lanes. This was supposed to be a post-apocaliptic race battler with RPG elements. What´s the problem with it? ID´s software dumb touch is the problem. Closing the player in a dead end with either a wave of enemies or big bosses, dumbly blocking strategical positions and exits with impassible little fences, like DOOM does. limiting ammo and grinding, removing maps from interiors so you get lost after you finish the level (the old 'where the ♥♥♥♥ next?!?'), and the most imcompetent corpse-looting in the history of games (not like STALKER where you can loot weapons, or Elders Scrolls where you can even loot armor: this ♥♥♥♥ get 5 Bucks per corpse and a little random ammo). Yes, it´s just like a Bethesda game... if you diminished scenario, casualized inventory and cutted the open world to a little canyon. I rarely write reviews, but after THIS game all i can feel is... RAGE.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
0, 2014
												Rage is a classic first person shooter with a post-apocalyptic scenario.Graphics:     7/10The good news is that the game on the whole looks very good. When you play it for the first time you will have the "wow-effect" as soon as your character leaves the survivor capsule. The particle effects are not exeggerated and suitable. When you get the first weapons you will agree that the developers put some work into them. They may not be everbody's taste but the visual quality is unquestionably good. You can say the same thing regarding the environment.The bad news is that if you look a bit closer at the textures you will be very disappointed. Some are very blurred and directly next to them some are razor-sharp ones, what underlines the blurring even more. It looks like someone mixed Crysis 3 textures with Minecraft textures. Nevertheless the game has a good appearance concerning the graphics.Sounds:     6/10The weapon sounds are really powerful (especially the shotgun). Usually the rule is "the louder the gun the more damage you do". The cars have a nice engine noise. While most of the enemies say nothing or have nasty sounds you don't want to hear the villagers have pleasant voices. I appreciate that the developers tried to give everything a sound. That made the game lively and authentic. Due to the really bad enemy sounds I give 6/10. The developers could have made it better than that.Gameplay/Handling/Equipment:     9/10It's an ego-shooter, you will get what you expect. You will spend most of the time shooting mutants and bandits. To keep the player entertained the developers wisely added some side missions to break the monotony. Besides that you can gamble, enter an extensive racing competition to win car upgrades and new cars, play cards with a "trading card game" or risk some fingers in the knifegame. The handling is nearly perfect. You can quickly change weapons and ammo type, draw your grenade or fix yourself up. Steering a car is really easy. The equipment is very nice. The different ammo types make the game interesting. If you are tired of normal shotgun ammo then craft explosive ones to transform your shotgun into a grenade launcher. Especially the crossbow has a lot of special bolts.Level design:     8/10The level design is pretty narrow with some exceptions. This makes the combat straightforward and the shotgun your best friend in close quarter combat. The exceptions are mostly the parts where you are driving the car. Sadly there are only two or three sniper side missions. The level routes are very interesting and sophisticated. You will have few monotonous areas in the game. The only really monotonous part is the open world which connects the mission locations.I loved the level where I had to go to the destroyed city to get the defibrilator-upgrade. It gave me a real apocalyptic feeling.Enemies/AI:     5/10The AI is relatively poor. Except for some scripted events the enemies are just charging at you or are not using the covers properly. They don't have teamwork or act structured. Well at least some enemies use special abilities like the "octopus-like" enemy with the hook. The enemy variety is relatively low but it doesn't really matter.Story:     3/10The beginning and the basic idea was actually cool but it seems that the developers lost their creativity in the end. You are a survivor of a meteor impact and then... well and then you have to deal with the new world. There are some people who want to use the rescue-capsule for something and you want to free the civillians from the enemy influence and make sure that the capsules don't fall into enemies' hands. I don't really get it, what's so damn important about the capsules? They missed the "legendary" reason to fight a big bad company. Im sad that they wasted potential here. Even I could have made a better script for a story. And the biggest disappointment awaits at the very end. No big fight (not bigger than before), noone really cares and nothing you could call an ENDBOSS. The game was made to have an endboss. I was 100% sure of it: There has to be one. But poof. Nothing at all. Borderlands 1 had a crappy Endboss but at least they developed one.Critic summary:     6,3/10Personal fun rating:     8/10     [very good game]With all it's problems and missed opportunities the game is still worth a try.If the developers make a sequel I desperately hope for them to implement an endboss.The game may not have an exciting ending (extremely boring to be honest) but the gameplay and the atmosphere at the beginning and midgame is really enjoyable.I recommend it to buy it for 10 bucks or less.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
1, 2013
												Review, not recommendation.The game is rather fun to play and is a straight forward shooter.  If you enjoy FPS's you'll enjoy RAGE.The setting feels appropriate, and the people populated into the world by the writers and actors fit the situation perfectly.  It was refreshing to have the characters populating the world feel like real people rather than plain cardboard cutouts.Like most sci-fi shooters in post apocalyptica, the weapons vary from a very basic pistol to a rocket launcher or a energy mini-gun.  As per normal, the only weapon in the game that can one shot anyone is a 'hi-tech' crossbow, and it can only do it if the enemy doesn't know you are there.There is a MadMax car component to the game that isn't bad, but I don't really view it as a core component to the game.  The car is mostly for getting you from point A to point B.  The car racing/demo derbies are fun distractors from going off and playing the other parts of the game.Overall, I'd say the greatest reason to play RAGE is the atmosphere and the well portrayed NPCs.  Most everything else is pretty generic.The story is pretty good, but the ending felt like a let-down to me personally.  Especially considering some of the things you do in game prior to its conclusion.Overall rating: 6/10 (Get it if you like shooters, you'll probably enjoy yourself)

content:
0, 2014
												If you are coming here expecting something with plot as great as Modern Warfare or New Vegas, turn back now.  If you want an open world full of systems and dynamics on par with the GTA series or the Fallout Series, turn back now.If you want a shoot mans game  that feels good and natural and intense as you approach a room full of hostiles, click buy.  I really wish the gunplay in this game was copied over into those other games I mentioned earlier.  The character models, the feel of the guns, the doubt as to whether you want to risk your high end ammo for a good kill or tough it out with smaller weapons to save the good bits for what is down the hall, that feels good.The crafting system is surprisingly fun, especially with the ability to craft turrets, spider drones, RC car bombs, and some meds, this is crafting that's on par with what new vegas had, more accessable actually.But all this comes at the cost of texture pop-in in the exterior, a shoddy story, pretty but lifeless towns, and an experience which is fun but kind of hollow. Get it cheap but get it to understand good gunplay.

In some areas the voice acting was JUST BAD like when you first meet the resistance in the sewers jesus that was horrible.2. Not very many enemy types throughout the whole game3. Car combat is very clunky and non-fluid it takes some time to get use to it.4. The game gets repetive after a while because of all the Main Quests.Final score 7.6/10 it honestly could have been it a lot better.

												All the hype and fan-♥♥♥♥♥ing aside, despite some of Rage's flaws, it is a mindblowingly fun and gorgeous gaming experience for those that love certain things about first person shooters - violent, bloody death scenes and an arsenal that kicks serious ♥♥♥! The AI was pretty darn decent (and amusing), the different ammo types were fun, and I absolutely adore sentry bots/turrets so had a fab time trying out the different gear. The racing elements weren't necessarily my idea of fun but the mixed genre was different for me and I quite enjoyed that. Its a beautiful, fun first person shooter. Did I mention poprocket ammo for the shotgun, mind control bolts and dynamite bolts for the crossbow and sentry bots / turrets? Noice. Grab it - if your gear is decent and can handle the game, you won't have much to complain about! :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 12, 2013
												RAGE is another single word title game from id Software, creators of DooM and Quake. This game was the showcase for id’s Tech 5 Engine and as well as the first new IP from the company since Quake. As one would expect, RAGE is a First Person Shooter, but only part of the time. It is also a racing game at times as well as a vehicular combat game.  RAGE takes place more than 100 years after an asteroid has devastated the planet in an atmosphere that is similar to the Fallout series in some ways. You play as an Arc Survivor, a person that was placed in cryogenic suspension to be woken up after the disaster to rebuild civilization. The player isn’t the average joe by any means. He has been infused with nanotech that enables him to heal amazingly fast and even come back from the dead. First the player battles the many bandits that inhabit the Wasteland, hideous mutants and then moves on to the tyrannical high tech Authority which aims to dominate the world.     Combat in RAGE is solid and was certainly the most enjoyable part the game for me. The weapons “feel” solid and are varied. Along with different weapons are different ammunition types. Some types of ammunition increase affectedness against certain types of enemies and a few make radical changes in how the weapon will act. In addition to using weapons the player is able to construct RC Bomb Carts, Sentry Turrets and even lethal Sentry Bots to help the player out in a fight. No small amount of combat that occurs in RAGE takes place on the roads of the wastelands as you drive about. This combat can get a bit tedious at times as there is little variation in the enemies and they attack in a fairly predictable manner. That was the good, now for the bad and that is the writing. I am not saying the writing is terrible, it gets the minimum job done. But it *only* gets the minimum job done. Most of the characters you see in the game come off as flat caricatures whose only reason to exist is to drive the story along, act as an info dump or give you a mission to accomplish. You really don’t care anything about these people. Even the ones you should care about such as Dan Hagar, the first person you meet on the game and he even saves your life. If the characters you meet in the game have any real life to them it is because the voice actor gives it to them. If Steve (Spike Spiegel) Blum can’t bring a lot of life to a character, something isn’t right. Sometimes there are things that show up that make no real sense and can break your suspension of belief. Bandits with British or Russian accents? What? WHY? Heck, I remember one bandit complaining about how he missed Mother Russia. This is supposed to be a post-apocalyptic world. You just don’t pick up and move hundreds of people halfway across the planet without even a hint an explanation or reason.  Something that irritated me was all the references to other id games that can be found in RAGE. Now I am not totally against the practice of referencing, but there is a point where it breaks immersion. Unfortunately in RAGE they go to the point of shattering immersion into a thousand little pieces for no good reason I can see. From hidden rooms dedicated to earlier games (done in the same graphical style as the original game) to advertisements for DooM 3 or RAGE 2, to “Pinkies” a combined take off on Twinkies and the Pink Demons from DooM. You can even find the “numbers” from LOST in there as well as a “Pick up the can” scene from Half Life 2. Probably the best illustration of the problems I see with RAGE can be found in “The Scorchers” DLC. In this we are introduced to Sarah, a member of the Hagar Clan. It seems to me that she was supposed to be a character similar Alyx Vance from Half Life 2. But if that was what id was going for, they failed and failed badly. She starts off as a very good fighter, then turns into a damsel in distress at the drop of a hat for no other reason to give the player a reason to follow the bad guys. Sarah shows more skin than just about any other female character and struts and poses like a model all the time. Worse after going through a fairly traumatic experience she shows absolutely no reaction to it other than a “Thank You”. Wut? The main enemy of the DLC (a bandit clan called the Scorchers) has a base in some strange ruins that look like they were built by aliens. In fact I actually thought that it did take place on another planet for a while since it didn’t resemble the environment seen in all the rest of the game. The end of the DLC leaves Sarah in the Trophy Room (Yes, that is the Official Name) and never leaving. If you talk to her she will snark a little at the player though.  I guess the biggest problem I have with RAGE is that I can clearly see is that id seems to have been shooting for the next Half Life or HALO IP and they screwed it up. They had all the pieces to make a compelling universe that people would want to visit again and again, but they failed to bring those pieces together and relied on writing that is often flat and riddled with clichés. I guess the part about RAGE I dislike the most is the fact I can see the great game it could have been and is not. Despite my complaints RAGE is a good shooter and if you are looking some good FPS combat RAGE certainly delivers. Just don’t expect much more than that. sm

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Rage had a lot of hype behind it and rightfully so. id Tech 5 introduced "Mega textures" and bolstered some other neat features. So did the engine and the game deliver us the true "next gen" id experience? Yes and no.You are an Arc survivor, one of the best [badass] and brightest of humanity before a major calamity befell earth. You wake up from your cryo-sleep ready to rebuilt society. Only to find the world has been reduced to a wasteland filled with bandits, mutants and is under control of the "authority". While getting on your feet, helping some of the more civilized natives you come across an overarching plot that ties everything together.The wasteland that you find yourself in is a pseudo open-world. It has a clear structure of progression with separated locations on the two over-world maps to clear out. You'll take on quests from people you meet in the hub towns and you're free to tackle all your quests in any given order. You travel to each location with a selection of quads and cars, all upgradeable at your leisure. While traveling from location to location you'll notice that the big draw here is the variety the id Tech 5 engine provides. Repeated textures are few and far in between, creating some wonderfully diverse scenery of sprawling vistas. This however comes at a cost.Rage uses immensely large singular texture maps ["Mega Textures"] for each location, streaming in only that what's being looked at at that moment. The most noticeable problem is that if you spin around 180 degrees or round a corner you'll see the textures clearly stream in. Another problem this generates is that because each location essentially has one large texture file the resolution of individual objects might seem rather low at close proximity. Because of these issues and the lack of directly being able to resolve them in the video settings menu [without going into the developer console], it is recommended that you use a GPU with 2GB of VRAM. I would also reckon that because of the sheer size of the textures a SSD drive would greatly speed up this streaming process as well.Do these glaring problems still make it worth exploring? Yes. Despite it's shortcomings Rage presents a wonderfully hand crafted world for you to explore. Each location you'll visit has a clear flavor, look and feels completely unique.The level design varies and changes per location, as do it's natives. Enemies come in a variety of flavors and the AI's tactics will be completely different from one faction to another. How each faction navigates their environment differently can make initial encounters jarring and tense. All that being said, everything can be disposed of with a well placed buckshot or two. The gun-play feels like the signature id Software gameplay we all grew up on, while also throwing in some new elements [vehicle combat] that can be hit or miss. All you need to know about the guns is that the signature id Shotgun and BFG are properly represented here.To sum it all up, Rage is an interesting, gorgeous but sometimes frustrating ride that stumbles in it's execution. With John Carmack's departure from id Software it might be the last "true" id game we see. And that's exactly what it is, it's an id game. Now suck it up, strap in and blow some bandits away.- Full disclosure - I played and 100% completed the SP component of this game on Hard. I have as of writing this review not touched any of the DLC or MP components.

content:
26, 2014
												I really enjoyed what I have played so far.  It is true that the driving isn't as fun as the shooting parts but the driving parts arn't bad either.  This game actually does a lot right.  It is varied and gives you lots of different things to do.  The guns feel powerful and meaty, as in any ID FPS, and it gives lots of options to customise the ammo you put in your gun.  It has a crafting system so you can make your own ammo and sentry bots and remote control car bombs and ....etc.  Wing sticks are a good addition and adds a new level of strategy when 4 guys are running towards you twirling through the air with flaming baseball bats.  The enemy AI is really well done.  In fact I think this game has the best AI I have ever played against in an FPS.  Graphics:  Are really well done.  The scenery is really beautiful as well as character models.  Some of the inside textures are low quality but it doesn't really detract from the overall feel.  You just might not be able to read what it says on a vending machine or on a computer screen.  Does not affect gameplay one bit and there are plenty of high res textures in the game.Sound: Very interesting soundtrack with the different guitar noises whenever you complete a quest.  It almost made it that much more satisfying to beat every mission.  The music in the FPS sections really sucks you in how it adds urgancy and scare the ♥♥♥♥ out of you at the same time.  Overall I would recommend this game for ID FPS fans.  If at first you are discouraged because of the racing parts, just keep going, it gets much better.

content:
r 12, 2011
												Rage is something of a departure for Id in that there is more to Rage than simple FPS mechanics. Sure the shooting is there and what shooting there is is incredibly well done with locational damage and some decent weapons. As well as some amazing enemy animations as well as AI that is impressive in it's ability to take cover. Rage offers more than this though with it's light RPG elements such as crafting and "quests" and the buggy driving mechanics which will come in to play while travelling to your quest locations. Here Id's abilty shines with car combat that wouldn't be out of place in a dedicated arcade racer.What really impresses though are the NPC animations, such as the blind Dr with the shoulder robot or the Mayor of Wellsprings who all show movie quality animations and facial tech. Just be wary if you're an ATI owner as there are some driver issues related to this game. 8/10.

												So after finishing the game that I was really looking forward to, I have mixed feelings with RAGE.PROS:+Great action. +Addictive driving and fun car combat. Fun races too! +Great weapons with good sounds+Impressive graphics once setup properly.CONS:-VERY linear -LITTLE exploration. No free roaming à la Borderlands / Fallout 3. -Few side quests / jobs to do.-No deathmach mode for multiplayer (very unlike id Soft)-Online racing can be tedious to find other players.-No BOSS FIGHT in the last chapter (quite unlike id Soft)-No proper closure of the campaign mode (still no DLC)-ATI Drivers issues at game launch made the game unplayable till months later. (Waited 5 months till the game was playable!)Saddening this game took MANY MANY YEARS in development and it ended up like this. Promising game with many letdowns. OVERALL:A disappointing game with fun shooter elements like id Soft are known for and that it could've been so much more. RATING:7.0 / 10UPDATE:If you loved playing RAGE, you may consider playing the single player DLC which is decent but don't expect more story into the game, unfortunately.

												This is DOOM creator´s Jhon Carmac last piece of ♥♥♥♥.Bethesda should know better than join up with ID software. The Game falls short right in the second wordlmap - this is ID´s post apocalypse shoot gallery with vehicle races, but if you tought "ELDER´S SCROLLS!" when you saw BETHESDA in the credits, look more carefully and you´ll see ID´s software is there too. The graphics are amazing and the game is open-world... if you consider a two-square mile canion with uninteractive gorgeous scenarious where you CAN´T GO open-world. You race in normal races and stupid ones where the objective moves constantly - so even if you tuned up your car you end up losing because you have no idea where to go - and battle with them, either against easy enemies or an horde of final ones, inside and outside the lanes. This was supposed to be a post-apocaliptic race battler with RPG elements. What´s the problem with it? ID´s software dumb touch is the problem. Closing the player in a dead end with either a wave of enemies or big bosses, dumbly blocking strategical positions and exits with impassible little fences, like DOOM does. limiting ammo and grinding, removing maps from interiors so you get lost after you finish the level (the old 'where the ♥♥♥♥ next?!?'), and the most imcompetent corpse-looting in the history of games (not like STALKER where you can loot weapons, or Elders Scrolls where you can even loot armor: this ♥♥♥♥ get 5 Bucks per corpse and a little random ammo). Yes, it´s just like a Bethesda game... if you diminished scenario, casualized inventory and cutted the open world to a little canyon. I rarely write reviews, but after THIS game all i can feel is... RAGE.

												I have read a lot of criticism against this game. Maybe Im not normal, but I mean that this is the best FPS I have ever played.- The good: Is an spectacle for the eyes. The cities, the landscapes, the interiors, and all the characters are lovely and nicely made. The physics is the best, how you move, how the enemies move and how they die! All that runs perfectly with an old gtx 260 m, with high seetings, just going down a little with textures and antialiasing (x8).- The bad: A problem with textures popping up. The game is too short in duration? yes, as all the FPS in the markedet nowadays. Is up to you: rush the game in around 12-16 hours or enjoy the way, play some of the minigames in the cities, do the races, and you get a longer gameplay. Not to say, if you do achievements, you know that 16 hours of gameplay can became much, much more. - A hint: if you are used to FPS, play the game in hard from start. Is not so hard. This is also a good way to get more gameplay. Rushing is not so easy then.

												If you are coming here expecting something with plot as great as Modern Warfare or New Vegas, turn back now.  If you want an open world full of systems and dynamics on par with the GTA series or the Fallout Series, turn back now.If you want a shoot mans game  that feels good and natural and intense as you approach a room full of hostiles, click buy.  I really wish the gunplay in this game was copied over into those other games I mentioned earlier.  The character models, the feel of the guns, the doubt as to whether you want to risk your high end ammo for a good kill or tough it out with smaller weapons to save the good bits for what is down the hall, that feels good.The crafting system is surprisingly fun, especially with the ability to craft turrets, spider drones, RC car bombs, and some meds, this is crafting that's on par with what new vegas had, more accessable actually.But all this comes at the cost of texture pop-in in the exterior, a shoddy story, pretty but lifeless towns, and an experience which is fun but kind of hollow. Get it cheap but get it to understand good gunplay.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 25, 2013
												I see other reviewers' complaints about the story line, characters, etc.  I find myself wondering whether they've played the same game as me?!This game is head and shoulders above any other FPS game out there for its weapons, movement and AI mechanics. The graphics is far ahead of any other game of its time, with its texture streaming technology where they've achieved the most realistic environments I've seen to date. Also, you will not see any repeating textures that are so common in other game titles.Game characters are exquisitely portrayed and memorable. Perhaps you won't find much back story for them, but this game is FPS with RPG elements, not the other way around. The game uses RPG elements to involve you into its story, it's a tool, not and end in itself.The same applies to story line. Simple doesn't always mean bad. On contrary, simplicity is Zen, and that is hard to achieve, especially in FPS. Take Crysis 2 or 3 for example, where I've still no idea what's going on, despite replaying it few times. That's because story in Crysis seems like an addon, so I don't care for it. RAGE will make you care, for its story is essential to your gaming experience. Vehicle fights are incredibly fun, but you need to take time to master it. Weapons are punchy and satisfying, with adversaries' AI providing just enough challenge to enjoy the fights. Close proximity fights are so much fun that it took me back to Doom2 and 3 days!The time invested in playing RAGE will reward you with hours of pure fun.

content:
r 12, 2011
												Rage is something of a departure for Id in that there is more to Rage than simple FPS mechanics. Sure the shooting is there and what shooting there is is incredibly well done with locational damage and some decent weapons. As well as some amazing enemy animations as well as AI that is impressive in it's ability to take cover. Rage offers more than this though with it's light RPG elements such as crafting and "quests" and the buggy driving mechanics which will come in to play while travelling to your quest locations. Here Id's abilty shines with car combat that wouldn't be out of place in a dedicated arcade racer.What really impresses though are the NPC animations, such as the blind Dr with the shoulder robot or the Mayor of Wellsprings who all show movie quality animations and facial tech. Just be wary if you're an ATI owner as there are some driver issues related to this game. 8/10.

content:
y 15
												This is THE game that made last year's remake of DOOM possible; DOOM 3 was good, but it still divides fans today.Sure, RAGE may come off as more of the tired, but classic post-apocalypse setting cliches, but id made them fresh again, with their know-how, and from borrowing asteroid 99942 Apophis from the headlines of 2004. Wingsticks are one of the game's trademark weapons, a pity they didn't get quite the following I for one expected them to get.Your rogues gallery of enemies consists of a fairly fresh take on the standard wasteland faire, including the Ghosts, who may or not be the unintentional forefathers of the Warboys from Mad Max: Fury Road. You are also up against the Authority, whose flag, weapons and red-and-black power armor evokes Hitler's SS; then there's the Mutant Bash TV gladiatorial show, hosted by the hilarious J.K. Stiles; RAGE's twists on After The End are the emphasis on vehicles, both to cross the wasteland, and to compete in racing and demolition derby mini games.One of the last adjustments RAGE makes to the recipe is its weapon and vehicle customizations, bought here and there from merchants, or from mechanics with special credits earned from racing. Yes, id put in a version of the BFG from DOOM - and no, I'm not gonna tell you WHERE exactly!Like a nice little bow atop RAGE's neat package, you also have bit roles of John Goodman voicing the first character you meet, and sexy voiced Steve Blum as John Marshall, the leader of those fighting the previously mentioned Authority.Let's face it - without the Scorcher's DLC, RAGE is actually pretty damn short; but with the Scorcher's, you can keep your game going long after the credits, AND you have more reason to hope for a sequel or an HD re-release.Fans of id Software's 26-year track record shouldn't pass this one up."Ashes scatter, Burnin' Jacob's Ladder, I'm afraid I might fade away!"

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
7, 2012
												Rage, if nothing else, is one of the most solid first person shooter experiences I've ever had. The graphics, despite the game taking place in a desert, is gorgeous. The gunplay is satisfying and responsive. The side quests, much like the NPCs who give them, are varied and colorful. So what went wrong?Plot wise, Rage has terrible pacing. A majority of the game is spent building your reputation. Your only act of significance occurs in the final moments of the game. Unfortunately, even the endgame isn't rewarding.Playing on the second most difficult setting, I died only twice. Rage is ridiculously easy. The AI is predictable and lacks intelligence. The guns are imbalanced. Challenge is something left to be desired.With regards to the mechanics, Rage does gunplay exceptionally well. Even vehicular combat is smooth and rewarding. However, refining the bare minimum won't get you very far. Nothing about Rage makes it stand out. Yes, it is fun. But no, it isn't memorable.Grade: B-

content:
16, 2015
												Overall, this game delivers a constantly fun experience throughout the whole game, which is more than what many FPS games can claim. It feels as if the designers thought about what's fun first and let the rest of the game fall into place around that concept.I consistently enjoyed the core shooting gameplay. It rewards precise aiming in that headshots do lots more damage. However, the enemies can feel like bullet sponges at times. I overcame this by using the strongest ammunition I could find. I ended up playing most of the game using the starting pistol with Fat Mamma and the shotgun with Pop Rockets. A headshot from a fat mamma or a direct hit with a Pop Rocket is an instant kill on normal enemies. So, if you start to feel frustrated by enemies seeming to have too much health, try that out. Even then, the frustration factor is mitigated by a revive mechanic AND a quick save and quick load mechanism.There's also racing. The racing controls on a keyboard kinda suck. The wheels turn before the camera, so you'll often end up turning to sharply. I didn't try playing with a controller because I didnt' know how it would handle switching between schemes, but I bet that would be better. That issue aside, it's actually a really fun addition to the shooting gameplay and a nice way to break it up and make the environment seem bigger and more lived in. In particular, I liked how they would put challenges that would reward bonus money when you were driving to an objective. It made it feel less repetitive even when you were driving back and forth. between the same areas.It's not without issues. They re-use several areas a few times. I didn't find this to be much of a problem because you're honestly just more focused on the shooting and what the enemies are doing, and they change up the enemies when you re-play through those areas. Also, if you play on a low sensitivity like me, the menus are very unpleasant and difficult to use effectively. It's the fact that they use mouse acceleration combined with a low sensitivity setting that just makes it possible the worst menu experience I've ever seen. Thankfully, you don't need to spend too much time in menus, but it would've definitely enhanced the experience.If you want a fun, precise FPS, definitely get this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Rage had a lot of hype behind it and rightfully so. id Tech 5 introduced "Mega textures" and bolstered some other neat features. So did the engine and the game deliver us the true "next gen" id experience? Yes and no.You are an Arc survivor, one of the best [badass] and brightest of humanity before a major calamity befell earth. You wake up from your cryo-sleep ready to rebuilt society. Only to find the world has been reduced to a wasteland filled with bandits, mutants and is under control of the "authority". While getting on your feet, helping some of the more civilized natives you come across an overarching plot that ties everything together.The wasteland that you find yourself in is a pseudo open-world. It has a clear structure of progression with separated locations on the two over-world maps to clear out. You'll take on quests from people you meet in the hub towns and you're free to tackle all your quests in any given order. You travel to each location with a selection of quads and cars, all upgradeable at your leisure. While traveling from location to location you'll notice that the big draw here is the variety the id Tech 5 engine provides. Repeated textures are few and far in between, creating some wonderfully diverse scenery of sprawling vistas. This however comes at a cost.Rage uses immensely large singular texture maps ["Mega Textures"] for each location, streaming in only that what's being looked at at that moment. The most noticeable problem is that if you spin around 180 degrees or round a corner you'll see the textures clearly stream in. Another problem this generates is that because each location essentially has one large texture file the resolution of individual objects might seem rather low at close proximity. Because of these issues and the lack of directly being able to resolve them in the video settings menu [without going into the developer console], it is recommended that you use a GPU with 2GB of VRAM. I would also reckon that because of the sheer size of the textures a SSD drive would greatly speed up this streaming process as well.Do these glaring problems still make it worth exploring? Yes. Despite it's shortcomings Rage presents a wonderfully hand crafted world for you to explore. Each location you'll visit has a clear flavor, look and feels completely unique.The level design varies and changes per location, as do it's natives. Enemies come in a variety of flavors and the AI's tactics will be completely different from one faction to another. How each faction navigates their environment differently can make initial encounters jarring and tense. All that being said, everything can be disposed of with a well placed buckshot or two. The gun-play feels like the signature id Software gameplay we all grew up on, while also throwing in some new elements [vehicle combat] that can be hit or miss. All you need to know about the guns is that the signature id Shotgun and BFG are properly represented here.To sum it all up, Rage is an interesting, gorgeous but sometimes frustrating ride that stumbles in it's execution. With John Carmack's departure from id Software it might be the last "true" id game we see. And that's exactly what it is, it's an id game. Now suck it up, strap in and blow some bandits away.- Full disclosure - I played and 100% completed the SP component of this game on Hard. I have as of writing this review not touched any of the DLC or MP components.

content:
y 30
												I thought that it was overall not a bad game, but it lacked depth. This game competes with Fallout 3 in terms of setting and mood. The graphics are nice. The shading and lighting is a lot better than Fallout. It feels a bit low poly and some of the textures are washed out despite the otherwise impressive engine.It is very smooth, even at highest settings.The gameplay is nice, but not ground breaking. I severely disliked the feeling that you are on rails the entire time. You can not even jump over small obstacles. There is always only one way to get to where you need to be. Everything is very scripted. Enemies will appear out of nowhere because of the way things are scriped. Your path will frequently close behind you, blocking your way back. As a result there is no finesse to the combat. You can not sneak up on the enemy and take them out silently (forget about the boomerangs, they are worthless). This is something that games like dishonored did a lot better.The engine would have provided the technology for an open world game like Fallout but they did not use it. It is a bit of a shame.There is no way to advance your character and learn new things (it is just a shooter, alright). You can buy a few items to boost but that is about it. There is the whole driving and racing element to the game. While it is fun, it feels like a separate game all together and very disconnected from the shooter part. The story is very linear and is lacking depth. It is also quite short. Where do those mutants come from? Why did they mutate like that within 100 years? We never get to meet people behind the authority. Why are they doing all of this anyway? We meet a lot of characters but we never get to really know them.Finally something for the game designers (and not just in this game but many post apocalyptic games): Why does no one clean up?! People occupy some ruins and install all sorts of traps and machinery but no one bothers to clean up and make the place livable? And why is there is still power in all those abandoned ruins? It makes so sense!

content:
2013
												If you can get this game on a budget, then its a great buy....granted most purchases are... ha ha ha. This is a good game.  Its not quite as action heavy or remarkable as say ...."Doom" made by ID, but it still has good things about it.    If you've ever played Fallout 3 you may have been impressed with the vastness of that game regarding the places to travel, guns to use, things to shoot, and people to meet.   Rage takes a diffrent approach by offering "quality" over "quantity"  Not saying that Fallout didnt have quality, but Rage gives a smaller, more polished and prettier experince.   You dont have as many places to go, but damn it looks georgous and you even get some sweet rides to take you there (the optional races in those rides are fun too).  You may not level up your character, but you get some wicked high-tech gadgets to become force multiplyers.   There may not be as many guns, but the guns you do get all have a role that never gets tossed aside and you obtain deadly new varities of ammunition  that changes how they operate and the level of carnage they can cause. The graphics are amazing.  The character details are amazing.  The animations and behavior of the things trying to kill you are amazing.  No joke, its great to have one of the Ghosts do a parkor flip off the side of a wall to avoid your shotgun blast.  I was even suprised to notice that a NPC computer controlled ally of mine maintained realistic gun control and even kept their trigger finger outside of the trigger guard until he was ready to shoot.  Its this great level of detail that makes Rage a new experince that I would encourage others to try.  Whats not so amazing?  The way it ends.   It seems like such a great build up for something that doesnt ever seem finished.  Perhaps they put too much detail in other things and they just ran out of time and/or money, but it seems like it ends to abruptly for a proper ending.  Not really timewise, but gameplay wise.Also after completing the main story and the DLC you're going to be quite constrained.  In fallout and borderlands you can at least go around the land and shoot things.... in RAGE ( please correct me if I'm wrong) you cant unless they changed something in an update that I dont know about.  Once you beat an area enough times that area is closed off.  Kinda lame.

content:
er 28, 2013
												I HONESTLY BELIEVE THIS GAME SHOULD ONLY BE BOUGHT ON SALE!!!Alright, now that I've gotten that out of the way. .  If you're a fan of Fallout 3 and post apocalyptic settings, first person shooters with a variety of guns, like driving vehicles around and even racing them in a side game, then you'll enjoy this game. It's a linear fps with an okay story, some very repetitive quests, lots of driving around like in Borderlands, and it's not all that intricate. You don't assemble any weapons, but you can buy an upgrade every here or there. The voice acting isn't the worst in the world. You don't get to set what your character looks like at atll. The game starts you right in the middle of nowhere, but you're immediately given a mission and a gun. From there on out, you do his missions to gain a couple more weapons and your own race buggy, though you don't really have to race all the time. I hated the racing aspect of this game, but since I went into it with gloomy expectations, I wasn't let down much at all. It was pretty simple, laid back and had a lot of tacked on side games and side quests. I hear the multiplayer is d-e-a-d dead! So it'd be for the single player experience if you're thinking of getting it right now. Which I've heard lasts around 8-10 hours to beat, depending on how much exploring or time you sink inot the side games. All in all, for what I paid, I got a good amount of play time just waiting for me to log back in, but I wouldn't have purchased it if it hadn't been on sale. I'd say if you like SP FPS and a good sale, get it. If you like shooters that have a multiplayer slaughterfest of 1 on 1 or team vs. team, then this is definitely not the game fore you. But I think if you can get it and the DLC for 7 or so bucks, you should.

content:
9
												I remember how much ♥♥♥♥ this got when it came out initially. It's very interesting to play it after Wolfenstein and Doom came out. Between the gunplay and story this game feels like an Id game. That is to say the gunplay is good and the story is dumb. In fact I think the story gets more boring as the game continues. You realize people are offering you these quests and it gives you the option to decline but for what!? They all act like you're doing this tough stuff when you're obviously a god, it just feels out of place. The dialog completely ruined the immersion for me.The game really shines when you're in a good gun battle. The enemy's maneuverability is awesome and underutilized. The game is the worst when you're driving (or racing) past other cars to get to the gun fights. The guns feel good but I wish the battles were more diverse. X amount of enemies spawn kill them to open a door. That happens over and over again. Some of the best levels happen later in the game. There is one fighting the Jackal Clan that has a lot of verticality and feels like a bombardment from all directions, very fun and tough! A lot of the game just feels empty even for a wasteland. You're only allowed to kill enemies in a particular room so every corridor is empty.One HUGE plus, the graphics hold up. I think this game could come out now and no one would complain, that's incredible from a game that is 6 years old. Also nice is the voice acting, they went all out and have some serious names.I kind of liked it but the game is a meh for me but you can't choose that on steam. I'm not sure Wolfenstein and Doom would be what they are without this game. I don't recommend you play this game but you might want to play, then do what you want.

												If you can get this game on a budget, then its a great buy....granted most purchases are... ha ha ha. This is a good game.  Its not quite as action heavy or remarkable as say ...."Doom" made by ID, but it still has good things about it.    If you've ever played Fallout 3 you may have been impressed with the vastness of that game regarding the places to travel, guns to use, things to shoot, and people to meet.   Rage takes a diffrent approach by offering "quality" over "quantity"  Not saying that Fallout didnt have quality, but Rage gives a smaller, more polished and prettier experince.   You dont have as many places to go, but damn it looks georgous and you even get some sweet rides to take you there (the optional races in those rides are fun too).  You may not level up your character, but you get some wicked high-tech gadgets to become force multiplyers.   There may not be as many guns, but the guns you do get all have a role that never gets tossed aside and you obtain deadly new varities of ammunition  that changes how they operate and the level of carnage they can cause. The graphics are amazing.  The character details are amazing.  The animations and behavior of the things trying to kill you are amazing.  No joke, its great to have one of the Ghosts do a parkor flip off the side of a wall to avoid your shotgun blast.  I was even suprised to notice that a NPC computer controlled ally of mine maintained realistic gun control and even kept their trigger finger outside of the trigger guard until he was ready to shoot.  Its this great level of detail that makes Rage a new experince that I would encourage others to try.  Whats not so amazing?  The way it ends.   It seems like such a great build up for something that doesnt ever seem finished.  Perhaps they put too much detail in other things and they just ran out of time and/or money, but it seems like it ends to abruptly for a proper ending.  Not really timewise, but gameplay wise.Also after completing the main story and the DLC you're going to be quite constrained.  In fallout and borderlands you can at least go around the land and shoot things.... in RAGE ( please correct me if I'm wrong) you cant unless they changed something in an update that I dont know about.  Once you beat an area enough times that area is closed off.  Kinda lame.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 1, 2012
												Being a big fan of any post-apocalyptic media of any kind, I had to buy this when it was 75% off... and I have been very pleasantly surprised. The graphics are different to any other game I've played: they are slightly odd - I don't know the technical reasons why, but the textures from afar look ultra-real, and even the far-distant cliffs and the background horizons are modelled (rather than being 'flat' images). However, sometimes nearby objects can look comparitevly pixelated. Overall though, the graphics are spell-binding. When I first emerged from the Ark, I had to loiter, agape, for some minutes. id have tried to make a 'free roaming' game, and come close to lulling us into beliving that it is one. Certain things make it essentially linear though - the 'internal' levels are 'one route only' and so feel like a simple shooter (I hasten to add that the gameplay is far superior to the tedious shoot-strafe-shoot Doom 3). Also, there is some choice as to the order of missions attempted, but really, it has nothing like the content of other Bethesda titles like Oblivion, Skyrim or Fallout 3. As the Gamespot reviews of Rage correctly say, the characters are animated well and brilliantly imagined, the driving is fun and destructive, and the mini-games are simple but enjoyable. And ok, when you compare Rage to Fallout 3, its an unfair contest. Rage doesn't have even close to the same amount of content (it even has you going back to locations to complete only slightly different missions, evidently to reuse their painstakingly-constructed maps). Having said that, Rage is a step up from Fallout 3 graphically. Overall, if you accept that Rage is a different sort of a game, you won't fail to enjoy it. Rage is all about simple destructive fun, and it looks good while it does it. Highly recommend.

content:
ry 6, 2015
												After three attempts at getting through this game (twice on Steam) and 15 hours of my life, I can safely say that this is the most boring post-apocalyptic "sandbox" game I've ever played.First of all, there is nothing aligning "Rage" with sandbox. The world you're thrown in is absolutely not open and there is fairly little you can do outside of missions. "The Saboteur" is a sandbox game. "Just Cause 2" is a (great!) sandbox game. "Rage", on the other hand, is a dreadful experience of clunky game mechanics, blurry textures with loading delays, cumbersome inventory screens, and most importantly, BORING fetch/kill missions with a little driving mixed in and mini-games that make me want to jump off a building.I can't tell you how many times I've gotten lost within cities or big quest areas (like the Blue Line) without a minimap; it is exclusive for when you're driving around the Wasteland. I also cannot possibly count the amount of times I've tried finding something, coming to a door only to see I can't open it - even inner-city areas are completely devoid of rooms and exploration, unless they're tied to a quest character or a merchant.The graphics of this game - well, we all know how bad they are, and for me no amount of patches and workarounds made a huge difference, except perhaps that the textures are loading a bit faster; but that's still not enough.I have yet to be interested in the soundtrack enough to listen to it outside of the game - the opening cinematic was good but the rest sounded entirely uninteresting.Unless you get this game dirty cheap on a sale, like I did, I suggest you avoid this disaster.

content:
er 22, 2014
												Careful before buying: the game doesn't use steam cloud it only saves locally so back up your saves with Gamesavemanager.This is unimpressive compared to masterpieces from id like Doom and Quake 1-3 mainly because those games redefined and changed everything, but it still has it's merits. To id's credit it is a creative game that has solid, smooth combat and great weapons and enemies, one of the smoothest running engines I've ever played, and also great sound effects. It has great graphics (besides the god awful mushed textures up close) and very nice presentation value and is a lot of fun to play. The combat is really very good, top notch. One big thing that makes combat so awesome is that all weapons sound very good. The weapons sound loud and hard hitting, especially when I blow a guy into outerspace with a point blank shotgun blast and it kabooms in my ears through my headphones.id software worked with Bethesda so Bethesda had some say in it and probably nudged them towards making it a wasteland game like Fallout 3 since it was so wildly popular at the time. That's OK, but I miss the evil satanic neo-gothic stuff from Doom and Quake. It also has a horrible last boss and ending. You do many things and craft and quest and so on, then the game just ends. But id knew they ♥♥♥♥ed that up and there's an expansion that lets you play even after the final boss.This game was an experiment for id to showcase their new engine which is incredible, as I said one of the smoothest game engines I've ever seen. It performs flawlessly. Although the graphics are beyond horrible in some areas, like ground and stationary surface textures. Just a blurry mess. Actually you know what, the graphics in this game just suck balls, period. Fantastic art direction, suck balls graphics quality. Oh and if there is one thing that id absolutely cannot do, it is racing. The racing parts in this game just ♥♥♥♥ing suck and are horribly sleep inducing. Also, the mouse pointer in game menu's, all of them, never feels right. It just doesn't move normally, but loose and crappy.Despite the games numerous merits, it doesn't live up to id's standards when you compare it to Doom and Quake 1-3. It was like they said "we are going to create a good game even if it kills us" and to their credit, they did that, but therein lies the argument that prevented this from being their next mega-hit. But RAGE holds it's own for what its worth: a wasteland FPS with very solid mechanics, a phenominal game engine besides the suck balls graphics, and not much else to complain about other than id's standardized approach to it's production quality.Lets just hope that John Carmack didn't leave id software because this game and future projects are what their production mentality is starting to curve towards. Let's hope that we actually see them bring back the magic when they put out Doom 4.Edit: DOOM 4 is the BEST GAME EVER7.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
2013
												 For years many First-Person shooter RPG Hybrids taken place in some wasteland has been for many of us just a regular tradition each year. With the release of Fallout and even earlier games have made it fun; Rage took up the reins of 2011 for the wasteland First-Person shooter game. Does it stack up as good as the others such as Fallout? Or would it be lost forever, post-apocalyptic style?Story/Design: The story goes that in 2029 the real life meteorite Apophis is on a direct collision mark with Earth and nearly causes mass extinction; however with the world taking precautions they start to send out volunteers in Arks with cryo-genetic hibernation. It didn't go so well, and you are the only survivor of your own particular Ark. After 106 years off that, you step out in the world for the first type, post-apocalypse...Sound familiar? Anyway, the game starts out with a great starting cinematic, yet the story is only decent, if not weak. It takes time that you can try and change the story in general and find out what exactly happened to all the other Arks. The starting point is extremely slow and it took me real motivation to try and push through it in the first hours and not completely stop the game. . Furthermore, just before the game starts to heat up and get you interested it abruptly ends. The ending is certainly jarring (and extremely disappointing) it could serve as a quality story based DLC. The game is quite beautiful though, it honestly depends on your PC though, just like any other game. With the new id tech 5 engine they say it doesn't use any of the same textures twice which is nice; however, this means that your graphics will change once you rotate the camera and will load in accordingly. This can mean textures take in at least a full second or two to load in and can make some gamers lag. It's beautiful, but as a closer look in towns you realize how fuzzy and low-style they are. Overall, I'd like to get this through to everyone, if you're buying Rage then you should NOT be buying it for the story, it's slow and disappointing and forgettable. The textures are nice while driving around, yet in towns it can a whole second or two to load in at least a simple one.Gameplay/Mechanics: This is obviously a First-Person shooter. And I'd like to say that this is a game based off its shooting mechanics and it does a fantastic job of it. It feels smooth enough and has multiple guns to choose from. The game is also a RPG mixed game, obviously trying to take from other wasteland style of games, but is nowhere near as complex as say Fallout, or even a few mechanics of Borderlands. It results in using different type of ammo, selling and trading items, building things with objects for opening doors and other objects. It's simple yet does well. It also has quests and side quests to do multiple things along with just running around, killing, or just collecting. Racing and vehicle combat is also a big part of the game, races are critical to upgrading your vehicle. The driving controls are odd though, realistic they are not and you must keep using it to feel comfortable behind the wheel. The FPS feel is great and well done, the RPG elements are simple yet for some groups can be just what they want, with more experienced RPG players it will seems a bit too simplistic for them. The vehicle combat is actually fun and is a key thing from the game. It's a fun game to play but as I said, just to play, not to hear about the story.Rage is a game not based on story; it tries and fails with disappointment. The combat and gameplay is fun and engaging. The wasteland is beautiful yet with the hiccups it might seem like an aesthetic blemish to some, yet game breaking for others. It's an above-average FPS shooter, but it's just that. Slightly above average, the same bland story as some, and not memorable as I had to force and push myself to get through it. If you want a good FPS, without good story then you can try to get this on sale. If you want story...you're going to need to find something else. 6.8/10
