content:
11, 2013
												RAGE is an extremely fun shooter with a lot of fun weapons,impressive AI,and it makes great use of its somewhat limited level design by throwing interesting enemies at you,like those dudes who run on the walls and grab stuff on the ceiling and will even roll on the ground to avoid your fire.It's one of the very few good modern shooters.The health regen isn't even a handicap to the game,because there is lenty of cover and you don't have to wait for long.I might add that your view doesn't spaz out up and down like in most horrible modern first person shooters.AND YOU ARE NOT FORCED TO ONLY CARRY 2 WEAPONSThe fighting feels visceral,the animations are brilliant,there is a lot of blood and gory headshots,and when enemies explode,they leave a big splat of blood and tiny gibs go everywhere,painting the walls red.The driving aspect of the game is neither fun or interesting,and the races are absolute uninspired garbage and seems to have been thrown in there at the last minute.You'll spend your time between cool epic firefights driving back home to get new missions,and then driving to said missions.With random events like meteors made out of goodies that fall in front of you and you have to catch them.Or bandits you can fight,but it's not nearly as interesting.The vehicles only have 2 weapons,and the game auto locks on an enemy for you.They happen way too often and you should have the option to only make them spawn when you want,or be able to teleport back to town.The story is not really interesting,and gets buried deep underground by the annoying voice acting.It's not badly voiced,but it's pointless.The game takes 5 minutes to tell you ''good job,here is reward.''And you can't skip the dialogs.(or in this case,monologs) so you have to run backwards until the NPC stops talking and come back to him to hear the next part,and keep repeating this until you can finally accept the mission.One of its biggest qualities is the the level design.It's not just the ''point A => cutscene QTE cutscene QTE hide shoot hide shoot cutscene QTE point B end'' formula.There are no cutscenes during fights.Or annoying QTEs.That deserved to be said.The game uses fairly open linear levels,with a bit of exploration.The ''open world'' isn't really that open or that big,but it doesn't affect the game in a negative way.I still wonder how fun it could have been to roam around a huge map,enter a random building,and have super fast paced firefights.There is a little bit of RPG in this game,as you can collect junk,sell it,and craft stuff.Like some kind of door opening thing that will open locked doors that lead to stuff for you to get and sell/use to shoot baddies.You can also craft RC cars that go boom.Overall it's an amazing shooter with small problems that you can easily overcome.And it has fun coop!

content:
3, 2016
												It was a decent game. To start things off we'll talk about the setting. Rage is set in a post apocalyptic wasteland, the scenery is mostly vallies of stone and sand with remnants off dead trees and various other small flora like dune grasses here and there. Not a whole lot,though it is a desert like setting where water is scarce so it makes sense. The general vibe is very steam punkish with a lot of rust and metals with weapons ranging from modified crossbows to machines to plasma cannons etc.. Indoor settings are mostly tech like and/or mutatant infested sewers or a combination of the two.The graphics were well enough. I played through on medium settings and it looked good and ran rather smooth on my laptop. No blocky square head or hands, the animations weren't clunky and looked proper enough for the actions. The controls were easy enough to get accustomed too ( you can change them anyhow if you don't like them in the settings) and were accurate. They were a bit sensitive though.... During gun fights they were well enough but the cursor on menus was insanly sensitive. Straffing was very fast as well, peaking around corners for stealth turned into full blown assaults very quickly lol. The jump button was pretty pointless as well, I couldn't jump over anything at all in the game and I tried just about everything >.< .Sound was alright along with voice acting. Never had to shove my head into my screen to here characters speak or had stuttered speech. Few well known actors voiced.Haven't played alot of multiplayer yet but from what it seems it is  Racing, V.S, and Team version campaign missions from the game. All in all I loved the game and reccomend it to others. My biggest dislike was the fact that after the main quest line there is no free roam.   SPOILER:After Lassard has go you collect the I.D decryptions  just before Marshall has you activate the Ark Capsules  be sure to get all of your exploring and side quests in. After you leave wellsprings for the resistance you can go back to the other settlements at any time, prior to the last mission. As stated I advise you do for the full experience.

content:
2013
												 For years many First-Person shooter RPG Hybrids taken place in some wasteland has been for many of us just a regular tradition each year. With the release of Fallout and even earlier games have made it fun; Rage took up the reins of 2011 for the wasteland First-Person shooter game. Does it stack up as good as the others such as Fallout? Or would it be lost forever, post-apocalyptic style?Story/Design: The story goes that in 2029 the real life meteorite Apophis is on a direct collision mark with Earth and nearly causes mass extinction; however with the world taking precautions they start to send out volunteers in Arks with cryo-genetic hibernation. It didn't go so well, and you are the only survivor of your own particular Ark. After 106 years off that, you step out in the world for the first type, post-apocalypse...Sound familiar? Anyway, the game starts out with a great starting cinematic, yet the story is only decent, if not weak. It takes time that you can try and change the story in general and find out what exactly happened to all the other Arks. The starting point is extremely slow and it took me real motivation to try and push through it in the first hours and not completely stop the game. . Furthermore, just before the game starts to heat up and get you interested it abruptly ends. The ending is certainly jarring (and extremely disappointing) it could serve as a quality story based DLC. The game is quite beautiful though, it honestly depends on your PC though, just like any other game. With the new id tech 5 engine they say it doesn't use any of the same textures twice which is nice; however, this means that your graphics will change once you rotate the camera and will load in accordingly. This can mean textures take in at least a full second or two to load in and can make some gamers lag. It's beautiful, but as a closer look in towns you realize how fuzzy and low-style they are. Overall, I'd like to get this through to everyone, if you're buying Rage then you should NOT be buying it for the story, it's slow and disappointing and forgettable. The textures are nice while driving around, yet in towns it can a whole second or two to load in at least a simple one.Gameplay/Mechanics: This is obviously a First-Person shooter. And I'd like to say that this is a game based off its shooting mechanics and it does a fantastic job of it. It feels smooth enough and has multiple guns to choose from. The game is also a RPG mixed game, obviously trying to take from other wasteland style of games, but is nowhere near as complex as say Fallout, or even a few mechanics of Borderlands. It results in using different type of ammo, selling and trading items, building things with objects for opening doors and other objects. It's simple yet does well. It also has quests and side quests to do multiple things along with just running around, killing, or just collecting. Racing and vehicle combat is also a big part of the game, races are critical to upgrading your vehicle. The driving controls are odd though, realistic they are not and you must keep using it to feel comfortable behind the wheel. The FPS feel is great and well done, the RPG elements are simple yet for some groups can be just what they want, with more experienced RPG players it will seems a bit too simplistic for them. The vehicle combat is actually fun and is a key thing from the game. It's a fun game to play but as I said, just to play, not to hear about the story.Rage is a game not based on story; it tries and fails with disappointment. The combat and gameplay is fun and engaging. The wasteland is beautiful yet with the hiccups it might seem like an aesthetic blemish to some, yet game breaking for others. It's an above-average FPS shooter, but it's just that. Slightly above average, the same bland story as some, and not memorable as I had to force and push myself to get through it. If you want a good FPS, without good story then you can try to get this on sale. If you want story...you're going to need to find something else. 6.8/10

er 22, 2012
												Nice game concept and post-apocalyptic game-world but the eye straining style just tickles my brain, in a bad way. After about a hour of playing i had to take a break because i felt nauseous and my eye's felt dry. It's the same strain level as Jazz Jackrabbit... The controls are a bit dodgy, the feeling of a bad PC port is big in this game. By tapping the strafe button you take a big step to the side instead of a normal step in all of the other FPS's so the controls can be called quite bulky, invisible walls are used almost as much as in the old-school Medal of honor titles which means that you will encounter allot of these, and the inventory system is just bad, you can clearly see that it was designed for a controller. The texture loads a bit slow, so be prepared for allot of texture loads while you play.Overall the weapons and character models look nice, the intro sucked me right into the game and atmosphere but as soon as the game really began it lost all of its charm. It's worth the 5 euro's i spend on it but if it is above this price i would spend the money on a game like Fallout 3 since this is a better alternative.After playing for 90 minutes i rate it a 6,5/10, mainly due to the dodgy controls and eye straining style. This also gets my "Bad port" stamp of disapproval.

content:
er 26, 2013
												For me the only frustrations that arose with RAGE surrounded the fact that it comes so close to greatness.  A troubled PC launch seemed to kill the multiplayer community and the DLC adds little to the experience.  Yet even the limp ending and slim illusion of player freedom cannot hide the fact that ID know all about shooting things in the face.  That is where the fun is to be had in this game; shoot all of the things, then throw spiderbots, turrets and boomerangs into the mix.  The world and character design are enjoyable, although you never really interact with them in a meaningful way.  Whilst the racing and mini games are briefly entertaining, they prove to be little more than resource grinding.  RAGE also harbours RPG and crafting pretensions that do not get in the way, but feel strangely unimportant as a result.  If any one of these elements worked as well as the shooting, ID would have been on to a real winner here.  Just imagine what this could have been like if they had nailed them all......As it stands, RAGE has a solid core hidden amongst elements that either time, money or skill (all three?) prevented from truly coming together as a whole.  Seven out of ten seems fair, perhaps the ambition sends it a point either side of that mark, depending on how you take to the games weaker elements.  Should ID have focused their effort a little better?  Perhaps; the game shines when played with a controller and employing a gung ho approach to ammo and resource expenditure, as the title would seem to suggest.  It's just a shame that other aspects of the game never hit those heights.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
er 6, 2014
												RAGE was delivered as a fresh new franchise (on release) which is developed and published from id software, and as a huge long-time id fan there was no question of me getting this title. It's set in a post-apocolyptic world (somewhat of a cliche' these days), and you're one of the last people from before this time preserved with microscopic nanites flowing through your blood. There's a high price to the Authority and the Rebels for you and/or your head.Although the high res graphics are locked out (which you can change through internet research), and it was off to a sketchy release loaded with issues - but then why should you trust any developer on release or close to on PC titles?The game looks nice, performs well and introduces some nice mechanics. It presents a challenge and has a nice story which you can believe and immerse yourself in. For me personally, I loved the Rebar gun which was a part of the DLC package on Steam. The rebar gun launches a solid stick of ~400mm rebar or rio as we call it in Australia, and it can pin opponents to nearly any object, it can take heads off, it can take out multiple enemies with a really well placed shot, and it will terminate larger opponents with a couple of well placed shots - it does however take only one piece of rebar and reload speeds are slow. You are able to recover the rebar once launched, and it is the star of the game, so much fun.It is however very linear in the campaign, but once you're off campaign there's much more freedom. There are a lot of annoying invisible walls, and the trading/shop seems a little tedious if you want to be well stocked at all times, but you can compete in an array of races to gain some currency.Overall it is a fantastic game, but for the average user I wouldn't rush about to complete it. If you're into FPS games and/or into id software's style I would say it's a must own. When you get a chance, make sure you enjoy this title - there'll be another one on the way once DOOM is released next year!

That's exactly what I expect from ID and that's exactly what I got.

												Great post-apocalyptic game with stunning graphics, considering it was released in 2011 it still can compete with some present games. If you like crawling around in deep tunnels of neverending sewer network, passing through abandoned city or fighting bandit clans this game is for you! Lots of minigames, including great racing system with multiple wehicle types and tons of upgrades for them this game has a bit of every post-apocalyptic rpg and pristinely combines it together. Oh did i mentioned it has cooperative missions and multiplayer. So i'm gonna take this slow, so you can unerstand it: "Just   Buy  It!"

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 22, 2014
												While this game has a lot of rough edges and if you do buy it you might want to look up some config or visual modification tools in order to make it work for you the game is well done for the most part.  While it may not be as open as some other FPS/RPG games out there it does bring a few good things to the table that others do not have.  The enemy models, animations and reaction are very well done, fluid and depending on which faction you're fighting against it might play out differently.  NPC interactions are good, and facial animations are very well done making them feel organic at times.  The story is a bit rough in places and if you've read anything about this game you will already know that the ending is well not great to say the least.  While I do wish there was more to the game then what is offered it was mostly fun while it lasted.  The tech in the game world is very nice and refreshing; the in game crafting is rather well done and very quick allowing you to use different items against different enemy types.  The game could have been better, defiantly, the story could have been a bit better and my god the texture pop in is the worst I have ever seen in my life, however it may not have entirely been iD’s fault based on what I’ve read.  Even on current gen systems you will at times get odd FPS loss and major screen tearing and if you have an ATI card you might want to look else where because I have read that people are STILL having trouble running this game.  If you can buy/find it on sale like I did when I got it, it’s well worth the money, especially once you tinker with the game engine to make it look/run a little better.  It’s far better then anything Gearbox has done to date I can honestly say that, it’s not a boring motionless world with singular friendly/peaceful NPCs, however it is no Fallout 3, it is very much in between, far better gun play then FO3 for sure however.

If your waiting for Mad Max and also played the hell out of Borderlands, try Rage. I think you'll like it.

content:
y 27, 2015
												I'm a decent way in to the game now - got all the gear, fairly certain where the end game is headed. I definitely have a good feel for the features and style of the game, and while I've selected yes - I do recommend the game - that comes with several important caveats. iD have created a shooter with some really interesting ideas in RAGE. Unfortunately, it suffers from a stunning lack of ideas in many important respects, also - most of which have to do with the actual playing of the game. It's very old fashioned, in many ways, which you may view as a good thing if you're nostalgic for FPS games of old. Weapons assigned to number buttons, 1-10? Check. Unlock them in sequence, just as they're needed? Check. Tight corridors and fast enemies for shotgun splooshing? Check. Open spaces and cover loving baddies for sniper or machine gun play? Check. Oh, and here's a crossbow. Because crossbow. The enemies, while spouting some interesting dialogue, are of very limited variety, models reused with alarming frequency. Likewise, their move sets are limited. The challenge arises here in presenting you with more enemies, or sometimes enemies with higher hit points, than in providing smarter baddies. I can't think of a single interesting villian - or hero, for that matter - in the game so far. The characters are massively cliché. Attempts at making the world intimidating, or even horrifying in terms of things you see in bandit camps, are immediately undone by slapstick bad guys with cartoonish animation. Also, it's always jarring to be lectured endlessly about the dangers of this horrifying world, how every step outside the secure towns is taking your life in your hands as hordes of unspeakable monstrosities await the frothy goodness of your very blood...and then to saunter from place to place on a quad bike or stupidly heavily armed buggy without so much as an insult shouted from a nearby hillock. RAGE is not a dangerous world. Glasgow pubs are, literally and figuratively, more dangerous than RAGE. This is a game with too many ideas, some of which conflict stylistically with each other. And despite, or perhaps because of, the implementation of these ideas, other things are just left to the side. The world is very small, with some areas getting reused numerous times, just filled with different baddies. There's no true free roaming, in that you follow a limited set of canyons to a few major hubs. Occasionally you blow up a dam, or other obstruction, to unlock new canyons and a new hub. Quests are just places to go and collect things, with set pieces all along the way. A little bit on rails for a modern shooter. RAGE also features an incredibly annoying set of outdated features which aren't directly related to the gameplay. ALL the button prompts are for xBox controllers, even if one isn't hooked up. I know it's a console port, but that's just lazy and off-putting, and the mapping for controls is far from explicit about what the assigned key will do. The game actually prompts you to save on some occasions (only seen this in DLC missions so far, to be fair), stating that "The action is about to HOT up, better save". Any immersion you managed to achieve in this game, you just shattered with one pop-up. It may sound like griping, but the menu is just plain silly. Select quit game...get the "Are you sure" message. Select yes...get dumped to the opening splash screen, prompted to press enter. Press enter, get the main menu. Select quit game, and...get the are you sure window *again*. The game also features something worth special mention: The Most Pointless Weapon Upgrade Ever. Yes, the MPWUE can be found right here in RAGE! An otherwise neat little gun, the Authority LMG, features an optic with decent magnification, good accuracy, large magazines, and an armour piercing ammo variety. It's a staple, and it comes in very handy. And you can buy a laser pointer for it. Now this would be fairly useless anyway, as the shotgun takes care of anything short range and for long range - duh, optic. But the laser beam actually fades away within a few virtual inches of the gun. Even if you stand beside a wall, you realise it's just "painted on" - no red dot ever appears. And, and - there's an aiming reticule anyway! Granted, I've never tried disabling it. Maybe you can. Even so, this somewhat expensive upgrade feels like a lot of ideas in this game: it doesn't matter whether it WORKS, we just think it's cool. So why would I recommend RAGE? The vehicle combat between hubs actually feels pretty good. They got the feel and speed very nearly perfect. The weapons, while outlandish and old school, are very fun, especially the alternative ammunition types. Some of the town characters are kind of fun - Kvasir is a favourite, with the little cute robot head on his shoulder nodding or shaking its head along with his conversation. The crafting aspect is pretty well implemented without being intrusive. The little turrets, sentry bots, RC bomb cars and so on, are all fun to scavenge for and use. The areas you go to for missions - should have mentioned, they load up when you enter, they're not part of the open canyons directly - are well laid out, though the path is fairly linear. A little exploration is rewarded with spare parts and such. RAGE kinda sorta tries to be a more action oriented Fallout, but falls way short of the depth and story of that remarkable world. It also tries to be a single player Borderlands, a bit, and that's just absurd. A showcase of great ideas pinned on an ungainly donkey, pick it up cheap, laugh at its absurdity, enjoy smooshing mutants with an arsenal of stuff...but don't expect awe or major adrenaline rushes, nor a deep, post apocalyptic experience.

content:
0, 2014
												This game tries to be a Shooter, Racer, & RPG but fails at all 3 of them.  The races have 2 modes of difficulty.  Baby mode easy & stupidly designed difficult.  Some races are checkpoint races that show you the checkpoints, but do nothing about showing you the order.  So, you will have to try multiple times just to figure out which order you have to go in to beat the time limit.  The world is open but huge & empty with little going on other than a bandit car or two, forcing you to drive everywhere to make any progress. The shooting is average & linear like any other Id game.  Invisible walls aplenty.  The RPG part is the game tries to be sort of Fallout 3 style with quests, but just... fails... entirely...  Every side quest is "Go kill this.  Get said item.  Return."  It really feels like they were just being lazy with the story.  Voice actors are great at least.As for the Co-Op, I never got a chance to try it because YOU HAVE TO UNLOCK IT by beating the campaign mode first & I just couldn't take the single player anymore...  After you beat all the races & get all the car unlocks there isn't really much point to keep playing. It gets incredibly boring after a few hours.  The online multiplayer is also just the races.  That's it.  So, this game is pretty much just an action racer with shooting minigames.

er 31, 2015
												Rage was a much better game than it got credit for. Smooth gun play, beautiful backdrops, and relatively enjoyable NPCs. However, it took heat for a few, notable reasons: First, at launch it was a buggy, ♥♥♥♥♥tormed MESS of a game! Second, the end of the game feels like a friggen "mid-point" in the story arc - but nope, that's the ending. And third: The Id Tech 5 engine has issues with particle textures. That being said, up close things don't always looks so amazing.All and all, the game IS good, it just wasn't good ENOUGH. I'd say I feel this game needs a "meh" or "alright" thumbs rating more thant "good" or "bad". If it's on sale, and you like the Fallout type of world (this is similar in some ways), this is worth your time to mess around with if anything else. 4.99 or 8.99 would be fair prices

content:
y 8, 2016
												Let's start immediately with the only thing I didn't like: weak finale. Really? Come on Id, you've a long list of weak finales (quake, quake2,doom3 was better though) but this is probably the weakest.Ok. Cons list done. Apart from that, Rage is probably a MASTERPIECE. You start being an old-era apocalypse survivor and, before you have enough time to understand what's happening you're diving in a BEAUTIFUL post-apocalyptic HUGE scenario. A world, so various that goes from broken highways to dead cities, filthy sewers and many many more.Graphics, The detail is UNBELIEVABLE, every single aspect of every map is placed carefully and planned deeply. You can almost smell the garbage in wasted garage or gasoline in Shrouded Bunker. It's awesome how level designers pay attention to every single insignificant detail. Beautiful. I didn't see any popping artifacts, I must say, Probably because my video card is very old engine just decides to use low texture by default (most of all in Dead City level apparently), which it's ok for me.Gameplay, It's id, come on, Obviously the best in town. Every shot you fire it seems that really hurts enemies, and their bodies react with damage + previous movement so it really seems that a running mutant, coming after you, after been shot to death, has still some inertia to die in front of you making two more steps. This is art, imo.I noticed they add a little "RPG" addition, like the possibility to buy / sell items and to create objects from blueprints but developers decided that, very wisely imo, this is an FPS and has to remain an FPS, so this is the only "non FPS" insertion they added.Environment. Various, huge, well detailed. East and west waste land differ very much one from the other.Open Word. The entire game level is open, sure. But, during missions, you've the sensation that there's only one way to finish the mission and one way to follow to reach the end of the level but, it's done so beautifully that imo is a pro and not a con.Summary. I really don't see a reason why not to buy (maybe in sale if it's possible) this masterpiece from ID Software. If new Doom will be at least 40% good as Rage, it will be awesome!!

content:
y 9, 2015
												In this game you can carry 10 weapons (and probably unlimited ammo)  and shoot mutants along with  high-tech supersoldiers in a postapocalyptic world. You can also be a race driver with your very own cars. Pro:The combat system is excellent (these guys made the Doom series..), and I must mention, that the enemy death and combat  animations are exemplary. If I shoot somebody in the stomach, he falls to the ground, then drags himself to the nearest cover, and prepares to die. But he's still alive, so until then, shoots some bullet at you. If I hit somebody's feet, it limps, like in reality. You can be an engineer and construct items such as sentry bots and turrets. These bots are overpowered in my opinion, you can spawn 2 at the same time, and they clear the area for you. The races are exciting, but won the first place always at the first try. The minigames are also cool. Never facede any bugs (fell off the map once, but it was my fault). Contra:However, you can't really jump. Apart from the race fields, the whole game is very linear. You go into a building through the front door,  kick some ♥♥♥ inside, then return to that door again. And almost every single mission is like this.  The characters are boring, but their mimics and gestures are detailed. The textures sometimes look correct, but when they don't, they're ugly and low detailed. You have to save manually, because the game saves only at the beginning and the end of the mission. Forgot that when I started, and had to start again a mission. This game offers much more then 25 hours of content, in overall, it's a great FPS. If it has 75% off, or more, don't hesitate, buy it!

												I have read pretty much everything and its opposite about that game. So I wanted to write a review, to try to give a comprehensive list of the pros/cons of that game.First of all, this game is NOT a Role Playing Game. Of course, like every single game, it can fit into its definition, since you play the role of a character in an imaginary world. Now, it is not what is conventionally accepted as a RPG. This game has no character levels, it has no skills, it has no skill-tree either of course, and so on.This game is a shooter. By the people who invented the genre, id Software. Now, if it is from the people who invented the genre, how can it only have a User Score of "49" (at the time of writing) on metacritic? The reason is simple: this game is really different from what id Software usually does (or did. I did not play, by far, all the id Software shooters; but I played Doom and Quake).So, what are the pros and the cons?Pros:The overall experience is rather original, refreshing, with a definitely solid and consistent shooter feeling (think of other id Software games, the weapon handling is really close to that). The id Tech 5 graphical engine is incredibly slick, does a wonderful job, and even if the textures are sometimes ugly, or even horrible, when inspected from up close; the game has really neat graphics.In addition, the world, even if not so deep (remember, this is by no mean a RPG), has some interesting aspects, and the artists did an unbelievable job making each part of it unique and authentic.Cons:id Software used to do PC games. For a company that pretty much invented the FPS genre, it was perfectly logical. Whereas I can understand why publishers decide to make every single game available on consoles, it still is a mystery for me when developers also take that direction. Not for all games, of course, Mario and Sonic were totally fitting for consoles, and so were many arcade games I played as a kid.But for FPSes, one can only wonder. I know that the fingers are probably the most precise appendices we have, but even; how can someone imagine to replace two hands with five and three fingers (for the keyboard and the mouse respectively), plus one arm (the mouse movement has more amplitude, and therefore, more precision, than a stick) by only four fingers (thumbnails and indexes), for the same result?And even if id Software managed (thanks to their extensive experience?) not to get the main gameplay cluttered by such a decision, ALL the rest of the game has been affected. Not only the interfaces.And the game also features some mandatory races, there are achievements for random games (random achievements? what's next, unobtainable achievements?), and trying to 100% the game will be an incredibly frustrating experience, for those reasons.It's also worth mentioning that the difficulty is somewhat low (that goes with the "console" aspect I presume: the game has to be accessible to as many people as possible), or at best inconsistent (the Scorchers DLC increased the difficulty a bit, but also gives the nail gun, which has an unlimited ammo (rebar) and a rail gun mode, allowing to see the enemies in advance, and even to kill them without exposing yourself), even in ultra nightmare (which is turning the game into a binary experience (who shoots first) rather than into a harder one), and that in spite of the obvious efforts to make the game as non-linear as possible; all the missions are constructed with the scheme: talk to X, go to Y, kill all the baddies along the way.Bottom line:The game still is worth some money, as it has a strong shooter feeling, various encounters, an awesome atmosphere. But don't expect the usual id Software FPS, it is not.Additional Note:I got an "Anarchy edition" (the pre-order bonus) key in order to get all the additional content. I would recommend to do the same, or at least, to unlock the pre-order content (there is a console command for that) when you play the game, as it deeply changes the gameplay.

content:
r 28, 2015
												This is one of those games where you have a lot of fun until the very last moment. You REALLY wanna think this is a great game, and you'd be right for the most part. Excellent premise, good gameplay, great graphics, even for someone who has bad graphics card, it's not demanding for something that looks soo good. But then, the music happens and it's sorta, lacking something, it isn't bad, but it's not quite great either. Then there's the gameplay, yes the FPS is in corridors and the like that's similar to Metro 2033, but honestly you'd need it to be in such of a place, it sorta fits. The story isn't too bad either, much better than some of the FPS games I've played, although nowhere close to Metro and other story driven FPS's. It does leave a sense of "disappointment" at the end of the game. Great level designing though. Overall, I say yes on getting it and playing it, at 20 dollars? No, at 15? Yes, and if you're a fan of Metro, or Borderlands, even Fallout, then it's a must at 10 dollars.

y 3, 2016
												I played it all of the way through once. The overall feel of this game is like if Borderlands and Fallout 3 had a baby and then dropped it repeatedly on it's head.I can't quite put my finger on what it is that I find irritating about the gameplay here, but one of the main things is that it feels like a jumble of ideas, none of which quite fit together fluidly.Visually this game is a complete mess, which I attributed originally to it being based on a pretty sub-par engine that does not support SLI setups.  Having attempted to replay it on a brand new GTX 980 Ti and still experienced the same issues (blurred, low-def textures, horrendous pop-in issues etc.) I can safely say that it is just a terrible engine.I know that this game is probably right up a lot of people's street, but it really is not up mine.Pros:-Some fun moments with the gunplay/driving-Interesting scenery when viewed from a distance!Cons:-Terrible engine (with regards to graphical issues)-Iffy storyline-Parts of it plays like a dumbed mix of the boring elements of Fallout game combined with the same from Borderlands.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Rage is a first-person shooter set in a post-apocalyptic world that offers plenty of enemies to shoot, and a variety of other mini games to play.As far as the world is concerned, there will definitely be a lot of comparisons to Borderlands. It is certainly a darker, and grittier version of that world, but it is less expansive and even less characterful than Borderlands. Also, the game tries to progress the story through a series of quest-givers to make it feel even more like Borderlands, however without any of the RPG elements such as character progression, talent trees, or loot, it seems out of place. In fact, because there are no RPG elements, the story could have been presented in a much more immersive way. The game tries to add in other diversions to make the world feel more immersive. Crafting allows you to create various gadgets and weapons, but you can easily get through the game without crafting anything. Often, it is simply easier to just buy whatever you want instead of crafting it. There are a variety of mini-games, including a card game where you can collect cards found throughout the world. However, not everyone in this world plays it. In fact, only a very few NPCs play this game, and they can be beat without finding all the "best" cards, so it takes the incentive away from trying to hunt down the cards. The game also tries to shoehorn in a driving aspect and even lets you upgrade all the parts of the vehicle: and you can only get these upgrades through a currency you get from racing. But in the end, the racing is not really challenging nor particularly fun. So finally, that leaves the shooting element of the game. There are certainly many enemies to shoot in this game. But none of your guns seem to pack a visceral punch. They don't sound or feel strong enough, and even when at point blank range with a shotgun, most average-grunt enemies still require 2 to 3 shots to down. All-in-all, Rage is a game that has many dimensions, but none of them are fleshed out particularly well. If you are a fan of first person shooters, you may find some interest in playing through this title, but it's certainly not going to be a title you will have a great experience playing, nor will it be particularly memorable. It's pretty much the definition of "middle of the road."5/10 "Mediocre"

content:
r 8, 2014
												I would definitely recommend buying this game. It has a very Mad Max vibe and provided hours of entertainment. There is a standard FPS weapon spread (pistol, shotgun, SMG, AR, etc) and a fair variety of enemies to shoot at. I found the story to be standard post apocalypse fair but this games take on it is good. There is a decent amount of sidequests and even some races both with and without weapons to provide some more thrills. Vehicles and weapons can be customized as the story progresses. There is also decent multiplayer based off events that take place during campaign to keep you going after the campaign is finished.

												At every possible moment this game threatens to become a good shooter.  There's really no reason it shouldn't be.  It's got a gorgeous graphics engine, entertaining guns... what else do you need?  Oh right.  What we don't have here is pacing, good level design or interesting enemies.  On top of that the game just decides to end at one arbitrary point.  On my first playthrough I got through the whole game without ever firing the game's 'super weapon'.  I was saving it for a climactic boss fight or final level that never actually came.Too easy, as well.  I played through on nightmare and felt no sense of accomplishment having beaten it whatsoever.

												(review for single-player only)RAGE is a strange game. It's a mash-up of different scenarios that doesnt really fit together. It's one part Combat Cars Racing game, one part Mad Max, one part Steam, one part Zombie fps and a small but significant part sci-fi. If the dev's had only stuck to one or two and then really seen that through, it would have been great.The mechanics are good, the main story is ok to a start, side stories and quests are easy to find and do, character progression is ok, but not great but somewhere in mid-game, the devs just stopped working and the result is not what the game could have been.Too bad really, I really liked it the first hrs.It's not really a bad game, I just got really disapointed after awhile.Buy it on sale if you wanna shoot stuff in a mad max futuristic steamish world, and race cars at the same time.

content:
r 3, 2014
												There is a lot of things I dislike about this game, but I still quite enjoy playing it. But there is some things that just irritates me about it. Let's start of with what I dislike.Negative:*You do not have an in-game town/world map, kind of sucks cause I'm one of those guys who likes to explore everything and check off certain areas as "done" with memorizing the areas through world map. On the other hand the game seem to be so linear that you don't need one.*The jump seems worthless, there are obstacles in the game that's not even up to your knees that you can't jump across, which makes me think "why did they even give you the option to use jump at all?". You can't even climb over desks, or big windows with stuff in it, you have to get a lock grinder or whatever it's called to blow up the door. That's so poor.*A headshot with the crappy pistol doesn't kill the enemy, not even 1 feet away. A bullet through the skull on a human being should kill him. (And no, I do not mean the guys with helmets)*The co-op was a bit dissapointing and really short, I was expecting being able to play full campaign with my brother and not some short missions. Maybe I did my research badly before purchasing the game.*Using bandages or creating them seem to be quite useless. I mean you do regenerate full health by just not getting shot anwyay and if you badly need a bandage you're probably screwed over anyway cause you need to swap to the bandages from whatever you're currently using, like HE grenades or whatever. A heal button is missed in those scenarios, like pressing "H" on your keyboard.*The mouse feels bad when you're in the menu, checking inventory, quests and things like that. Feels like it's lagging.*In combat you can't lean!! I hate that you can't lean and take cover, best you can do is to crouch behind a desk or things a like and just stand up to shoot and then sit again. I think it's rreally poor that you can't lean when your opponents can do all kind of stuff, lean, jump over desks, climb though windows, take their arm up with gun only shooting at you while taking cover.Postive:*The vehicles looks good and are fun to drive.*The FPS is overall nice, except you can't lean!*The enviroments and graphics are okay for being a couple of years old game, don't see why people complain over it really.*The enemies move good and make up for the lack of leaning.*Quests are OK.Overall, there is more negative things to say about the game then positive.I would recommend this game at a low price on sale, but no chance of getting it at it's full price, there for I do NOT recommend buying this game. It kills some time sure, but if you're out after a good fps game, spend your money on something else.

number of helpful: 20 of 39 people (51%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
2, 2015
												Just another spam spawning, bullet sponge rail shooter with mediocre graphics and AI.Honestly, Rage is a step backward from the 2009 release of Wolfenstein.As with every other iD installment, area triggers spam in mobs, even in areas you just cleared. The term "one clip, one kill" applies here, as mobs which aren't mutants will require a full magazine pumped into them to take them down. It takes a minimum of two head shots from the sniper rifle, which is just a forced waste of ammo. One human enemy in white armor took 3 and 1/2 magazines of ammo to drop, and that was at 5 paces using short controlled bursts so no bullets missed. It was not a boss, but just a trash mob bad guy.Graphics.I keep seeing people praising the graphics of this game, but cannot see why. I got it shortly after it was released, and even then it was sub par compared to other titles. Sure, outdoor scenes can look quite picturesque overall, but the moment you get near any items, their mediocre look really shows. It's as if, even when on the highest graphics settings, that Mipmap number 2 is being used. Some items in the game haven't even been properly UVW mapped, so they just have distorted, splotchy pixels on them. I feel this is a symptom of iD being bought out by Bethesda. Several of us had been discussing whether Bethesda would bring iD down, or iD would bring Bethesda up back when iD was acquired. Unfortunately, Bethesda won, and iD's quality has suffered.Maybe it's due to the game being a port, but that is just breaking the 8th commandment of good game development and not an excuse for releasing a bad looking game on the PC.Gameplay and AI.The game handles like your average iD game. Mouse wheel through some of the guns (have to hit the numbers on the keyboard to access the rest), shoot spamming mobs of respawning bad guys, run out of ammo and punch the rest to death while strafing backward. Grab quest item and repeat. The formula worked better in the original Doom.The AI seems like it wants to work, but frequently just starts bouncing bad guys around until you Whack-A-Mole them to death one or two bullets at a time. After an hour in game, it becomes apparent that the AI is sorely lacking, and the game becomes painfully redundant and predictable. Maybe I just played too many iD titles over the decades.If you like redundant rail shooters with mediocre graphics, AI and love spamming hordes coming and going, then grab this game. If you want any kind of sophistication or thought provoking gameplay, avoid it like the plague.After thought.iD attempted to include aspects of all types of genres, and did manage to mix them together well. They even included card games. So you have rail shooter, racing/demolition derby, platformer/killhouse, Magic cards all in one game. I don't play Magic or Borderlands because I don't like Magic or Borderlands. I bought Rage because I thought I was getting another Doom style experience according to their hype. Nope.

content:
, 2016
												The game isn't terrible, but it has too many faults to be worth buying in this day and age, where we have so many great games out there. -After a certain point in the game, maybe 7 hours in, I started to get dizzy whenever I played it. Once I beat the area where it all began, I was fine again. However a bit later it came back, and it turns out that a lot of areas in the last half of the game, just induse dizziness. -Enemies soak up bullets so much! I expect 30 bullets to mean I potentially have 30 kills in my magazine, if I get headshots. In Rage this means 1 kill, maybe 1 kill and injuring another enemy. Boring as ****-It is super linear, and you get no choices anywhere, except for what weapons to use and what upgrades to put on your car.-There is no sensitivity option for your mouse, so you just end up sliding all across the menu, never getting the mouse where you want it to be.It's okay to play and certainly not the worst I've had, but it could have been done so much better. Skip this game.5/10 my lowest rating of all time.

content:
r 13, 2011
												I don't know, Rage isn't all that bad. The game does look great, but there are so many technical issues that prevented me from truly enjoying it. The fact that V-sync, at first, wasn't implemented was a bad choice. The texture pop-in was awful as well. Combine this with the freezing problem (every few minutes the game freezes for at least 1-2 seconds) and I'm sure you'll understand what I mean.The gameplay itself is like any other shooter. With some added RPG elements. You'll  collect a lot of worthless junk (which is a shame) and complete simple, sometimes fun, quests. But since there is no real reward for the sidequests there isn't much incentive to do them at all. You'll gain money and some licenses for your vehicle, but no weapons, schematics or anything else. Not even XP. So in the end there's no feeling you're getting any stronger. A missed opportunity. The driving segments are actually ok, but quite easy.Anyway, I did have fun with it, but I expected more to be honest.[Rating: 81/100]

												The best way I can sum up Rage is... if you are interested in playing Rage, you've already played this game. It is the next generic post-apocolypse shooter. It's like the sampler appetizer that has just a little bit of pieces of other games. However, this is the best looking of these games. Some of the textures look like total crap, but some areas and vistas look very nice. The game does take a lot of hard drive space for a fairly short game. Overall, it wasn't bad. It took around 13 hours to finish. The story is generic. Most of the combat is done in linear corriders. I didn't care for the hit detection when shooting enemies. Shoot them once and you gotta wait to shoot them again or the hit won't register. A lot of bullets and time were wasted having to wait through the AI recovery  god frame animations so the next bullet will register. Most of the exploration is done with vehicles that let you travel the map. I'd recommend getting Rage if it's on sale and you want some mindless fun. It is unremarkable in every way, but I still managed to have some fun with it.

er 30, 2016
												It's unfortunate that RAGE has been subjected to so much negativity. I'm not sure what the origins of it are. Perhaps people expected something different, perhaps people expecting something more on some level because it was the next big game by id. I always loved RAGE. Pretty much everything about it. It plays superbly, being one of the few shooters I've ever played where firing a weapon actually feels powerful and great. It has AI that, while not smart in the sense that FEAR did, they are fun to fight because they move so oddly and realistic at times. I just started playing the new DOOM today and that game is just not for me. Having to search the environment to find something specific is just so boring in that game. I recognize that DOOM just isn't doing something that I like. In the same way I feel that RAGE was subjected to such criticism because it did something a lot of people didn't like. But it is a fantastic game if you like the thing it's going for, because it nails it.(For the record, I played RAGE on 360 when it came out. Intending to play it now on PC, which is why my play time is effectively 0 hours as of this writing).

content:
3
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine RAGE is a game developed by id Software and published by Bethesda Game Studios. RAGE is a great game. Really enjoyed the vast majority of it. RAGE is an excellent first person shoot that puts many modern cash-grab shooters to shame. The game feels like it was inspired by the Mad Max seriesThe game has some excellent environments which are immersive, atmospheric, detailed and unique. Some novel weaponswith a very good crafting system. There are various enemy types and also some interesting and unique NPCs. RAGE offers a long and polished campaign which you get more than your money's worthHowever, RAGE's ending isn't very fleshed outIt should be noted that a small few of the weapons are crap on the higher difficulties. This is frustrating at first, but it promotes the use of some of the more unusual ammo (rebars, pop rockets, kill-bursts) which makes for a way better experience. There are many ammo types, some really unique, which makes it great fun to experimentRAGE is a unique and interesting first person shooter which breaks away from traditional FPS games RECOMMENDED :)

content:
24, 2016
												I like this game. It is a few years old now but the graphics are still fairly good overall. Overall it is a first-person shooter style game, but they added in a driving/racing aspect that not only seems to work fairly well, but to me adds a degree of realism to a post-apocolyptic world that so many other games seem to lack. And unlike some other games, while you can just walk around out on the main map; taking the buggy or the monarch to drive around definitely gets you there both faster and safer. There is a good amount to do in this game aside from the main quest line in the form of side quests and challenges, as well as several easter eggs from the older id software games that are just kinda cool to collect.Now for the bad. Thw game is fairly linear overall. You can miss out on things by progressing the main storyline too far too fast, and I'm not a big fan of that in open-world games. It's not too bad as long as you do optional side quests first then the main 1 but on initial playthrough it might not be obvious. Also, might just be because I'm late to the party, as in I did not buy this game when it was brand new, but there is never anybody on the multiplayer side of this so I can't unlock the rest of my acheivements. not a huge deal, but a little disappointing.Overall, like I said, I really do enjoy the game. I would rate the overall experience as about a 7 out of 10. Definitely worth trying.

content:
22, 2016
												I acquired RAGE on a sale, and for the price I paid, I'd recommend the experience.  The world is gorgeous, in a post-apocalyptic, Fallout-like style, with some obvious Fallout-like ripoffs.  Still, it's worth it just to experience some of the really immersive visuals.  The characters and people are reasonably good, beautifully crafted, fully voiced with a variety of personalities (even if some of the acting is forced).  Also, the first "Dead City" experience was really memorable.The game is largely good, but suffers from a lack of direction and from trying to do & to be too much.  The crafting system is interesting and provides some value, but largely unnecessary to complete the game.  The various minigames, too, are value-added, but in the same way that finding spare change in your pocket is value-added.  The vehicles actually drive very nicely and are enjoyable, and the vehicular combat isn't bad, but the entire racing circuit side-game is virtually mandatory and--as such--is a detriment.The game is arguably broken up into three sections, by "hub".  The first and third sections are really short, while the second is probably over-long.  The first section, being short, makes sense.  Its an intro to the game; the starting quest hub.  The brevity of the third hub, however, and the entire third section of the storyline--including the anticlimactic end stage and ending--feels shockingly unfinished, especially compared with some real gems in the section section (Wellspring), most notably the first visit to the Dead City.Ultimately, I'd recommend the game, if only to experience the first half to two-thirds of it.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
y 26, 2016
												It seems that success was never in Rage's destiny. id Software (known for their genre-defining shooters, Wolfenstein 3D and Doom) released their 2011 open-world shooter in a post-Fallout 3 gaming landscape, choosing to leave their world fairly empty and uneventful aside from car combat encounters. It's testament to id Software's brilliance at making a polished combat system that the many flaws Rage has don't massively detract from the fun you'll have playing through it. It's glaringly apparent throughout Rage that much work has gone into the combat. Guns feel great to fire, with multiple modes of fire and different kinds of ammo to suit the varied situations and enemies you'll be encountering. There's a decent selection of them too, with the Combat Shotgun being a particular favourite, as you blast shells into mutants and bandits alike. There's also an Engineering (aka crafting) element, where you combine components to build certain tools. It's quite fun to build Sentry Turrets and deploy them, as well as RC Car Bombs that you can drive into a group of enemies and detonate. You'll quickly find yourself creating bandages to heal up more quickly, and making a ton of Pop Rockets for your shotgun for that extra explosive bang. Simply put, id knows how to do guns and do them right.As mentioned before, there's a fair bit of car combat in the game. We've since had games like Mad Max that do this quite a bit better, but here it's not too bad. You get a selection of cars throughout the game, and you can arm those with machine guns and rockets. Most of your encounters will be as you drive from one objective to another, and you can earn money from destroying bandit vehicles and returning to Wellspring or Subway Town for rewards. There's a decent amount of things to do in the game, with races and mini-games, plus the two main towns with their Job Boards that offer side quests. The biggest issues with Rage all concern its story and quests. You're mostly looking at a run of fetch quests throughout the game, and everything feels a bit samey. There's a general feeling of "meh" throughout the experience, as you venture into locations (sometimes more than once if you have to go back for a side quest) and dispatch of enemies, then either pick something up to bring back to town or plant something there. This is mostly a game that concerns itself with the fun feeling of shooting things, so in that respect it succeeds, but you'll not be playing this for any interesting or in-depth questlines. It's all going to wash over you, as the story limps to its conclusion. It's clear a sequel was planned, given the rushed, open-ended final cutscene.Overall, I do recommend Rage. I enjoyed my time with it, because the things that id gets right are the things that tend to matter in their games. You're getting a polished combat system, with plenty of nice guns and tons of enemies to shoot them at. You're even getting a small open-world to enjoy, even though there's not all that much to do in it aside from drive around, shoot other cars and occasionally pop in for a quick match of Bash TV. There's a bit more to do in the towns and those are the activities that will take up much of your time. The quests are the major flaw here, being generally uninteresting and uninspired. Rage is still id's most underrated game, and while its flaws will be apparent to you as you play through it, there's some good, solid stuff here that makes for an enjoyable experience.

content:
23, 2014
												The Short: An unsuccessful blend of genresThe Long:With a setting very much like Fallout 3, RAGE instead focuses on being a straight 3D Shooter (not surprisingly given that it’s an id-game) and throws in some fancy driving/racing for good measure. But all these elements never quite gel. The driving feels very much like an afterthought to amp up the game (or an attempt to channel Mad Max 2) but not only does this feel like a separate game within the game (which the racing basically is) but it very much sabotages any kind of open world feeling games like Fallout 3 offer, since you don’t explore the world, you simply drive through it … fast!Also the pacing of the campaign is terrible. It’s basically the concept of a linear shooter disguised as a RPG quest system. The player is rushed from one mission to the next. There are few side quests, mostly lazily designed by revisiting a previous location playing it backwards from end to start the second time. RPG elements are rudimentary and never quite pay off.Characters are superficial and you never get emotionally invested in their stories or fates. But at least the voice acting is fairly good.The storyline is badly constructed. Starting from the initial point from the player being rescued by Hagar just to be send out again to do missions, over establishing the faceless Authority (which way too  much looked like Half-Life 2’s Combine troops) as villains before even properly explaining what makes them villainous, to shoving the player towards joining a Resistance he knows little about. As in fact the whole background of this world is never properly established.On the bright side the game looks very good and plays quite well as a shooter. The locations are well designed, with a decent amount of attention to detail.In my opinion the game would have been better had it focused on being a 3D Shooter. Driving could still have been part of the game, but in a way harmonious to the gameplay (e.g. like Far Cry 2 - as mediocre as that game was).The way it is RAGE pretends to be more than it is and fails on living up to that pretense. It’s not a bad game, but playing it leaves one disappointed because it promised more than it delivered. The ending is also fairly unsatisfactory, but I assume the developers pretty much envisioned it with some "RAGE 2" in mind. In a better game it would have disappointed me. Here I really didn't care.

You'll consistently be dumping your earnings into ammo. Vehicles a bit wonky for keyboard/mouse controls.  Controller recommended.

content:
24, 2016
												I like this game. It is a few years old now but the graphics are still fairly good overall. Overall it is a first-person shooter style game, but they added in a driving/racing aspect that not only seems to work fairly well, but to me adds a degree of realism to a post-apocolyptic world that so many other games seem to lack. And unlike some other games, while you can just walk around out on the main map; taking the buggy or the monarch to drive around definitely gets you there both faster and safer. There is a good amount to do in this game aside from the main quest line in the form of side quests and challenges, as well as several easter eggs from the older id software games that are just kinda cool to collect.Now for the bad. Thw game is fairly linear overall. You can miss out on things by progressing the main storyline too far too fast, and I'm not a big fan of that in open-world games. It's not too bad as long as you do optional side quests first then the main 1 but on initial playthrough it might not be obvious. Also, might just be because I'm late to the party, as in I did not buy this game when it was brand new, but there is never anybody on the multiplayer side of this so I can't unlock the rest of my acheivements. not a huge deal, but a little disappointing.Overall, like I said, I really do enjoy the game. I would rate the overall experience as about a 7 out of 10. Definitely worth trying.

content:
22, 2016
												I acquired RAGE on a sale, and for the price I paid, I'd recommend the experience.  The world is gorgeous, in a post-apocalyptic, Fallout-like style, with some obvious Fallout-like ripoffs.  Still, it's worth it just to experience some of the really immersive visuals.  The characters and people are reasonably good, beautifully crafted, fully voiced with a variety of personalities (even if some of the acting is forced).  Also, the first "Dead City" experience was really memorable.The game is largely good, but suffers from a lack of direction and from trying to do & to be too much.  The crafting system is interesting and provides some value, but largely unnecessary to complete the game.  The various minigames, too, are value-added, but in the same way that finding spare change in your pocket is value-added.  The vehicles actually drive very nicely and are enjoyable, and the vehicular combat isn't bad, but the entire racing circuit side-game is virtually mandatory and--as such--is a detriment.The game is arguably broken up into three sections, by "hub".  The first and third sections are really short, while the second is probably over-long.  The first section, being short, makes sense.  Its an intro to the game; the starting quest hub.  The brevity of the third hub, however, and the entire third section of the storyline--including the anticlimactic end stage and ending--feels shockingly unfinished, especially compared with some real gems in the section section (Wellspring), most notably the first visit to the Dead City.Ultimately, I'd recommend the game, if only to experience the first half to two-thirds of it.

content:
, 2016
												In my opinion, Rage isn't so bad, for the price at least ($4.99 Discount) ($9.99 Original price). The game suffers greatly from pop-ins, boring story, and stiff gameplay. For some reason lowering the graphic settings seems to help simmer down the pop in issues for me. The FPS combat aspect is fun but still lacking. The enemies' movements are pretty cool, but you as the player, your movements are very poor in comparison.If the player had the abilities to evade and maneuver more like or similar to the enemies it would be a great asset to the gameplay. I haven't gotten far into the story, but I can tell you now it isn't something great. While the beginning shows something unique it quickly starts to fall bland and boneless. So far it has been missions such as:"Go to this person and get something."OH, that person's something has been stolen. "Go to a Raider's camp and retrieve it."There is no actual Open world, everything is oddly convenient. Also, you can't pick up enemy weapons and gear. The game is very, very, basic. Which is unfortunate, it had potential. Rage has a Mad Max feel to it, you can race with your buggy and combat enemies with mounted weapons, but sadly the world just isn't open enough to justify it. This game is simply nothing exciting, but truth is I'm enjoying the game for what it costs. I would say give the game a try if it's on discount. I wouldn't recommend paying $10 as for this game honestly doesn't feel like a $10 game.Final Rating: 6/10 Could've been much better.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Seriously... BORING UNEVENTFUL STORY.I actively wished the entire game to have a CHOICE in ANYTHING, especially being able to side with the so-called 'authority' because they got cool armor and seemed to have some sembelance of an idea what the hell they were doing.I do not recommend this game for someone who wants:1) A good storyline with a thorough ending.2) Interesting characters you can interact with3) An open worldAdditionally, if you DO NOT want the following; beware:1) Racing is REQUIRED in the main storyline. (I do okay in racing games and was able to complete them, but I do not like them)2) a couple mini bosses but no real skill requirement to fight anything3) Endless random vendor trash to sell for no apparent reason.4) Endless ammo if you so choose.5) Enemies which while having some intelligence, still seem to put their back to you when you throw a grenade at them. (seriously, just watched 2 people run around cover and turn to face the grenade with me looking at them... smart.)6) A lack of 'fun guns' to play with. Ultimately, I ended up using the shotgun almost the entire game because using 'Pop Rockets' (grenade ammo) is simply the only weapon I found enjoyable, side for shooting mutants with an assault rifle and then slamming them in the face with melee. (other than this, wingsticks were my only other weapon choice)-Some BACKGROUND:I played RAGE originally back in 2012 and after getting bored with it, I stopped playing. This was after about 2 hours of the game and I had not completed the game.Then, again in 2014 I picked up the game again (figuratively) and played past the part I stopped at previously. Again, I became bored out of my mind and uninstalled it.Finally, in 2016 I finished it.Yes, I was bored with an id game. Three times now. I only beat the game to prove I could and... dear god it was still a waste of my time. (Surprisingly, yes I always enjoyed Doom 1,2 and 3, also played the original wolfenstein games and commander keen. So, I love id and I think they have a great staff.)Sadly, this game has dissappointed me greatly. When I first picked it up, read the cover and thought back to the trailers; I said "My, this would rock if it's anything like what is described." That is simply not the case.I was hopeful of a Fallout3/NewVegas with a doom atmosphere, because out of everything I want a survival horror wasteland game if I can get one. (Even if doom is a bit shooty ;-)Regardless, this game at first tries to fool you. It gives you quests, loot drops, corpses to desecrate and thereby steal gear from; but ultimately none of it matters. On top of all this; characters all spew dialog for long enough to make me decide to step away from my desk to grab a snack while they yammer, before I can actually get a quest or shop from them.If you want to jump into a shooter and just blow people and mutants up, it can be fun. I won't deny that. But ultimately, I have stopped playing it two other times because some areas are just so unbelievably boring.A final thought, the higher you crank the difficulty the higher enemy HP is. (very annoying as that is the only noticable difference)
